TITLE: Malema corruption case postponed
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); BAIL (88%); MONEY LAUNDERING (86%)
TEXT: The fraud and corruption case against expelled ANC youth league leader Julius Malema and four others was postponed in the Polokwane High Court this morning. Magistrate Janine Ungerer ruled the matter would resume on June 20, when a High Court date for their trial would be set. Malema is accused of having made nearly R4 million from corrupt activities. He is out on bail of R10,000 and faces charges of fraud, corruption, money-laundering, and racketeering. Appearing with Malema were his business associates Kagisho Dichabe, Lesiba Gwangwa, Helen Moreroa and Makgetsi Manthata, who were granted bail of R40,000 each on September 25.

TITLE: Malema corruption case postponed to June
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (91%); BRIBERY (88%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (88%); MONEY LAUNDERING (72%); JAIL SENTENCING (72%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (72%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (70%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (54%)
TEXT: Julius Malema, the expelled leader of South Africa's ruling ANC youth wing will return to court in June after his corruption case was postponed today. Magistrate Janine Ungerer delayed the case until June 20, when she is expected to set a date for the trial to be moved to a High Court. The ex-ANC firebrand is facing charges of corruption, money laundering and racketeering, based on allegations that he arranged lucrative government contracts for cronies in return for kickbacks. He was charged with four of his business associates and faces up to 15 years in prison. The financial affairs of the once influential 31-year-old, who is known for his extravagant lifestyle, were subject to a probe last year by the public watchdog. Some of his assets, including a farm and household goods, have been seized by the taxman to cover over US$2 million (1.5 million euro) in unpaid taxes.

TITLE: Two former officials of NA found guilty of corruption will face sentence in High Court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); VERDICTS (90%); SENTENCING (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); JUDGES (88%)
TEXT: Two former officials of the National Assembly (NA) who were earlier this year found guilty of corruption, will face sentencing in the High Court here tomorrow. The two men - former National Assembly Secretary Nama Goabab, 55, and former National Assembly Accountant Abraham George, 52 - were each found guilty on a charge of corruption which was dealt with under the Anti-Corruption Act of 2004. The two men were supposed to be sentenced on Friday last week, but Acting High Court Judge Marlene Tommasi who is presiding over the case, could not do so due to other official commitments. In a judgment delivered in the High Court in Windhoek earlier this year, Acting Judge Tommasi found Goabab and George guilty on one of three charges of corruption each in a trial before her since the end of March 2010. The charge against the two men emanated from their actions of corruptly using their positions to rent motor vehicles for private use at the government's cost.

TITLE: Ex-NA officials receive suspended sentences for corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); SENTENCING (94%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (92%); VERDICTS (90%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (90%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (90%); LITIGATION (90%); EVIDENCE (89%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (78%); LEGISLATION (78%); JUDGES (78%); ARRESTS (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (71%); INVESTIGATIONS (70%); ACQUITTAL (66%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (65%); WAGES & SALARIES (60%)
TEXT: Two former officials of the National Assembly (NA) who were earlier this year found guilty on a charge of corruption, got wholly suspended sentences. The two men - former National Assembly Secretary Nama Goabab, 55, and former National Assembly Accountant Abraham George, 52 - were each found guilty on a charge of corruption which was dealt with under the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003. Goabab was sentenced to three (3) years imprisonment which was wholly suspended for a period of five (5) years on condition that the former Secretary to the National Assembly is not convicted of contravening Section 43 (1) of the Anti-Corruption Act (Act Eight) of 2003 committed during the period of suspension. George was sentenced to one (1) year imprisonment which was also wholly suspended for a period of five (5) years on condition that the former NA accountant is not convicted of contravening Section 43 (1) of the Anti-Corruption Act (Act Eight) of 2003 committed during the period of suspension. Acting High Court Judge Marlene Tommasi imposed the sentences in the matter here on Friday morning. 'Contravening Section 43 (1) of the Anti-Corruption Act (Act Eight) of 2003 is a serious offence. Crimes of corruption should be visited with vigorous punishment. This court is, however, of the view that a wholly suspended sentence would be an appropriate punishment in this matter, ' said acting Judge as she handed down punishment today. In her judgment delivered in the High Court in Windhoek earlier this year, Acting Judge Tommasi found Goabab guilty on one of three charges of corruption in a trial before her since the end of March 2010. George was also found guilty on the same charge. The two men were, however, both acquitted on the two other charges against them. The charge against the two men emanated from their actions of corruptly using their positions to rent motor vehicles for private use at the government's cost. The two men rented two cars during March and April 2007. The total cost of the vehicle rentals is alleged to have been N.dollars 23 552 and N.dollars 18 497, which had initially been paid by the National Assembly. Evidence before trial had it that Goabab also unlawfully used a government car on 25 May 2007 while he was receiving a motor vehicle allowance as part of his salary. Four days after Goabab and George were arrested by the investigators of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) in June 2007, Goabab paid the money back. During trial, Goabab's attorney Lucious Murorua told the court the State failed to prove charges of corruption against his client. According to Murorua, there is no prima facie evidence presented before court by the State upon which a reasonable court could convict Goabab, and in the circumstances he is entitled to be discharged on this basis alone. Murorua strongly argued there is no evidence of gratification against his client, as set out in the definition in the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003. Advocate Zagrys Grobler, who is appearing for George, argued that his client acted on the instruction of his senior, and did not have the necessary intent to defraud the State. George testified in his own defence that he was only following instructions from Goabab when he helped to arrange the two rentals and the use of the National Assembly funds for payment. (edited)WINDHOEK; Two former officials of the National Assembly (NA) who were earlier this year found guilty on a charge of corruption, received wholly-suspended sentences here on Friday. Former NA Secretary Nama Goabab, 55, and former NA accountant Abraham George, 52, were each found guilty on a charge of corruption, which was dealt with under the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003. Goabab was sentenced to three years imprisonment, which was wholly suspended for a period of five years on condition that he is not convicted of contravening Section 43 (1) of the Anti-Corruption Act (Act Eight) of 2003 during the period of suspension. George was sentenced to one year imprisonment, which was also wholly suspended for a period of five years on condition that he is not convicted of contravening Section 43 (1) of the Anti-Corruption Act (Act Eight) of 2003 during the period of suspension. Handing-down punishment, Acting High Court Judge Marlene Tommasi said contravening Section 43 (1) of the Anti-Corruption Act (Act Eight) of 2003 is a serious offence. "Crimes of corruption should be visited with vigorous punishment. This court is, however, of the view that a wholly suspended sentence would be an appropriate punishment in this matter," she said. In her judgement delivered in the High Court in Windhoek earlier this year, Tommasi found Goabab guilty on one of three charges of corruption in the trial before her since the end of March 2010. George was also found guilty on the same charge. The two men were both acquitted on the two other charges against them. The charge against the two men emanated from their actions of corruptly using their positions to rent motor-vehicles for Goabab's private use at the government's cost. The cars were rented during March and April 2007. The charge on which they were convicted was based on an allegation that money from the National Assembly's budget had been used to pay for the rental of cars for Goabab's private use. According to Goabab, the arrangement was that the money paid for the vehicle rentals be recovered from his salary. Acting Judge Tommasi ruled in her verdict that the use of public funds to settle a personal debt of Goabab, even if it was his intention from the start to repay the money, was unlawful and amounted to him having used his position to obtain gratification in the form of a loan for his own benefit. Chief State Prosecutor Danie Small during trial agreed that a fine or, in the case of George, a suspended sentence, would be the most appropriate punishment. The total cost of the vehicle rentals is alleged to have been N.dollars 23 552 and N.dollars 18 497, respectively, which had initially been paid by the National Assembly. Evidence before trial had it that Goabab also unlawfully used a government car on 25 May 2007 while he was receiving a motor-vehicle allowance as part of his salary. Four days after Goabab and George were arrested by the investigators of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) in June 2007, Goabab paid the money back. Goabab and George had been free on a bail of N.dollars 5000 each.

TITLE: Ethiopian government minister, businessmen to face corruption charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); LITIGATION (90%); ARRESTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (88%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (88%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (88%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (88%); TAX FRAUD (73%); TAX LAW (73%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (68%)
TEXT: An Ethiopian court ruled today that prosecutors have two weeks to finalize corruption charges against two dozen people who have been arrested, including a senior Cabinet minister. The 24 people charged include the head of Ethiopia's revenue and customs authority, Melaku Fenta. They are accused of illegal trading and tax evasion. Ethiopia's top anti-corruption official, Ali Sulaiman, told parliament today that the suspects had been under surveillance for over two years. Prosecutors yesterday requested permission to keep the suspects in custody for two more weeks for questioning. The country's intelligence agency and corruption watchdog announced the arrests of 13 people over the weekend, but court documents now show an expanded list of suspects that includes family members of the accused.

TITLE: Acting Keetmans CEO accused of corruption
SUBJECT: EXECUTIVES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); MAYORS (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%)
TEXT: The Acting Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Keetmanshoop Municipality Hermanus Losper is under fire as he already faces allegations of corruption after just a few months in office. Information availed to Nampa indicates that last month Losper allegedly received a quotation "backdoor" from his wife to fix municipality computers and pays her N.dollars 3 800. His wife's quotation was allegedly handed to him and was never discussed by efficiency committee (tender board sub-committee). The source further alleges that when tender board sub-committee discussed the repair of the computers with Losper, he apparently misled them that he had found someone who can do the work for less than N.dollars 1000; this is less than what his wife was paid. Other allegations are that, on 29 May 2013 the acting CEO instructed municipality supervisor for town lands, De Jay to give council tools and equipment to town mayor Moses Titus for private use at his farm. "The equipment includes spanners, pulleys and chains. These are municipal properties and may not be hired by outsiders. Titus abused his office power to demand the equipment and use them on his farm. They are not for hire and have not been returned to date," a reliable source told the news agency. Confronted with the allegations on Wednesday, Losper explained that on the issue of his wife's quotation there were only two quotations when the tender board sub-committee met to discuss them. It was later realised that there has to be three quotations before any selection is done and that is when the third quotation for Losper's wife came in. "We discussed and agreed that the lowest quotation will be selected, so my wife's quotation happens to be the lowest and she qualified for the job. I did not mislead anyone, the tender board sub-committee usually selects candidates even when there are only one or two quotations, that is wrong and I stopped it," he defended. Responding to the tools and equipment he allegedly gave to the mayor; Losper said he does not see anything wrong with the move, because giving tools for private use by council members is a common practice in their council. "I found them doing it so it is common practice here. As long as the person signs that they have received the tools and promise to return it then they get it. Yes they are not for hire that's why I did not see the need for payment," Losper responded. TITLE: Vavi covered up corruption to protect his ally - report
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); BANKING & FINANCE (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (88%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (88%); FINANCIAL PLANNING (88%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (73%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (66%); LABOR UNIONS (55%)
TEXT: Cosatu general secretary Zwelinzima Vavi allegedly covered up a report on apparent corruption involving its investment company to protect his ally, the Mail & Guardian reported today. The report by the Financial Service Board (FSB) apparently found cases of corruption, fraud, and money laundering involving the Congress of SA Trade Unions' investment company Kopana ke Matla and Westside Financial Services. The newspaper said two sources with insight into the report had confirmed that Kopana ke Matla conducted financial advisory services without approval in terms of the Financial Advisory and Intermediary Services Act. The two people had told the newspaper the report recommended that criminal charges be brought against senior staff members of Kopana ke Matla. One Cosatu leader said the report recommended the matter be reported to the Hawks for criminal investigation but Vavi did nothing about it.

TITLE: Brazilian President vows to battle corruption while improving government services as she acknowledges the anger that has led to vast protests
SUBJECT: PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (91%); SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (90%); RIOTS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL PROTESTS (88%); CITY LIFE (86%); PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION (86%); SUMMER OLYMPICS (65%); SOCCER (65%); SPORTS & RECREATION (65%); TOURNAMENTS (65%); FIFA WORLD CUP (65%); SOCCER TOURNAMENTS (50%)
TEXT: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff vowed to battle corruption while improving government services as she acknowledged the anger that has led to vast, sometimes violent protests across Latin America's largest country. Yesterday's nationally broadcast 10-minute address ended Rousseff's much-criticized silence in the face of demonstrations that have roiled the nation for more than a week, and were projected to continue today. Rousseff said that her government would create a national plan for public transportation in cities. Officials in many cities have already backed down from the hike in bus and subway fares that set off the protests. Some 1 million anti-government demonstrators took to the streets nationwide Thursday night to denounce everything from poor public services to the billions of dollars spent preparing for next year's World Cup soccer tournament and the 2016 Olympics in Brazil.

TITLE: A Cairo court has adjourned to August 17 retrial of former President Hosni Mubarak over charges of corruption and involvement in killing of protesters during 2011 uprising
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ELECTIONS (88%); APPOINTMENTS (88%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (88%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (73%); APPEALS COURTS (73%)
TEXT: A Cairo court has adjourned to August 17 the retrial of former President Hosni Mubarak over charges of corruption and involvement in the killing of protesters during the 2011 uprising that ousted him. Mubarak and his two sons, Alaa and Gamal, who are on trial for corruption, appeared at the court session today. Mubarak is charged with both corruption and responsibility for the deaths of some 850 protesters during the early days of the 2011 revolt. The former leader was convicted in 2012 of the charges, but an appeals court granted a retrial. Mubarak's democratically elected successor, Mohammed Morsi, was overthrown by the military on Wednesday and replaced with an interim president as part of what the army says is a roadmap to new elections.

TITLE: South Sudan guilty of widespread human rights abuses and awash with corruption
COUNTRY: SUDAN (95%); SOUTH SUDAN (79%); PAKISTAN (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ANNIVERSARIES (78%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (74%); CIVIL WAR (73%); REFERENDUMS (65%); NATIONAL SECURITY (55%); PEACE PROCESS (50%)
TEXT: South Sudan is guilty of widespread human rights abuses and awash with corruption, campaigners warned on the second anniversary of the country's independence today. US activists who backed the split from Sudan claimed in a letter that the fledgling country faces 'an increasingly perilous state'. Signatories of the letter, which accuses the new country of failing its own people and repeating the mistakes of previous rulers before independence, include John Prendergast, a former director for African affairs at the White House's National Security Council. 'Many people in South Sudan are suffering, yet government officials seem to care only about themselves,' reads the letter, also signed by former US State Department officials including Ted Dagne, a former advisor to the government. The activists, who call themselves the 'Friends of South Sudan', also said there was 'clear evidence of massive corruption' and urged 'profound reform'. South Sudan split from Sudan on July 9, 2011, after its people voted overwhelmingly for independence in a referendum six months earlier, part of a 2005 peace deal that ended one of Africa's longest civil wars.

TITLE: Six people arrested by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) for alleged fraud involving over N.dollars 71 million
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ARRESTS (91%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LAWYERS (74%); JUDGES (72%)
TEXT: The suspects made their first appearance on 16 May this year in the Windhoek High Court before High Court Judge-President Petrus Damaseb during a pre-trial conference, in which both the prosecution's representatives and the accused persons' defence lawyers came together to decide on how to proceed with the matter, and to decide on a date for the trial proper. The group includes key suspect and former AfriSam cement company employee Esmerelda Majiedt, 45. The other five suspects are Rundu businessmen Daniel Batista de Jesus, 36; Calvin Bezuidenhoudt, 49; the latter's brother Gerhard Bezuidenhoudt, 40; Majiedt's sister Louise Izaaks, 49; as well as a former partner of Izaaks', James Wilson, 55. The group, arrested in 2011 and 2012, will altogether face a total of 630 charges of fraud, theft and corruption, according to a decision taken by the Office of Prosecutor-General Martha Ekandjo-Imalwa. The other five accused persons were added as accused persons in the case in which Majiedt was initially charged alone when they made their first court appearance before Windhoek Magistrate Ingrid Lerato Unengu on 22 October 2012.

TITLE: UN has voiced fears about a new media law in Somalia only days after UN experts sounded alarm over corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LEGISLATION (90%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (90%); WRITERS (90%); FREEDOM OF PRESS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); MUSLIMS & ISLAM (77%); FREEDOM OF SPEECH (77%); FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION (72%); RELIGION (56%)
TEXT: The United Nations has voiced fears about a new media law in Somalia only days after UN experts sounded the alarm over corruption in the African country's new government. The UN Human Rights Office has urged President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud's government to review a new law that would require journalists to reveal sources and prevent them spreading information against Islam or Somali traditions, said a statement released today. Rupert Colville, spokesman for the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, said the legislation was 'vague' and 'could easily be used to curtail freedom of expression.' The draft legislation, which could become law within two months, requires journalists to reveal their sources if published information stirs up public sentiment, and would suspend journalists accused of violating the media legislation. The president took power with UN and widespread international backing in September, heading a government that took over from eight years of corruption-riddled transitional rule. It has only a limited rule as the government and an African Union force battles Shebab Islamists. But the new administration was considered a beacon of hope as Somalia has had no effective government since the fall of dictator Mohamed Siad Barre in 1990.

TITLE: Public hearing into alleged corruption in multi-million arms deal underway in Pretoria
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC HEARINGS (90%); RESIGNATIONS (88%)
TEXT: Public hearings into alleged corruption in the 1999 multi-million arms deal get underway in Pretoria today. This would come after a five-month delay and the 11th-hour resignation of one of the commissioners. The Arms Procurement Commission said on Friday its schedule would not be derailed by Judge Francis Legodi's departure. But the Democratic Alliance noted that the judge's resignation -- for undisclosed personal reasons -- was 'the latest setback in a series of setbacks' suffered by the commission since it was established by President Jacob Zuma in November 2011. These include the immediate resignation of Judge Willem van der Merwe, followed by those of senior investigator Norman Moabi in January and law researcher Kate Painting in March. The deal has dogged South African politics since it was signed and nearly scuppered Zuma's ascent to the presidency.

TITLE: Everyone has a role to play in preventing corruption and should become eyes and ears of law-enforcement agencies in this fight: ACC Director
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); JOB CREATION (68%); EMPLOYMENT GROWTH (68%)
TEXT: Everyone has a role to play in preventing corruption, and should become the eyes and ears of law-enforcement agencies in this fight, Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) Director Paulus Noa says. He made these remarks during the Ministry of Information and Communication Technology (MICT)'s annual general staff meeting here on Friday. Noa said corruption, whether in the public service or in any other sector, has a corrosive effect to good governance and public order. He noted that it does not really matter whether it takes the form of administrative corruption, or grand corruption, saying it retards economic growth. According to Noa, a lack of effectiveness in the execution of official duties, lack of transparency in service delivery, inconsistency in the enforcement of disciplinary actions and lack of a culture of accountability are some of the administrative misconducts which result in corruption if not dealt with. Noa added that the prevention of corruption is a precondition to high and sustained economic growth, employment-creation and increased income equality, which goals are focused on in the Fourth National Development Plan (NDP4).

TITLE: Noa calls on politicians to fight corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); ETHICS (89%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); RULE OF LAW (75%); PUBLIC FINANCE (73%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (71%); TAX LAW (70%); TAXES & TAXATION (70%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (68%); TAX FRAUD (54%)
TEXT: Director of Anti-Corruption Commission Paulus Noah says fighting corruption requires persistence from political leadership. Noah said this during the first day of the two-day National accountability Institutions Conference in the capital on Tuesday. "That is what is termed political will. Political commitment to fight corruption does not imply exclusive commitment from the Executive. It is a commitment that is demonstrated from the Executive to equally other organs of the State," he said. Noah said corruption has negative effects on citizens whose members of Parliament represent in Parliament adding that parliament therefore cannot ignore the fight against corruption or leave it to other oversight institutions only. He stressed that corruption destroys good governance, peace and public order, and it reduces revenue collection through money-laundering and tax evasion. The director said corruption drives away investment opportunities and in the process exacerbates poverty and inequality and it also erodes democracy and rule of law which are the hallmarks of democracy. It results in the mismanagement of public projects and ignorance of sound national policies. It results into moral decay and in the end those occupying public positions do no longer uphold ethical values. "While in the end the entire citizenry becomes the victims of corruption, the worst and immediate victims of corruption are the already impoverished members of the society. It should not be ignored that corruption can cause anarchy and public disorder when livelihood of citizens does not improve on account of corruption," Noah said. He said Citizens (electorate) has used their "power of ballot" to elect their representatives whom they trust to serve their interest, thus Parliamentarians have a role to impeccably demonstrate that it raises awareness and remain vigilant to ensure that corruption does not spread its tentacles. The conference ends on Wednesday (07 August 2013). (edited)WINDHOEK: The Director of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), Paulus Noa says fighting corruption requires persistence from the country's political leadership. "That is what is termed political will. Political commitment to fight corruption does not imply exclusive commitment from the Executive. It is a commitment that is demonstrated from the Executive to equally other organs of the State," he said on the first day of the two-day national accountability institutions' conference. The conference, which was held under the theme 'Working towards Coordinated Strategies in Strengthening the Accountability Process in Namibia', started in the capital on Tuesday. It was aimed at discussing topics such as Parliament and accountability; the legislative link between the Auditor-General and other accountability institutions; the role of civil society in the accountability process; and ethics and accountability, amongst other things. Noa said corruption has negative effects on citizens, whose Members of Parliament represent them in Parliament, adding that it therefore cannot ignore the fight against corruption or leave it to other oversight institutions only. Corruption destroys good governance, peace and public order, and reduces revenue-collection through money-laundering and tax evasion, he stated adding that corruption also drives away investment opportunities, and in the process exacerbates poverty and inequality. It also erodes democracy and the rule of law, which are the hallmarks of democracy. It furthermore results in the mismanagement of public projects, ignorance about sound national policies, moral decay and in the end, those occupying public positions no longer uphold ethical values. "While in the end the entire citizenry becomes the victims of corruption, the worst and immediate victims of corruption are the already impoverished members of society. It should not be ignored that corruption can cause anarchy and public disorder when the livelihoods of citizens do not improve on account of corruption," Noa stressed. He said citizens (the electorate) have used their 'power of ballot' to elect their representatives whom they trust to serve their interest. Thus, parliamentarians have a role to impeccably demonstrate that it raises awareness, and remain vigilant to ensure that corruption does not spread its tentacles. Over 50 African parliamentarians from various countries are attending the conference, which ends on Wednesday. The conference was organised by the Namibian Parliament, in conjunction with the African Development Fund and the African Development Bank.

TITLE: Corruption trial of former Zambian president thrown into disarray
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); WITNESSES (90%); LAWYERS (75%); CONTRACT AWARDS (71%)
TEXT: The corruption trial of former Zambian president Rupiah Banda was thrown into disarray yesterday when the state's star witness denied the embattled ex-leader's had benefitted from a $2.5 million oil contract. Banda is charged with abusing his authority in awarding the Nigerian oil contract and was allegedly to benefit from the proceeds from the deal. But the head of the firm which facilitated the deal unexpectedly denied the charges in court, and denounced the trial as politically motivated. Akan Ekpene said Zambia never paid a single cent and it never lost any money, adding they paid the $2.5 million as deposit on behalf of Zambia and this money has been recovered by themselves. Having travelled from Nigeria for the trial, Ekpene broke down when a Banda lawyer accused him of turning state witness out of hate. Banda has pleaded not guilty after he was stripped of presidential immunity and arrested in March.

TITLE: Egypt's former president Hosni Mubarak granted conditional release in one of the corruption cases against him, but will remain in custody on charges in an additional case
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); LAWYERS (90%); HOMICIDE (72%)
TEXT: Egypt's former president Hosni Mubarak has been granted conditional release in one of the corruption cases against him, but will remain in custody on charges in an additional case, judicial sources said today. His lawyer plans to appeal against the fourth and final case, which is also related to corruption, in a bid to secure the former president's release, according to a judicial source. Farid al-Dib, Mubarak's lawyer, is expected to argue that his client paid back the $600,120 (449,570 euros) worth of gifts he received from his minister of information -- the issue at the heart of the fourth case. Since April, courts have ordered Mubarak's conditional release in two of the four cases against him -- one involving corruption, and a second for allegedly killing protesters. Today, he was granted conditional release in a third case, and will now seek to be cleared of charges in the fourth, the judicial sources said. The former president, 85, is on trial with his former interior minister Habib Adly and six police commanders on charges related to their rule before the 2011 uprising that toppled his regime.

TITLE: Chinese court hearing corruption case against disgraced politician Bo Xilai has released videotaped testimony from his wife, whose murder of a British businessman set off the scandal that ruined Bo's career
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); TESTIMONY (91%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); MURDER (90%); SCANDALS (90%); WITNESSES (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (73%); POLITICS (73%)
TEXT: The Chinese court hearing the corruption case against disgraced politician Bo Xilai has released videotaped testimony from his wife, whose murder of a British businessman set off the scandal that ruined Bo's career. The video of Gu Kailai released Friday is intended to bolster bribery allegations against her husband. Gu has not been seen she was convicted of murder in China's messiest political scandal in decades. In the video, Gu says a businessman accused of bribing Bo was a family friend who often paid for the family's international air tickets and brought gifts that included expensive seafood and a Segway, an electric standup scooter. Bo has launched a spirited defense in the trial that opened Thursday. He denies taking bribes and questions his wife's credibility and even her mental health.

TITLE: Seriti Commission of Inquiry into alleged corruption in 1999 arms deal resumes in Pretoria
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%)
TEXT: The Seriti Commission of Inquiry into alleged corruption in the 1999 arms deal resumes in Pretoria today. Yesterday, SA Navy Rear Admiral Derek Christian, the commission's fourth witness, was asked by evidence leader Simmy Lebala to explain the allocation of funds for national defence, against other competing socio-economic demands. Lebala asked Christian to explain how the navy would fare without the equipment acquired through the controversial arms procurement deal. Lebala then asked what would be the future of the SA Navy without these capabilities? Christian told the commission, sitting in Pretoria, that without the arms deal vessels, the navy would be crippled.

TITLE: A Chinese official drowned by investigators who stripped him naked and held him down in a bathtub as they attempted to extort a confession to corruption, state-run media reported
SUBJECT: EXTORTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); NEWS REPORTING (90%); FORENSICS (73%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (72%); CONTUSIONS (68%)
TEXT: A Chinese official was allegedly drowned by investigators who stripped him naked and held him down in a bathtub as they attempted to extort a confession to corruption, state-run media reported Wednesday. Yu Qiyi was held down by graft investigators in a tub full of 'icy water' several times after his questioning failed to produce satisfactory answers, the Beijing Times said, citing a court filing by prosecutors. They only stopped when Yu, 42, the chief engineer of a state-owned company in the eastern city of Wenzhou, stopped struggling, the report said. He was taken to hospital and died a few hours later. A post-mortem showed he had been made to 'imbibe liquids' that caused pulmonary dysfunction and eventually his death, according to a photograph of a forensic document carried by the newspaper. Relatives also found multiple bruises on his body after his death in April, it added. He had been detained since early March over suspected wrongdoings in a land deal, the report said.

TITLE: Somalia said that international investigators commissioned by government had cleared it of corruption accusations leveled by UN monitors
COUNTRY: SOMALIA (94%); AFRICA (93%); ERITREA (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (92%); PAKISTAN (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); MIDDLE EAST (79%); EUROPE (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); WEAPONS INSPECTIONS (88%); CAMPAIGN FINANCE (86%); GOVERNORS (54%)
TEXT: Somalia said today that international investigators commissioned by its government had cleared it of corruption accusations levelled by United Nations monitors. The Horn of Africa country is striving to shake off the tag of one of the world's most corrupt nations as it emerges from two decades of conflict and lawlessness. In July, the United Nations Monitoring Group on Somalia and Eritrea said Mogadishu's central bank had become a 'slush fund' for political leaders and that the current governor played a central role in irregularities surrounding unaccountable disbursements of cash. The Mogadishu government said it had commissioned FTI Consulting, whose chairman for the Europe, Middle East and Africa region is British peer Lord Mark Malloch-Brown, and a U.S. law firm to investigate the findings. Central Bank of Somalia Governor Abdusalam Omer has denied the allegations against him, branding them malicious.

TITLE: ACC launches report on anti-corruption frameworks
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (90%); SMALL BUSINESS (89%); RISK MANAGEMENT (89%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (78%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (76%); CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (71%); PUBLIC CONTRACTS LAW (64%)
TEXT: The Anti Corruption Commission (ACC) launched a survey report on the existence of anti-corruption frameworks within private and State-Owned Enterprises (SOE) in the country here on Thursday. Although the survey was commissioned in November 2012, the actual field work only commenced on 04 March 2013 and was completed on the 13 April 2013. The broad objective of the survey was to establish if participating organisations have any anti-corruption policy framework in existence to minimize occurrences of corruption. This includes strategies and tools the private sector and SOEs use to improve transparency, accountability and risk management as a way of ensuring good governance. The geographical area that was covered is that of paid up members of the Namibia Chamber of Commerce and Industry (NCCI). The covered NCCI branches include Ongwediva, Windhoek, Swakopmund, Walvis Bay and the //Karas region. Other areas were not covered because efforts to obtain the list of the members of those branches were in vain the report indicated. The enterprises (study population) were divided into medium to national and small enterprises respectively and the results are alongside that division. The survey thus revealed that most of the enterprises have an anti-corruption policy framework in place adding that the medium to national enterprises registered a higher percentage of 92 per cent with anti-corruption framework in place. The small enterprises registered 73 per cent. On the issue of risk management, the medium to national enterprises again were in the lead with 77 per cent with such tools in place compared to the small enterprises with 65 per cent. According to the report most of the enterprises merely have guidelines in place especially the small enterprises which is why they are lacking on tools or strategies on accountability, transparency and risk management. The report highly recommended the enterprises develop a comprehensive anti-corruption policy framework supported by a fully operational guideline. This will ensure a total response against corruption and hence minimize if not eliminate corrupt incidence in the sector under review and the country at large,ŒÂ it said. Giving the keynote address during the official launch of the survey report held at Nice Restaurant Director of the ACC Paulus Noa said one of the mandates of the ACC is to examine the practices, systems and procedures of public bodies and private bodies in facilitating the discovery of corrupt practices. The ACC he said is further mandated by law to advise public bodies and private bodies on ways of preventing corrupt practices and on changes of practices, systems and procedures compatible with the effective performance of their duties. ŒÂThe best method to fight corruption is to prevent it. Government through public institutions has to set the standard of zero tolerance for corruption for the private companies to follow,ŒÂ he stated. Applicable rules for public procurement must be known by all participants he pointed out adding that bidding procedures must be above board and transparent enough. He urged that there should be no room for collusion either between officials of public and private companies or through intermediaries and that the use of third party should not be done under the veil of secrecy. ŒÂThough the survey did not reach out all the companies in the country, the outcome clearly shows that private enterprises must review their existing framework to become more compliant with the acceptable standards,ŒÂ he said. Although the survey was commissioned in November 2012, the actual fieldwork only commenced on 04 March 2013 and was completed on 13 April this year. The broad objective of the survey was to establish whether participating organisations have anti-corruption policy frameworks to minimise corruption. This includes strategies and tools which the private sector and SOEs use to improve transparency, accountability and risk management as a way of ensuring good governance. The geographical area covered by the survey is that of paid-up members of the Namibia Chamber of Commerce and Industry (NCCI), including the NCCI branches at Ongwediva, Windhoek, Swakopmund, Walvis Bay and in the //Karas Region. The report indicated that other areas were not covered because it could not obtain the list of members in these areas. The enterprises (study population) were divided into medium to national and small enterprises respectively, and the results are given along those categories. The survey revealed that most of the enterprises have an anti-corruption policy framework in place, with medium to national enterprises registering a higher percentage of 92 per cent of businesses with an anti-corruption framework in place. The small enterprises registered 73 per cent. On the issue of risk management, the medium-to-national enterprises were once again in the lead with 77 per cent, while amongst the small enterprises, only 65 per cent had risk management strategies in place. According to the report, most of the enterprises merely have guidelines in place, especially the small enterprises, which is why they lack tools or strategies on accountability, transparency and risk management. The report highly recommended that the enterprises should develop a comprehensive anti-corruption policy framework, supported by fully-operational guidelines. "This will ensure a total response against corruption and hence minimise, if not eliminate, corrupt incidences in the sector under review and the country at large," it said. Delivering the keynote address during the official launch of the report in the capital, ACC Director Paulus Noa said one of the mandates of the commission is to examine the practices, systems and procedures of public bodies and private bodies in facilitating the discovery of corrupt practices. The ACC is further mandated by law to advise public bodies and private bodies on ways of preventing corrupt practices and on changes of practices, systems and procedures compatible with the effective performance of their duties. "The best method to fight corruption is to prevent it. Government, through public institutions, has to set the standard of zero tolerance for corruption for the private companies to follow," he stated. He furthermore pointed out that applicable rules for public procurement must be known by all participants, adding that bidding procedures must be above board and transparent. Noa said there should be no room for collusion either between officials of public and private companies or through intermediaries, and the use of a third party should not be done under a "veil of secrecy". "Though the survey did not reach out to all companies in the country, the outcome clearly shows that private enterprises must review their existing frameworks to become more compliant with acceptable standards," he noted.

TITLE: Uganda said it had suspended 24 of its army officers, who were part of a UN-mandated force battling Al-Qaeda linked rebels in Somalia, over corruption allegations
SUBJECT: ARMIES (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); AL-QAEDA (90%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (90%); ARMED FORCES (90%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (88%); UNOFFICIAL ECONOMY (71%)
TEXT: Uganda said today it had suspended 24 of its army officers, who were part of a UN-mandated force battling Al-Qaeda linked rebels in Somalia, over corruption allegations. A defence ministry spokesman said among those recalled for 'getting involved in conduct injurious' to the African Union AMISOM force was the head of the 6,000-strong Ugandan contingent, Brigadier Michael Ondoga. 'They were suspended two days ago,' the Ugandan defence spokesman, Colonel Paddy Ankunda, told AFP. According to an independent local newspaper, The Daily Monitor, the officers were recalled by President Yoweri Museveni over the alleged black market selling of food and fuel meant for the Ugandan troops. The paper said that some ordinary soldiers were eating only one ration pack a day because of the scam.

TITLE: Two Liberian journalists arrested on suspicion of criminal libel after accusing government of corruption on national radio have had the case against them dropped, they told AFP
SUBJECT: FREEDOM OF PRESS (93%); LIBEL & SLANDER (92%); ARRESTS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); JOURNALISM (90%); WRITERS (90%); LITIGATION (78%); AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENTS (72%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (69%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (69%); SUPREME COURTS (69%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (69%); MALARIA (67%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (56%)
TEXT: Two Liberian journalists arrested on suspicion of criminal libel after accusing the government of corruption on national radio have had the case against them dropped, they told AFP today. Octavin Williams and Rufus Paul were detained last week after criticising ministers on Hot FM's Henry Costa talk show for giving a $13 million road maintenance contract to a company they said was connected to the sister of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf. But they were told when they arrived to face charges in a Monrovia court today that the sister who contacted police over their appearance on the show had dropped her complaint. Their case was the second recent high-profile criminal action against journalists which critics have described as part of a worrying clampdown on press freedom in the west African nation. Rodney Sieh, editor of the Frontpage Africa newspaper, was taken into custody on August 21 following a Supreme Court ruling that the paper should pay $1.6 million (1.2 million euros) for libelling former agriculture minister J. Chris Toe. Sieh, who has been treated for malaria, was returned to prison from a three-week hospital stay last week, drawing criticism from international rights groups.

TITLE: Anti-corruption watchdog ranks U.S. and Germany as most active at enforcing rules prohibiting multinational companies from using bribes in foreign markets, but says half of the world's top exporters are doing little or nothing at all
COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); GERMANY (91%); JAPAN (79%); BRAZIL (79%); PAKISTAN (67%); NETHERLANDS (51%)
SUBJECT: EXPORT TRADE (91%); MULTINATIONAL CORPORATIONS (91%); BRIBERY (90%); CORRUPTION (90%)
TEXT: An anti-corruption watchdog ranks the U.S. and Germany as the most active at enforcing rules prohibiting multinational companies from using bribes in foreign markets, but says half of the world's top exporters are doing little or nothing at all. Transparency International's report released today showed only the U.S., Germany, Britain and Switzerland actively enforced the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention agreed upon by 40 major exporting countries between 2009 and 2012. The 1997 convention prohibits bribes to win contracts and licenses or to dodge taxes and local laws. Twenty countries that together account for about 27 percent of the world's exports, including G-20 members Japan, Brazil, South Korea and the Netherlands, showed little or no enforcement, the watchdog said. A further 10 had only limited enforcement.

TITLE: Malawian President Joyce Banda named a new cabinet today after dissolving the previous one last week amid fraud and corruption allegations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (88%); APPOINTMENTS (88%); SCANDALS (72%); ARRESTS (72%)
TEXT: President Banda's new cabinet has left out Finance Minister Ken Lipenga and Justice and Constitutional Affairs Minister Ralph Kasambara. The Malawian leader has also brought in some new faces in her new cabinet, among them non-politicians. Maxwell Mkwezalamba was named new finance minister and Fahad Assan new justice minister, who once served as the country's attorney. Since September, there have been multiple arrests of government officials at the Treasury, Accountant General and the Office of the President and Cabinet, who were allegedly involved in a fraud scandal of millions of dollars. Before sacking the cabinet on Thursday, President Banda had been facing the pressure to fire the finance minister to pave way for investigations.

TITLE: Uganda failing to clamp down on senior officials implicated in stealing public funds, yet has arrested and jailed anti-corruption activists
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); JAIL SENTENCING (90%); ARRESTS (90%); HUMAN RIGHTS (90%); SENTENCING (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); SCANDALS (88%); INVESTIGATIONS (88%); PRIME MINISTERS (71%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (71%)
TEXT: Uganda is failing to clamp down on senior officials implicated in stealing public funds, yet has arrested and jailed anti-corruption activists, a major rights report said today. The study, conducted by Human Rights Watch and Yale Law School, said no high-ranking government official, minister, or political appointee has ever served a prison sentence despite investigations into numerous corruption scandals over many years. The report said corruption scandals have had a direct impact on human rights in Uganda over many years. Donor funding worth $12.7 million (9.3 million euros) was stolen from the office of the Prime Minister in late 2012. The money was earmarked for rebuilding northern Uganda, a region ravaged by a 20-year war, and Karamoja, Uganda's poorest region. The 63-page report, 'Letting the Big Fish Swim: Failure to Prosecute High-Level Corruption in Uganda,' documented what it said were the potentially 'disastrous consequences' of the theft of resources intended to help realise fundamental rights to justice, health, water, food and education.

TITLE: Malawian President who has declared war against fraud and corruption in the country receiving death threats: Information minister
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (88%); ARRESTS (88%); BUDGETS (87%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (72%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (72%); PRESS CONFERENCES (72%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (72%)
TEXT: Malawian President Joyce Banda, who has declared war against fraud and corruption in the country, is receiving death threats, information minister Brown Mpinganjira disclosed to journalists today. The development comes after top and junior government officials continue to be arrested over failure to account for huge sums of cash found either in their houses or cars. At a joint press briefing Mpinganjira held with Fahad Assani, who is the minister of justice and constitutional affairs, in the capital of Lilongwe, Mpinganjira said the president together with her family were receiving death threats but the minister said he could not reveal much at the present stage. President Banda's crackdown on graft began with the arrest of an accounts assistant of the Finance Ministry early September, who was found with hard cash amounting to around 309 thousand U. S. dollars in his car and his house. The arrest was followed by the shooting of the country's budget director, Paul Mphwiyo, by unknown thugs when the senior government officer was approaching his residence gate on the evening of Sept. 13.

TITLE: Prominent lawyer and his friend who had corruption charges withdrawn against them to face same charges in High Court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); MAGISTRATES (90%); LAWYERS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (78%); ARRESTS (73%)
TEXT: Prominent lawyer Dirk Conradie and his friend Sarah Damases had corruption charges against them provisionally withdrawn in May this year, but will now face the same charges in the High Court here during November. The charges were withdrawn against the two accused on 31 May this year after the Office of Prosecutor-General Martha Ekandjo-Imalwa took too long to pronounce itself on the matter. Conradie and Damases thus made another appearance in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court along Lí_deritz Street here today on summons when Windhoek magistrate Hileni Riana Kavara ordered the transfer of their alleged corruption case from the magistrate's court to the High Court. They will make their first appearance in that court on 14 November this year for a pre-trial conference when both the defence team and prosecution representatives come together to decide on how to proceed with the case, and thereafter fix a trial date. Conradie and Damases were arrested in June 2012 by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) on charges of corruption. They were apprehended in connection with a N.dollars 60 million advertisement contract for Mobile Telecommunications Limited (MTC), on whose board Conradie served as the chairperson.

TITLE: Lawyer Conradie's alleged corruption case sent to High Court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); MAGISTRATES (91%); LAWYERS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); LITIGATION (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (77%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (77%); ARREST WARRANTS (73%); ARRESTS (73%)
TEXT: Prominent lawyer Dirk Conradie and friend Sarah Ngenohani Damases who were in May this year set free following withdrawal of charges of corruption against them, will face same charges in the High Court next month (November). The alleged corruption charges were provisionally withdrawn against the two accused persons on 31 May this year (2013) after the Office of Prosecutor-General Martha Ekandjo-Imalwa took too long to pronounce itself on the matter. Conradie and Damases made another appearance in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court along Luderitz Street here this Thursday morning on summons when Windhoek Magistrate Hileni Riana Kavara ordered the transfer of their alleged corruption case from the Magistrate's Court to the High Court. The duo is now scheduled to make their first appearance in the Windhoek High Court on 14 November this year during a pre-trial conference when both the defence team and prosecution representatives come together to decide on how to proceed with the case and, thereafter, fix trial date. 'It is, hereby, ordered that this case be transferred to the Windhoek High Court and be heard in the said court on 14 November this year (2013) at 09h00. It is further ordered that a complete record of the proceedings of this case be forwarded by the Clerk of of the Magistrate's Court to the Prosecutors' Clerk of the High Court as well as to the Registrar of the High Court. The two accused persons are both warned to appear in the Windhoek High Court on 14 November 2013 at 09h00. In case of failure to appear in the High Court on the above-mentioned date, a warrant for arrest may be issued against you, ' Magistrate Kavara informed the two accused persons today. On 31 May this year (2013), the same Magistrate (Kavara) withdrew the alleged corruption charges against the two accused persons following a prolonged failure by the PG's Office to pronounce itself on the matter. "This matter was first remanded for the Prosecutor-General's decision on 14 September 2012 to 18 January 2013. That was a remand for four months. On 18 January 2013, the PG's decision was still not available before court, and the State's representative requested for a lengthy remand for the PG's decision, and that remand was granted. The State was then granted five months for the PG's decision, which was a final remand for the PG's decision. In total, the State had been granted nine months and today (31 May 2013), that decision is still not available before this court. Indeed, the court has granted the State sufficient time, and this court will not allow another remand for the PG's decision as ample time was already awarded to the State. The failure by the State to avail the PG's decision is now deemed as a withdrawal of the case against the two accused persons", explained Magistrate Kavara before she made her withdrawal order at the time. In addition, the court on 31 May this year also ordered the cancellation of their bail, and that their bail money of N.dollars 30 000 each be refunded to the depositors. Public Prosecutor Erick Naikaku earlier appeared for the State, while Windhoek-based defence lawyers Elia Shikongo and Mbushandje Ntinda represented Conradie and Damases. Meanwhile, today (Thursday), the two accused persons were both represented by Windhoek-based defence lawyer Slysken Makando while Public Prosecutor Oscar Sinvula appeared for the State. The duo is now free on warnings, and were again warned to appear in the Windhoek High Court on 14 November this year. Conradie and his friend Damases were arrested in June 2012 by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) on charges of corruption. They were apprehended in connection with a N.dollars 60 million advertisement contract for Mobile Telecommunications Limited (MTC), on whose board Conradie serves as the chairperson. Damases is accused of allegedly "conspiring with Conradie to commit an offence". ACC deputy director Erna van der Merwe earlier said Conradie allegedly "corruptly solicited gratification as an inducement or reward for giving assistance or using his influence in the promotion or procurement of a contract with MTC for the provision of advertising services". Conradie is one of Namibia's most renowned lawyers, and has represented people in several high-profile court cases. He also serves in various influential national positions and boards, including the Lands Tribunal. TITLE: Corruption hits Ariamsvlei border post
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); IMMIGRATION (91%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (90%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); POLICE FORCES (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LITIGATION (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); TEXT MESSAGING (77%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (63%)
TEXT: An immigration officer stationed at Ariamsvlei border-post in the //Karas Region, was arrested by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) last week Monday for alleged corruption. The accused person Muliza Godfried, 39 and a Zimbabwean national Vincent Ncube, 33 were allegedly exchanging cellphone text messages that Monday, to aid a corruption practice, when someone alerted the police and the ACC. Confirming the arrest to Nampa on Tuesday, the Commander of the Namibian Police Force in //Karas Commissioner Armas Shivute, said Ncube allegedly offered to bribe Godfried with N.dollars 230 in an exchange for 36 extra days on his passport. Shivute said Ncube was entering Namibia from South Africa at the time of the suspected bribe. "We suspect that after the immigration officer agreed to take the money, Ncube placed the N.dollars 230 inside his passport and handed it to Godfried. Before the transaction is completed the passport was confiscated and both were arrested," Shivute explained. He noted that the police also learned with great concern that the corruption practice of receiving bribes from civilians seems to be on the increase at Ariamvlei border post. "We do not have enough proof as yet but we have noticed that this is not the first time such corrupt practices are taking place at that border. We are now closely watching the immigration officers at that border to make sure no corruption takes place," said the //Karas commander. Ncube is charged with corruption for allegedly offering a bribe to a public officer. Godfried is also charged with corruption for allegedly accepting a bribe in exchange for extra days on Ncube's passport. The two already appeared in the Karasburg District Court last week Thursday, where they were remanded in custody for further police investigations. They are expected to make their second appearance in the same court tomorrow. TITLE: Corruption deprive people of opportunities: Pohamba
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); LEGISLATION (89%); ORGANIZED CRIME (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (78%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (73%); VULNERABLE HEALTH POPULATIONS (73%); THIS DAY IN HISTORY (73%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (71%); CRIME PREVENTION (70%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (68%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (67%); MISAPPROPRIATION (64%); TERRORISM (50%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (50%)
TEXT: Anti-Corruption Commission Headquarters (ACC)which coincides with the commemoration of the International Anti-Corruption day was officially Inaugurated by President Hifikepunye Pohamba on Monday in the capital. Speaking at the event, President Pohamba stated that the 9th of December was designated as International Anti-Corruption Day, following the adoption of the United Nations General Assembly Resolution Number 58/4 of 31 October 2003. On this day, Namibia joins hands with other members of the international community to recommit ourselves to the ongoing and unrelenting fight against corruption, he noted. " We have articulated our government's stance on corruption clearly and forcefully over the years,. We view the menace of corruption, in whatever form it manifest itself, in the most serious light. We believe that it is a cancer that deprives our people of the opportunities and the resources needed for development. It hampers efforts to alleviate poverty, and undermines political stability and economic growth. It corrodes and diminishes opportunities for investment. Therefore,it should not be allowed to fester. We must all fight it and combat it tooth and nail, with all the dedication that we can muster, without fear of favour. The culprits must face justice and be punished for their deeds to serve as a deterrent for anyone contemplating to engage in corrupt practices." said Pohamba. Pohamba said that we must not allow the limited resources, which are meant to proved services to our people, especially the poor and vulnerable members of our society to be misappropriated by anyone. This year, the commemoration of International Anti-Corruption Day is being held under theme "Zero Corruption, 100% Development. This is in line with our own commitment to Zero tolerance for corruption, Pohamba noted that by working for a common objective as a nation, we will achieve the objectives set out in our National Development Plans, Vision 2030, and the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Pohamba also noted that in keeping with the UN Convention Against Corruption, Namibia has taken concrete steps to criminalize acts of corruption and organized crime, in this connection, we have enacted new laws such as the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003, the Prevention of Organized Crime Act 2004, the Financial Intelligence Act of 2012 and the Prevention and Combating of Terrorist Activities Act 2012. Pohamba said that the official opening of the Head-Quarters of the Anti-Corruption Commission is demonstration of our Government's commitment to the work of this important institution in the unrelenting efforts to combat corruption at all levels of society in our country. "I once again, call on all stakeholders, both in the public and private sectors to play an active role in preventing and combating corruption in Namibia. At the same time, i reiterate my appeal to the Namibian people to report all incidences of bribery, misappropriation of public funds and other related crimes of corruption to the law enforcement agencies, it is the patriotic duty of all our people to report all cases of corruption to the ACC or to other law enforcement agencies." said Pohamba. Pohamba also stated that as part of Government leaders, we will continue to strengthen the capacity of different institutions in our criminal justice system to carry out their duties and responsibilities effectively and efficiently from the investigation to the prosecution of all crimes, including corrupt practices. "Although notable progress has been made, we must continue to work as a team in order to uproot corruption whenever it manifests itself in our society. I commend our people who have supported the ACC in fighting corruption. I encouraged anyone who is aware of corrupt practices to report such cases to the ACC or other law enforcement agencies so that they can be investigated and the culprits brought to justice. Let us all do our part and help the ACC succeed in carrying out its mandate". Stated Pohamba. At the same time, I reiterate my appeal to the Namibian people to report all incidences of bribery, misappropriation of public funds and other related crimes of corruption to the law-enforcement agencies. It is the patriotic duty of all our people to report all cases of corruption to the ACC or to other law-enforcement agencies," he stressed. Pohamba also stated that Government leaders will continue to strengthen the capacity of different institutions in their criminal justice system to carry out their duties and responsibilities effectively and efficiently from the investigation to the prosecution of all crimes, including corrupt practices. "Although notable progress has been made, we must continue to work as a team in order to uproot corruption whenever it manifests itself in our society. I commend our people who have supported the ACC in fighting corruption. I encourage anyone who is aware of corrupt practices to report such cases to the ACC or other law-enforcement agencies, so that they can be investigated and the culprits brought to justice. Let us all do our part and help the ACC succeed in carrying out its mandate," requested Pohamba.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission HQs inaugurated
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (88%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (88%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (51%)
TEXT: The headquarters of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) was official inaugurated today. President Hifikepunye Pohamba officially unveiled the complex, and the event coincided with International Anti-Corruption Day. The 09th of December was designated as International Anti-Corruption Day, following the adoption of the United Nations' General Assembly Resolution Number 58/4 of 31 October 2003. Pohamba said on this day, Namibians join hands with other members of the international community to recommit themselves to the ongoing and unrelenting fight against corruption. He said they have articulated the government's stance on corruption clearly and forcefully over the years, and view the menace of corruption - in whatever form it manifest itself - in the most serious light. The president added that corruption hampers efforts to alleviate poverty and undermines political stability and economic growth. Pohamba noted that culprits must face justice and be punished for their deeds to serve as a deterrent for anyone contemplating to engage in corrupt practices.

TITLE: Businessmen arrested in connection with fraud, corruption, theft to go on trial in High Court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ARRESTS (91%); MAGISTRATES (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); CITY LIFE (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CITIES (78%); CITY GOVERNMENT (78%); EXECUTIVES (77%); LAWYERS (74%); REAL ESTATE DEVELOPMENT (73%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%)
TEXT: Four local businessmen arrested earlier this month in connection with alleged fraud, corruption and theft involving the B1 City development project in the capital, will go on trial in the High Court. They are former chief executive officer (CEO) of the Roads Contractor Company (RCC) Kelly Nghixulifwa, 56; David Imbili, 46; Hafeni Nghinamwaami, 48; and 51-year-old Anna Ndoroma. The group made another appearance in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court along Lí_deritz Street before Magistrate Ruth Modesta Herunga today, when their alleged fraud case was transferred to the Windhoek High Court, as per an order issued by the Office of Prosecutor-General Martha Ekandjo-Imalwa. They will make a first appearance in the Windhoek High Court on 10 April this year when both the defence lawyers and prosecution representatives come together during a pre-trial case of management to decide on how to proceed with the matter. They face a total of eight main charges, including corruption, fraud, theft and money-laundering. Four of the eight charges flow from the Roads Contractor Company's involvement in the B1 City property development project during 2005 and 2006.

TITLE: Pohamba defends fight against corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (87%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (79%)
TEXT: President Hifikepunye Pohamba has dismissed the notion often perpetuated by opposition politicians that his administration has failed to root out corruption, noting that he has done everything in his power to root out corruption. Pohamba made the remarks on Thursday when he responded to questions posed by opposition parties' leaders in parliament during his 9th state of the nation address in parliament on Thursday. Congress of Democrats (CoD) leader Ben Ulenga wanted to know how far the president has gone in his stance against corruption. Ulenga was referring to Pohamba's numerous public statements against corruption. The president said the establishment of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) is testimony to government's stance against corruption. As a president, Pohamba said, he was expected to provide structures that deal with the scourge of corruption and not to personally police government officials and the citizenry. "I have contributed to the fight against corruption. I have put up the Anti-Corruption Commission and they are now in charge of fighting corruption. It is not the president who must go and investigate. Do you want me to go from house to house? No, that is not my duty," he said. Pohamba however raised concern with the length of investigations, especially in the public sector, which he said was too long. "This thing of investigating something for years and nothing comes out is really not good. This needs to be addressed. People investigate for years and in the meantime, the person being investigated draws a salary while still on supervision and run his small business on the side," stressed Pohamba. Pohamba is currently serving his second and last term as president. By law, Namibian presidents are only allowed to serve a maximum of two terms.
