TITLE: Trial of Cameroonian businessman and a Namibian national facing charges of fraud and corruption will begin in March next year
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (88%); LITIGATION (88%); VALUE ADDED TAX (85%); JUDGES (73%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (67%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (67%)
TEXT: The trial of Cameroonian businessman Antoine Mbok and a Namibian national facing charges of fraud and corruption involving nearly N.dollars 4 million, will begin in March next year. This trial is set to begin in the High Court on 16 March 2015. Mbok (age not given) and Namibian national Daniel David Nghiwilepo, 40, made another appearance in the High Court before Judge Naomi Shivute this morning, when their alleged fraud and corruption case was remanded to next year for plea and trial. The two men will face a total of 10 charges of fraud and corruption when the trial begins. A summary of substantial facts contained in the charge-sheet have it that the two men allegedly defrauded several Namibian businesses and Government agencies of up to N.dollars 3,9 million in Valued-Added Tax (VAT) and returns for import VAT. Allegations are that between 25 January 2010 and 18 February 2010, five cheques were intercepted by personnel at the Ministry of Finance, and deposited into Mbok's company's account.

TITLE: ACC of Namibia's boss meet Okakarara Town Council's leadership because of corruption claims by community
SUBJECT: CITY GOVERNMENT (94%); CITIES (93%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); EXECUTIVES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CONSTRUCTION (90%); CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTING (86%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%)
TEXT: The Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) of Namibia's boss met the Okakarara Town Council's leadership yesterday, allegedly because of corruption claims by the community. ACC Director Paulus Noa told Nampa that he only came to meet his brother Nathanael Karuaihe, who is the chief executive officer (CEO) of this town. Mayor John Viakondo was also in that closed-door meeting. Several residents of Okakarara had written a letter to the ACC, complaining about the manner in which tenders for construction projects are being awarded by the town council. The same letter was also forwarded to the Minister of Regional and Local Government, Housing and Rural Development Charles Namoloh, further threatening that the community would use force and close the doors of the Okakarara Town Council building. This action of 'closing doors' was expected to take place yesterday, the same day that Noa came to town. However, none of the concerned community members showed up at the council building to put their threats into action.

TITLE: 60 disabled youth attend anti-corruption workshop
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); DISABLED PERSONS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (71%)
TEXT: About 60 youth living with disabilities in the Oshana Region attended an anti-corruption workshop here last Wednesday. It was organised by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC)'s Oshakati office. The ACC's Oshakati Public Education Officer, Ebba Kandjaba revealed this to Nampa on Monday, saying the workshop's main aim was to enhance anti-corruption awareness among the youth. It was also about creating a better understanding of the term corruption and dangers associated with corruption among the youth and the Namibian community at large. Additionally, the session was organised to sensitise the youth about ACC mandates, and likewise, it also educated the participants about evils of corruption as well as the importance of fighting corruption within our own areas and the entire Namibia. One of the best sources which define corruption to the participants were the abuse/misuse of Government offices, properties, resources, funds or money, power and positions by Government officials for their own benefit/self-enrichment, she explained. The participating youth with disabilities were also educated about the ACC mandates of receiving and then investigating allegations of corrupt practices reported to it.

TITLE: Prominent lawyers arrested on corruption charges to go on trial in High Court
SUBJECT: LAWYERS (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); ARRESTS (91%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (78%); JUDGES (78%)
TEXT: Prominent lawyer Dirk Conradie and Sarah Damases, who were arrested in June 2012 on corruption charges, will go on trial in the High Court during April next year. The two accused persons' trial will begin on 16 April 2015 and is set to run until 15 May 2015. Deputy Prosecutor-General Ed Marondedze revealed this when Conradie and Damases made another appearance before High Court Judge Elton Hoff during a pre-trial conference today. The prosecuting authority is also in the process of acquiring the services of a foreign judge to preside over this trial. The date was decided upon as per agreement reached between the accused persons' privately-instructed defence lawyer Slysken Makando and the prosecution's representative, Marondedze. The two accused persons are free on warning, and were again warned to appear before court on 16 April next year. The duo was arrested in June 2012 by investigators attached to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) in connection with a N.dollars 60 million advertisement contract for Mobile Telecommunications Limited (MTC), on whose board Conradie served as chairperson at the time.

TITLE: Three of the five people arrested in connection with theft and corruption released on bail
SUBJECT: BAIL (92%); ARRESTS (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); MAGISTRATES (78%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (77%); CONSPIRACY (73%)
TEXT: Three of the five people arrested in June this year in connection with a theft and corruption case involving N.dollars 4.9 million from the Ministry of Works and Transport, have been released on bail. Manuel Heyn, 52; Jacobus Totie Gurirab, 43; and the 49-year-old Berend Johannes Neels were all released from police custody after they managed to pay their N.dollars 30 000 bail each. The other two suspects still in police custody for failing to pay their bail money are officials from the Ministry of Health and Social Services, Jane Ndapandula Kashiyukile (age not mentioned), and Brown Rasta Abraham, 39. This is according to officials at the Windhoek Magistrate's Court, who spoke to Nampa on condition of anonymity on Friday. Reports carried by local English daily New Era today had it that four of the arrested five persons, excluding Kashiyukile, are all linked to a company which obtained a tender from the Ministry of Health and Social Services a few years back. According to the newspaper report, the five people allegedly conspired to have a total of N.dollars 4,9 million deposited into a bank account supposedly belonging to the company contracted by that Ministry.

TITLE: Three in N$5 million theft/corruption case released on bail
SUBJECT: BAIL (92%); CORRUPTION (90%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); LARCENY & THEFT (90%); MAGISTRATES (89%); BANKING & FINANCE (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); AUTOMATED TELLER MACHINES (89%); POLICE FORCES (76%); LAWYERS (74%)
TEXT: Three of the five people arrested in June this year over alleged theft and corruption case involving N.dollars 4,9 million from the Ministry of Works and Transport, have been released on bail. The trio- Manuel Heyn, 52, Jacobus Totie Gurirab, 43, and 49-yerar-old Berend Johannes Neels- were all released from police custody after they each managed to pay their N.dollars 30 000 bail. The other two suspects still in police custody for failing to pay their bail money are the official from the Ministry of Health and Social Services Jane Ndapandula Kashiyukile (age not mentioned) and Brown Rasta Abraham, 39. This was said by the officials at the Windhoek Magistrate's Court (who asked not to be named) along Luderitz Street upon inquiry by Nampa on Friday morning. Reports carried by the local State-owned English daily newspaper 'New Era' on Friday had that four of the arrested five persons, apart from Kashiyukile, are all linked to a company which obtained a tender from the Ministry of Health and Social Services over the past few years. According to the newspaper reports, the accused five people have allegedly connived in depositing a total of N.dollars 4,9 million in a bank account, supposedly belonging to the company contracted by the Ministry of Health and Social Services. It is alleged that accused Kashiyukile was allegedly informed the bank account of the company contracted by her ministry had changed from the one initially provided and that she must deposit money in a new bank account. Kashiyukile allegedly complied with the instruction she got and in order to see if the money had indeed been deposited, an initial amount of N.dollars 500 was allegedly withdrawn from an Automated Teller Machine (ATM). It is further alleged that after that the accused persons allegedly proceeded to withdraw an amount of N.dollars two (2) million from inside the bank, raising suspicion among bank officials. The bank then informed members of the Namibian Police Force (NamPol) and investigators attached to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), who then arrested the five accused persons last month (June). All five accused persons each face two counts of corruption under the Anti-Corruption Act, including corruptly using an office or position for gratification. Kashiyukile was arrested on 19 June this year while Heyn and Abraham were nabbed the following day. Accused Gurirab and Neels were arrested on 24 June 2014. Public Prosecutor Henry Muhongo represented the State when the five accused appeared in court. Windhoek-based defence lawyers Mbushandje Ntinda and Hipura Ujaha represented the accused persons. The five accused persons will return again to the Windhoek Magistrate's Court along Luderitz Street on 29 August this year. TITLE: Two senior Unam employees arrested in connection with corruption in tendering process
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ARRESTS (91%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LITIGATION (78%); MAGISTRATES (74%); BAIL (73%)
TEXT: Two senior Unam employees were arrested this week in connection with alleged corruption in the tendering process for the construction of hostel facilities at the Neudam Agricultural Campus. They are University of Namibia (Unam) Pro Vice-Chancellor for Administration and Finance, Dr Boniface Mutumba who is a member of Unam's Tender Board; as well as Ruben Prinz, the institution's Assistant Director of Estate Services. Mutumba was arrested on Monday, and Prinz yesterday by investigators attached to the Anti-Corruption Commission. Mutumba appeared in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court along Luderitz Street on Tuesday, and Prinz made an appearance in the same court yesterday. Their case was remanded until 03 October this year for the fixing of their trial date. They are both free on bail of N.dollars 5 000 each. It is alleged that Prinz made recommendations to the Unam Tender Board, on request of Mutumba, for a company, C & K Construction and Electrical CC (close corporation), to be awarded the tender, despite it being more expensive than other tenderers. The two men will stand trial in the Windhoek Regional Court in Katutura along Mungunda Street.

TEXT: Two senior employees (officials) of the University of Namibia (UNAM) were arrested this week in connection with the alleged corruption tender process for the construction of hostel facilities at the Neudam Agricultural Campus. The two men are: Pro Vice-Chancellor for Administration and Finance, who is a member of the UNAM's Tender Board Dr. Boniface Mutumba as well as Ruben Prinz, the Assistant Director of Estate Services. The two men were both arrested by investigators attached to the Anti-Corruption Commission. Mutumba was arrested on Monday (01 September 2014) this week and while Prinz was nabbed yesterday, Wednesday (03 September 2014). Mutumba appeared in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court along Luderitz Street on 02 September this year while Prinz made an appearance in the same court yesterday (Wednesday), and their was remanded until 03 October this year (20140 for the fixing of their trial date. The two men are each free on bail of N.dollars 5000. In the result, the UNAM Tender Board then based on the presentation made by Prinz awarded the tender to the Company C & K Construction and Electrical CC (close corporation). The process was, however, stopped after suspicions were raised in respect of the tender allocation to the aforesaid company. TITLE: B1City fraud/corruption trial begins next year
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); EXECUTIVES (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); CITY LIFE (89%); CITIES (89%); REAL ESTATE DEVELOPMENT (78%); INDICTMENTS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (78%); MONEY LAUNDERING (78%); CITY GOVERNMENT (78%); REAL ESTATE (78%); JUDGES (72%); CONSTRUCTION (70%); BOARD CHANGES (69%); ENGINEERING (68%); SHAREHOLDERS (66%); JOINT VENTURES (60%)
TEXT: Four local businessmen arrested in February 2014 in connection with alleged fraud, corruption and theft involving the B1 City development project in the capital, will go on trial next year (2015). The four accused persons' alleged fraud and corruption trial will kick-off in the Windhoek High Court here on 01 October next year (20150), and will run until 16 October 2015. The suspects are former chief executive officer (CEO) of the Roads Contractor Company (RCC) Kelly Nghixulifwa, 56; David Imbili, 46; Hafeni Nghinamwaami, 48; and 51-year-old Anna Ndoroma. The date for the start of the trial was made known when the group made another appearance before High Court Judge-President Petrus Damaseb during a pre-trial of case management here on Thursday morning. Meanwhile, the four accused persons will return to the Windhoek High Court on 23 October 2014 for the date of the trial to be finally confirmed or changed. The four were arrested between 14 and 16 February 2014 by investigators attached to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC). They face a total of eight main charges, including corruption, fraud, theft and money-laundering. Four of the eight charges flow from the Roads Contractor Company's involvement in the B1 City property development project during 2005 and 2006. Other charges relate to Nghixulifwa's tenure as chief executive officer of the RCC, which came to an end with his resignation at the end of 2006 after he had been suspended from his position. The Prosecutor-General's office had decided to indict Ndoroma, Nghixulifwa, Imbili, Nghinamwaami, the Ae Gams Engineering company, represented by Imbili, and Cradle Investments, represented by Nghinamwaami, in the High Court on the main charges of corruptly using an office or position for gratification, fraud, failing to disclose an interest in a contract and money-laundering. It is alleged that Nghixulifwa was a shareholder in both Ae Gams Engineering and Cradle Investments, but allegedly concealed his stake in the two companies by having his shares held in Ndoroma's name. It is further alleged that Nghixulifwa failed to disclose his interests in the two companies to the board of directors of the RCC. With the RCC Board allegedly kept in the dark about Nghixulifwa's stake in Ae Gams Engineering, in which Nghinamwaami and Imbili were also shareholders, Nghixulifwa and Imbili in February 2005 signed an agreement in terms of which the RCC and Ae Gams Engineering were to undertake the B1 City shopping complex and taxi rank development as a joint venture. Nghixulifwa thus allegedly corruptly used his position at the RCC to buy the plot of land where the B1 City development was to take place on behalf of Ae Gams Engineering with RCC funds and a credit facility in the amount of N.dollars 4,87 million. Nghixulifwa allegedly also defrauded the RCC by bringing managers at the parastatal and the chairperson of the RCC board under the impression that a mortgage bond of N.dollars 4,87 million had been registered over the B1 City property in the RCC's favour, when in fact that had not been done. It is also alleged in the indictment that while still employed as RCC chief executive officer, Nghixulifwa defrauded the RCC and a construction company, Murray and Roberts, in December 2004 by concealing his shareholding in Cradle Investments, and inducing the RCC and Murray and Roberts to pay a 'facilitation fee' of N.dollars 150 000 to Cradle Investments and Nghinamwaami for the role they had supposedly played in the construction of a new head office for the parastatal. It is alleged that in fact Nghinamwaami and Cradle Investments had not been appointed as project facilitators, and were not entitled to receive such a fee. It is also alleged that Nghixulifwa used his position with the parastatal in April 2006 to have a debt of N.dollars 29 954 of Cradle Investments with a firm of auditors settled with RCC funds. In another charge, it is alleged that Nghixulifwa corruptly used his position as RCC CEO in March 2006 to have a payment of N.dollars 92 729 made with RCC funds on the home loan account of an RCC employee, Brian Nalisa, which was allegedly in arrears. Windhoek-based defence lawyers Mbushandje Nhinda, Sisa Namandje and Frank Kopplinger are representing the accused persons. They are all free on bail of N.dollars 60 000 each, and their bail was also today (Thursday) extended until their next court appearance on 01 October 2015. The date was made known when the group made another appearance before High Court Judge-President Petrus Damaseb during a pre-trial case management meeting here on Thursday morning. The accused persons will return to the Windhoek High Court on 23 October for the date of the trial to be finally confirmed, or changed. The four were arrested between 14 and 16 February 2014 by investigators attached to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC). They face a total of eight main charges, including corruption, fraud, theft and money-laundering. Four of the eight charges flow from the Roads Contractor Company's involvement in the B1 City property development project during 2005 and 2006. Other charges relate to Nghixulifwa's tenure as the RCC's CEO, which came to an end with his resignation at the end of 2006 after he had been suspended from that position. The Prosecutor-General's office had decided to indict Ndoroma; Nghixulifwa; Imbili; Nghinamwaami; the Ae Gams Engineering company, represented by Imbili; and Cradle Investments, represented by Nghinamwaami, in the High Court on the main charges of corruptly using an office or position for gratification, fraud, failing to disclose an interest in a contract and money-laundering. It is alleged that Nghixulifwa was a shareholder in both Ae Gams Engineering and Cradle Investments, but allegedly concealed his stake in the two companies by having his shares held in Ndoroma's name. It is further alleged that Nghixulifwa failed to disclose his interests in the two companies to the board of directors of the RCC. With the RCC Board allegedly kept in the dark about Nghixulifwa's stake in Ae Gams Engineering, in which Nghinamwaami and Imbili were also shareholders, Nghixulifwa and Imbili in February 2005 signed an agreement in terms of which the RCC and Ae Gams Engineering were to undertake the B1 City shopping complex and taxi rank development as a joint venture. Nghixulifwa thus allegedly corruptly used his position at the RCC to buy the plot of land where the B1 City development was to take place on behalf of Ae Gams Engineering with RCC funds and a credit facility in the amount of N.dollars 4,87 million. Nghixulifwa allegedly also defrauded the RCC by bringing managers at the parastatal and the chairperson of the RCC board under the impression that a mortgage bond of N.dollars 4,87 million had been registered over the B1 City property in the RCC's favour, when in fact that had not been done. It is also alleged in the indictment that while still employed as RCC CEO, Nghixulifwa defrauded the RCC and a construction company, Murray and Roberts, in December 2004 by concealing his shareholding in Cradle Investments, and inducing the RCC and Murray and Roberts to pay a 'facilitation fee' of N.dollars 150 000 to Cradle Investments and Nghinamwaami for the role they had supposedly played in the construction of a new head office for the parastatal. It is alleged that in fact, Nghinamwaami and Cradle Investments had not been appointed as project facilitators, and were not entitled to receive such a fee. It is also alleged that Nghixulifwa used his position with the parastatal in April 2006 to have a debt of N.dollars 29 954 of Cradle Investments with a firm of auditors settled with RCC funds. In another charge, it is alleged that Nghixulifwa corruptly used his position as RCC CEO in March 2006 to have a payment of N.dollars 92 729 made with RCC funds on the home loan account of an RCC employee, Brian Nalisa, which was allegedly in arrears. Windhoek-based defence lawyers Mbushandje Nhinda, Sisa Namandje and Frank Kopplinger are representing the accused persons. The accused are all free on bail of N.dollars 60 000 each, and their bail was also extended until their next court appearance.

TITLE: Corruption charges withdrawn against MAWF employee
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); MAGISTRATES (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENTS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LAWYERS (73%); ENGINEERING (50%)
TEXT: An employee of the Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry arrested here in March this year (2014) over allegations of fraud and corruption involving more than N.dollars 100 000, has been set free. The 29yearold Joyce Daphne Erna Zussino was set free on Thursday morning following the withdrawal of the alleged corruption and fraud charges by the prosecution when she made another appearance in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court along Luderitz Street. The alleged corruption and fraud charges against Zussino were withdrawn shortly after Public Prosecutor Henry Muhongo informed presiding Magistrate John Liwoyo Sindano that he (Muhongo) has received instructions from the Office of the ProsecutorGeneral Martha EkandjoImalwa not to proceed with the matter, and instead to apply for a withdrawal of the case. 'This matter was postponed from Wednesday (yesterday) to Thursday (today) for the purposes of plea and trial. In the meantime, and after considering the evidence of the case, I have received instructions from the Office of the ProsecutorGeneral Martha EkandjoImalwa to apply for the withdrawal of the case and this information was also communicated to Zussino's defence lawyer Sisa Namandje, ' said Muhongo in his submissions as he requested Magistrate Sindano for the withdrawal of the case. In the result, Magistrate Sindano thus withdrew the alleged corruption and fraud charges against Zussino as per request by the State. In addition, an order was also made by the court that Zussino's bail money of N.dollars 20 000 be refunded to the depositor. In the matter, Zussino was facing a total of nine charges of fraud and corruption for allegedly having contravened Section 36 of the AntiCorruption Act Eight of 2003. ACC Chief Investigator Nelius Becker said in an earlier media statement availed to Nampa in March this year (2014) that Zussino is employed as a private secretary to the Director of Extension and Engineering Services in the ministry's head office in the capital. It alleged that Zussino owned a company called TuahafaZussino Creations, which allegedly delivered some services to the agriculture ministry where she works. It is alleged that she allegedly had a role in obtaining quotations for the said ministry, and her company also submitted quotations while she was privy to the information and pricing of other suppliers. Furthermore, it was alleged that she did not have the required permission to perform outside remunerative work. In terms of Section 36 of the AntiCorruption Act Eight of 2003, a public officer commits an offence knowingly and corruptly, and otherwise as a member of a registered joint stock company consisting of more than 20 persons, when it acquires or holds, directly or indirectly, a private interest in any contract, agreement or investment emanating from or connected with the public body on or in which he or she serves as a member or as an employee or which is made on account of the public body. A total of about N.dollars 121 749.50 is said to be involved in the alleged fraud and corruption case, said Becker at the time. Zussino has been free on bail of N.dollars 20 000. TITLE: Nafau Branch Organizer arrested by Anti Corruption Commission
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ARRESTS (91%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); LABOR UNIONS (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); MAGISTRATES (77%); POLICE FORCES (77%); BAIL (73%)
TEXT: The Namibia Food and Allied Workers Union (Nafau), Branch Organiser at Swakopmund, Moses Veiko, 31, was arrested by the Anti Corruption Commission (ACC) last week Thursday. Detective Chief Inspector Erastus Iikuyu of the Namibian Police Force (NamPol) at Walvis Bay, confirmed the arrest to Nampa today. Veiko allegedly corruptly used his office and position to cash in on a salary increment negotiation between Nafau and the employees of Schweizerhaus Cafe Anton in Swakopmund. The employees, represented by Veiko on behalf of Nafau, apparently asked for 8.5 per cent increment on their salary, but management was only willing to give eight per cent increment. The accused allegedly approached the representative of Schweizerhaus Cafe Anton, asking her to convince management to pay him about N.dollars 5 000 on a promise that he will in return convince the workers to accept the eight percent increment proposal. After agreeing to receive the money at a certain place in the Mondesa residential area of Swakopmund, a whistle blower informed the ACC about the pending deal. The ACC officers then set up a trap and Veiko was arrested while receiving the bribe. He appeared in the Swakopmund Magistrate's Court the same day where he was granted bail of N.dollars 5,000.

TITLE: Nudo wants Anti-Corruption court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); SENTENCING (78%)
TEXT: The National Unity Democratic Organisation (Nudo) has said it will establish an anticorruption court to specifically deal with cases of graft, if it comes to power. According to Nudo Secretary General, Meundju Jahanika, cases of corruption do not receive priority in the country's courts and are often prolonged before judgement is made on them. He said his party will give due consideration to such cases, to avoid the misuse of government resources. Jahanika made the remarks during a Nudo star rally at Otjinene at the weekend. The Nudo SG said his party will advocate for stiffer sentences against corrupt government officials who betray public trust by involving themselves in hedious and shady dealings involving government resources. Jahanika used the opportunity to blast government for allegedly only granting recognition to traditional leaders affiliated to the ruling Swapo party, at the expense of those known to be aligned to the opposition. 'This thing of giving official recognition status to some traditional leaders especially those that are affiliated to Swapo  must end henceforth. It is a very bad practice as some traditional leaders do not even qualify to be called as such. Imagine a traditional leader having only 30 followers, yet he is recognized as chief. This has to end,' he said. Nudo, which has enjoyed massive support from the Otjinene constituency in past elections, said government was not serious in addressing the plight of thousands of Ovaherero and Ovambanderu communities who were affected by the 19041908 Genocide. The party claimed that the genocide and reparation motion introduced in parliament by erstwhile Nudo President, Kuaima Riruako last year, was only accepted 'to silence the Ovaherero people' According to Jahanika, Germany has managed to silence the Namibian government on the issue of reparation through the NamibiaGerman Special Initiative Programme. 'The Namibian government balances its books with the help of the money from the Germans. So, for that reason, they have chosen to be silence on the issue of reparation,' he said. TITLE: WRP vows to expose corruption
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); MINIMUM WAGE (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); LIVING WAGE (78%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (77%); COMPANY EARNINGS (76%); HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (75%); PENSION FUNDS (73%); SPORTS & RECREATION FACILITIES & VENUES (73%); FAMILY (73%); INFLATION (68%); ECONOMIC NEWS (68%); HOMELESSNESS (65%); GOVERNMENT GRANTS & SUBSIDIES (53%); TAXES & TAXATION (50%)
TEXT: The Workers Revolutionary Party (WRP) vowed to expose corruption and irregularities, as well as advancing the demands of the landless and the working class. The Workers Revolutionary Party will, for the first time, have members in parliament as from 21 March 2015. The party drew 13 328 votes and has been allocated two seats in the National Assembly, according to provisional elections results issued by the Electoral Commission of Namibia (ECN) on Monday. President of the Workers Revolutionary Party Hewat Beukes told Nampa on Tuesday that his party has since 1986 fight for the rights of Namibians and will continue to do so. "Voters knew that we are the most active party since many years ago. We will use our seats in parliament to expose corruption and irregularities. We are going to act against corrupt courts. WRP will also expose unpunished corporate theft and fraud, especially in the sectors of housing and pension," he stated. The victory of the party during the justended elections is because of hard work, according to Beukes. WRP's triumph is "not just a flesh in a pan." WRP has worked endlessly with the formers workers of Tsumeb Corporation Limited (TCL) that lost a pension fund worth more than N.dollars 100 million. The party has also over the years worked with the homeless and the landless in the south, as well as in the northern parts of the country and the Zambezi Region, according to Beukes. Amongst others, WRP's in its election manifesto promised to advance the demands of the South West African Territorial Force (SWATF)or Koevoet families and relatives, in relation to stolen pensions, loss of income and losses in general through economic sanctions, marginalization, victimization and discrimination, landlessness and homelessness. It also said it will articulate and support the demands of the Herero and Nama people for reparations for the genocide (19041908) from the government of Germany. "We will further advance the demand for basic needs of the working class families to be provided and subsidized by the government on the first tier level (Municipalities), housing, water and electricity, public transport, clinics, kindergartens, as well as sport and recreation facilities to be brought to the people. We will advance taxation for excesses and demand living wages tied to the rate of inflation (and not minimum wages)," it added. TITLE: It's difficult to remove corruption: Forensic expert
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); FORENSICS (90%); MULTINATIONAL CORPORATIONS (89%); PUBLIC POLICY (89%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (78%)
TEXT: The AntiCorruption Commission of Namibia (ACC) together with the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) and the Hanns Seidel Foundation (HSF) commemorated the international anticorruption day here on Tuesday. The day was celebrated under the theme "Break the Corruption Chain". The 9 December is marked as an International AntiCorruption Day by General Assembly, and the day aims at raising awareness of corruption, combating and preventing it. The Director of Forensics Services at Edward Nathan Incorporation in South Africa Steven Powell who gave a key note address said, it is difficult to remove corruption in all countries. He said corruption is an almost insurmountable obstacle in African countries which is preventing people to live in a free choice destination. He added that if people come together to tackle corruption effectively African countries will be destination of choice. "Africa is the investment destination of choice for international companies expanding their business footprint," he said. Bribes and facilitation payments are the most factors that lead to corruption says Powell. Corruption is seen as a process that undermines democratic institutions, slows economic development and contributes to governmental instability. The Forensics Services Director urged all the stakeholders to cooperate with each other to address the cancerous of corruption that is threatening the future of their beautiful countries. He also emphasised that every jurisdiction must ensure strong lawscontrols are effectively enforcement. "We must learn from each other civil society, the media and individuals all have a role to play," said Powell. He also urged people to learn how to say no to corruption otherwise they will not win this battle if there is no togetherness. Civil society, the media and individuals all have a role to play," said Powell. TEXT: The continuation of the corruption trial of former Namibia Wildlife Resorts (NWR) Managing Director Tobie Aupindi and his Italian co-accused Antonio Di Savino saw another delay today. The two defence lawyers brought an urgent application for the discharge of their clients shortly after Public Prosecutor Arrie Husselmann, who appeared for the prosecution during the hearing of the discharge application, closed the State's case. TITLE: Ex-NWR boss corruption trial sees another delay
SUBJECT: MAGISTRATES (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (90%); LAWYERS (89%); EVIDENCE (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (78%); TRIAL & PROCEDURE (78%); TESTIMONY (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (77%); CRIMINAL LAW (77%)
TEXT: The continuation of the corruption trial of former Namibia Wildlife Resorts (NWR) Managing Director, Tobie Aupindi and his Italian co-accused Antonio Di Savino, sees another postponement. The two accused businessmen made another appearance in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court before Magistrate Jarmaine Muchali along Luderitz Street on Wednesday morning, and they were informed that their trial will resume on 02 July this year (2015). The trial, which is based on charges of alleged corruption, was on Wednesday postponed to 02 July this year because the parties (prosecution and accused) involved in the matter are still awaiting for the High Court to hand down a judgment for the recusal of the magistrate from presiding over the case. A ruling on the two accused persons' apllication for the recusal of Windhoek Magistrate Helvi Kauna Shilemba from the trial is still pending with the High Court. The matter was postponed today to 02 July this year, as per the agreement reached by Public Prosecutor Erastus Hatutale and the accused persons' defence lawyers, Advocate Richard Metcalfe and Louis Du Pisani. On 24 February this year, the two accused men suffered a heavy blow when the Windhoek Magistrate's Court dismissed their application for discharge. "After carefully going through the evidence presented by both defence lawyers, Richard Metcalfe and Louis Du Pisani, and the prosecution team led by Public Prosecutor Arrie Husselmann, I have come to the conclusion that the two accused persons have a case to answer before court," said Magistrate Shilemba at the time. As a result of this, the two accused are now to be put on their defence when the trial continues on 26 February next year. The two defence lawyers also brought an urgent application for the discharge of their clients in February this year, shortly after Public Prosecutor Arrie Husselmann, who appeared for the prosecution during the hearing of the discharge application, closed the State's case. This unsuccessful discharge application was brought before court in terms of Section 174 of the Criminal Procedures' Act, the two defence lawyers stated at the time. They wanted the court to discharge their clients on the grounds that thus far, there had been no prima-facie evidence presented before court to indicate that the two men were involved in the alleged corruption, as the State claims. Husselmann, however, asked the court to dismiss the discharge application, arguing that the two accused persons should be put on their defences and should testify before court. On 06 February this year, the 36-year-old Aupindi and his co-accused Di Savino, whose age was not given, entered not guilty pleas at the start of their corruption trial. In the matter, it is alleged that Di Savino paid for a N.dollars 50 000 swimming pool which was installed at Aupindi's home in return for tenders for the refurbishment of the parastatal's resorts. The two men each pleaded not guilty to a number of charges under the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003, namely a main count of allegedly corruptly providing false information to an authorised officer, and a count of attempting to defeat or obstruct the course of justice. They also pleaded not guilty to the alternative count on the main charge. The duo entered their pleas as per Section 119 of Namibia's Criminal Procedures Act, and as per the instructions from their respective defence lawyers. Evidence contained in a summary of substantial facts in the charge-sheet has it that the former NWR boss had provided false information to an investigating officer of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), William Lloyd, by stating that he had paid N.dollars 50 000 in cash to a local company LIC Pools for a swimming pool installed at his house in 25 Kestrel Street, Hochland Park. The allegation against Aupindi is that he did not pay for the swimming pool himself, and that Di Savino in fact paid for the pool as a kickback in exchange for tile tenders awarded to his co-accused for work done at NWR resorts. Di Savino, like Aupindi, faces charges of providing false information to an ACC investigator, and attempting to defeat or obstruct the course of justice. The former NWR chief left the parastatal at the end of December 2010, four months before his contract was due to expire. Media reports at the time claimed that he received a 'golden handshake' of about N.dollars 4,5 million. Aupindi and Di Savino are free on bail, and their bail was also extended until 26 February 2013 for the continuation of the trial. SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (90%); SUBPOENAS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (89%); WITNESSES (78%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (78%); CONTRACT AWARDS (76%); LAWYERS (75%); GOVERNORS (75%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%); LEGAL AID (73%); MEATS (54%); STEPPARENTS (54%)
TEXT: The corruption hearing of Karas Regional Council chairperson Jan Scholtz and council employee Bernatus Waterboer was postponed for a fourth time in the Keetmanshoop Regional Court on Wednesday. The case, emanating from corruption charges allegedly committed late in 2011, will next be heard for plea and trial on 9 and 10 July. The two Government officials stand accused of allegedly corruptly awarding tenders worth N.dollars 540 000 to a company owned by a close friend in 2011. The company, Gerose Construction CC received paving tenders for the offices of the Karas Regional Governor in Keetmanshoop and the !Ami#us Constituency Office at Luderitz. Scholtz is councilor of this constituency. Scholtz is also accused of corruptly tabling and motivating a financial assistance request worth almost N.dollars 10 000 for Tommys Meat Products owned by his stepson, Clayton Bruce. He allegedly failed to disclose the nature of his relationship with the butchery owner during a council meeting. The charges were investigated by the Anti-Corruption Commission and subsequently brought to court after recommendation by the Prosecutor-General, Martha Imalwa. On Wednesday, private defense lawyer for the accused, Garth Joseph, rejected a request by the State for a further postponement and asked for a dismissal of the case. He argued that the postponement unduly prejudiced the political position of Scholtz who hoped to be re-elected as council chair later this year, and was financially draining on Waterboer whom he said had limited legal insurance. The States request was on the grounds that both the ACC case investigator and witnesses failed to show in court during the latest appearance. It emerged that the failure occurred as a result of subpoenas never having reached the intended parties. Chief prosecutor Pieter Smit informed the court that from his investigations it was unclear where in the administrative chain the documents may have been lost. Regional magistrate Sunsley Zisengwe rapped the State over its knuckles for "sluggishness" on the handling of the subpoenas, but wholly rejected the defenses request for dismissal. Zisengwe said he was taken aback by the "audacious" request for a discharge considering the defense had previously asked for postponement on two scheduled appearances. He ruled that Scholtz position was not in threat as he was presumed innocent until the conclusion of the court case. Zisengwe advised Waterboer on the option of State-funded legal aid. TITLE: Probe into Kooitjie corruption allegations complicated: ACC
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); EMBEZZLEMENT (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (89%); PRESS CONFERENCES (88%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (76%); EXECUTIVES (73%); JOURNALISM (73%); WRITERS (68%)
TEXT: The Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) says investigations on the corruption allegations against Topnaar chief Seth Kooitjie is complicated. The community he is leading of embezzling community funds amongst other accusations is accusing the chief. As such the ACC launched investigations against him two years ago. The Topnaar community is the branch of the Nama people, settled along the Kuiseb River some 40 kilometers south Walvis Bay. Senior investigations officer for the ACC in Erongo Region Walter Kurz on Thursday said investigations are tough on this case as allegations dates as far as 15 years ago. "We started investigations and then we realize it is a very complicated case. We have to collect all documents on things that took place 15 years ago. We can only proceed when we have all the relevant proof, " he said when asked by reporters how far investigations are. Kurz was speaking at the media conference on what constitute corruption held in Swakopmund. Asked when will the investigations be completed, he noted that investigations are continuing but it is not clear how long it will take. "It might take even five years to investigate this case," said the ACC investigator. He noted that there is no arrest yet in this case. Also speaking at the same event was the ACC chief education officer Tobias Amoonga who said there is good progress on fighting corruption in Erongo. He noted that since January 2014 a total of 75 cases were registered and 20 of them were prosecuted. Amoonga said the conference is aimed at building a strong relationship between the public watchdog and the media in fighting corruption. "We need partners especially the media and the public to work together with us in order to fight corruption. The media should not only expose corruption but journalists must also refrain from corrupt practices," said Amoonga. The conference on Thursday, was the first step for the ACC office in Swakopmund, to educate the public on what constitute corruption in a bid to sensitize people to report and stay away from corruption practices. More public education workshops will be held across the region throughout the year. (edited)SWAKOPMUND: The Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) says investigations into corruption allegations against Topnaar chief Seth Kooitjie are complicated. The Topnaar community is accusing their chief of embezzling community funds, and as such the ACC launched investigations against him two years ago. This community branches from the Nama people, and reside along the Kuiseb River some 40 kilometres south of Walvis Bay. ACC Senior investigations officer in the Erongo Region, Walter Kurz on Thursday said the investigations are complicated by the fact that the allegations date back as far as 15 years ago. Kurz was speaking at a media conference in Swakopmund held by the ACC. "We started investigations and realized it is a very complicated case. We have to collect documents on things that took place 15 years ago, and we can only proceed when we have all the relevant proof," he said when asked by reporters how far the investigations have progressed. Kurz said it might take five years to investigate. Speaking at the same event, ACC chief education officer Tobias Amoonga said good progress has been made on fighting corruption in Erongo. He noted that since January 2014, a total of 75 cases were registered and 20 of the accused were prosecuted. Amoonga said the media conference was aimed at building a stronger relationship between the public watchdog and the media in fighting corruption. "We need partners, especially the media and the public, to work with us in order to fight corruption. The media should not only expose corruption, but journalists must also refrain from corrupt practices," he said. The conference on Thursday was the first step for the ACC office in Swakopmund in educating the public on what constitutes corruption in a bid to sensitize people to report and stay away from corrupt practices. More public education workshops will be held across the region throughout the year.

TITLE: Lawyer Conradie's alleged corruption trial starts Thursday
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); LAWYERS (89%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (89%); JUDGES (89%); AGREEMENTS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (87%); CONSPIRACY (78%); MARKETING & ADVERTISING SERVICES (71%)
TEXT: Prominent local lawyer Dirk Conradie and Sarah Damases, who were arrested in June 2012 on corruption charges, will go on trial in the High Court here tomorrow (Thursday). The two accused persons' trial will begin on Thursday, 16 April 2015, and is set to run until 15 May 2015. This was made public by Deputy Prosecutor-General Ed Marondedze when Conradie and Damases made another appearance before High Court Judge Elton Hoff during a pre-trial conference of case management here on 03 Jully last year (2014). The prosecuting authority was also said to have acquired the services of a foreign judge to preside over this trial, the court heard last year. The date for the start of the trial was decided upon as per agreement reached between the accused persons' privately-instructed defense lawyer Slysken Makando and the prosecution's representative, Marondedze in July last year. The two accused persons are each free on a warning. The duo was arrested in June 2012 by investigators attached to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) on charges of corruption. This was in connection with a N.dollars 60 million advertisement contract for Mobile Telecommunications Limited (MTC), on whose board Conradie served as chairperson at the time. Damases is accused of allegedly conspiring with Conradie to commit an offence. ACC deputy director Erna van der Merwe earlier said Conradie allegedly corruptly solicited gratification as an inducement or reward for giving assistance or using his influence in the promotion or procurement of a contract with MTC for the provision of advertising services. Conradie has represented several people in high-profile court cases in Namibia. He also serves on various influential national positions and boards, including the Lands Tribunal.
