State of the nation Since the formation of the SNG, the Convener, Pastor Tunde Bakare and his members had made it abundantly clear that the group is out to cleanse the society and purge it of all anti-people policies and anti-democracy tendencies. They have vowed that nothing can stop them from rising against any form of oppression and injustices in the polity. It is against this backdrop that the group has taken it upon itself to organize series of seminars, symposium, workshops and annual lecture series to enlighten, educate, sensitise and mobilize the populace to know their rights and demand for them. Annual lecture series So, early this year, the first lecture, delivered by the universally renowned scholar, Professor Niyi Osundare was organized. And not satisfied with the state of the nation, the group came up with the second in the lecture series. An Associate Professor from Department of English and Literature, Cerleton University, Canada, Pius Adesanmi delivered the lecture titled: Reparations: What Nigeria owes the tortoise. In the lecture, the don identified greed, selfishness as well as excessive corruption on the part of the country's leadership as the cause of her backwardness, asserting that "until the nation is purged of all these societal ills, the country will continue to move from bad to worse." While likening Nigeria's rulers to the proverbial tortoise in the ancient fables, the lecturer narrated a couple of fables where the tortoise was reported to have ruined itself through "excessive consumption to the detriment of the collective goal of the people." According to him, since the resources of the country were for the welfare of the generality of the citizenry, "the covenant of greed, ala, the tortoise must be broken to give way to respect for collective goal and common will of the people," insisting that "common will of the people is sacred." Adesanmi, who wondered that the same oil discover in Dubai that has become a blessing to that country was the same oil that has been spelling doom for Nigeria was of the conviction that everything possible must be done to evolve a natural self fashioning for nationhood where common goal would be the pre-occupation of all and sundry. Waxing philosophical, the don warned that "the country would not move an inch if her leadership keeps on plagiarizing the greedy way of the tortoise and work towards a collective will of the people." He expressed sadness that "the leadership of the country is, sadly, not even plagiarizing the tortoise but stealing, robbing and looting the tortoise intellectual property and thus owe the tortoise reparations." He then challenged "those of us who bear the brunt of the repercussions of our leaders' greed, corruption and selfishness to rise up against the ills," submitting that "it is then that we will gradually find our way back to our common goal and collective will that will move the country forward." Call for protests The lecturer's postulation gingered the former Minister of the Federal Capital territory (FCT), Nasir el-Rufai, to admit that the country was at a crossroads, warning that the situation would degenerate if the people did not rise up to tackle the misdeeds bedeviling the nation. El-Rufai noted that creating what he called "Nigerian elite enclave mentality" would not shield anyone from the impending crises if the people refused to act now. According to him, people below the age of 20 currently constitute the majority of the country's population, but they are faced with hardship and excruciating poverty. He bemoaned the decadence in the social structure, which he said had led to an unending cycle of violence and bloodletting, stressing that all these problems manifesting in form of violence and terrorist attacks, were products of corruption, lack of inadequate education, as well as the high unemployment rate in the country. So to him, people must rise up to stop corruption in the country. Toeing el-Rufai's line was the Lagos State governorship candidate of the Democratic Peoples Alliance (DPA), in the 2007 general election, Mr. Jimi Agbaje, who noted that the fight against corruption in the country could only succeed with the collective responsibility of both the leaders and the led. He called on Nigerians to resist corrupt leaders or they would be constantly pauperized by them. On her part, the President of Campaign for Democracy (CD), and leader of Women Arise, Dr. Joe Okei-Odumakin, said the idea of always wanting to share the "national cake" had remained an obstacle to the nation's development. She therefore urged the government to prosecute all the parties found culpable in the controversial oil subsidy scam. "Gathering here is to prove a point that Nigeria belongs to all of us and we cannot fold hands and watch corruption tear us apart," she said. The Chairman of the Ikeja chapter of the Nigerian Bar Association, Monday Ubani, said the country had failed but still working for those responsible for it. He called for a synergy between the public and the press to chart a new course for the nation in the fight against corruption. A former member of the House of Representatives, Dino Melaye, asserted that the country's problem is mainly corruption, regretting that 60 per cent of the nation's budgetary allocation goes to mismanagement and corruption. He said the country was at the "emergency ward" and would go to the "intensive care unit" if the people did not act. In his closing remarks, the SNG Convener, Pastor Tunde Bakare lamented that the country is on the brink of collapse insisting that "it requires the urgent intervention of all citizens, especially through protests, to rescue it." Bakare therefore urged Nigerians to immediately take to the streets and bring an end to corruption and bad governance, which he said were seriously threatening the survival of the nation. Even religious leaders across Christianity and Islam were not spared as he alleged that some use their positions to enrich themselves, and maintain ostentatious lifestyles, including buying private jet just as he called on the people to begin to cleanse the corrupt system by moving against such clerics. His words: "All G.O. (General Overseers) must go to prison...and all of us must be rounded up and put in jail. This is not the first time I am saying it. If the revolution does not begin in the church or mosque, Nigeria will not change. Dubai (United Arab Emirates) once came to Nigeria to borrow money. And what prevents transformation in Dubais from happening in Nigeria is the corruption of our leaders." According to the preacher, the massive protests that greeted the removal of fuel subsidy by President Goodluck Jonathan in January demonstrated that the myth that Nigerians are a docile people, who lost the capacity to be shocked by the misdeeds of their rulers, has been shattered forever. Calling for protests to immediately begin, Bakare noted that almost everywhere in the world, democracy was preceded by revolution, and development, just as he agonized that, Nigeria had put the cart before the horse. If the clarion call for protests is heeded by the civil society, Nigerians, in no time will witness another mother of all protests against corruption and corrupt people in the country. And Bakare has assured that when it happens, it would shake the country to its very foundation.

TITLE: We are not fighting corruption-Izuogu
SUBJECT: GOVERNORS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); CIVIL WAR (71%); AIRCRAFT ACCIDENTS (68%); BOKO HARAM (65%)
TEXT: From Iheanacho Nwosu,Abuja Three times governorship candidate in Imo State and People's Democratic Party (PDP) chieftain, Dr Ezekiel Izuogu is not happy with the way things are going in the country. Apart from the insecurity, which has reached an unacceptable height, the corruption in the system and the lip-service government is paying to the crusade against it is the main reason he is sad. He also shared his thoughts on a number of other issues, including the controversy surrounding the money released by Anambra State governor for Dr. Alex Ekwueme's 80th birthday celebrations. Excerpts: You have, in some fora, lamented some events of last year, are you by that, suggesting that the national leadership did not do much? No, no. I am not indicting anybody. There are many things to be thankful for. We should thank God that we are alive; we should thank God that our country remains one; we should thank God that we seem to have a sense of direction even though we appear to be slow. As I said, there are many things to thank God for. However, last year was very, very bloody; it was the bloodiest year we have witnessed since the history of this country, apart from the civil war. The activities of Boko Haram were scary and bloody. The insecurity in the country reached an alarming level last year. Our country is now classified as the sixth most dangerous in the world. And that is not a wonderful commendation. These are great challenges. But, despite these challenges we have reason to thank God. We have remained a nation under God in spite of these incredible challenges. Look at the air crash involving the governor of Kaduna, that was very scary. My heart goes out to the widow of Yakowa and to the people of the state. The crash raised the level of insecurity to another level, a short shuttling that was less than 20 minutes in a chopper could claim the lives of those on board including a governor. Am happy that people are speaking on the need for a thorough probe into the incident. There is need for such probe so as to know if the crash was as a result of technical fault or sabotage. Everything does appear that nobody is safe anymore; you are not safe walking on the road, flying in the air or on water. I do hope that the Federal Government would look with seriousness the concerns of average Nigerians as far as security is concerned. Are you not contradicting yourself when you said that insecurity has reached an alarming proportion and yet you said that there is a direction in the country? I said that we have reasons to thank God for the nation because we have remained one despite the challenges we have had, there is nothing contradictory about that. The situation has been bad but we have managed to move along. I also think that the government is doing its best. I do not see what the President could have done to stop the Boko Haram insurgency other than to look for a negotiated settlement. And the government has made it clear, a number of times, that it is willing to negotiate with the sect. I support negotiation with the sect. Are you saying those who accuse the President of having not done much to address the worsening insecurity are not fair to him? Certainly, government must share some blame in what is happening because the issue of security belongs squarely to its court. Government at the federal, state and local government level has a duty to provide security for the populace. Certainly, more could be done by the government. Some are of the view that the President has not done much to deserve his loyalists campaigning for his re-election in 2015. What's your take? I don't share the view because in a democracy, people can campaign, it is allowed. If somebody chooses to campaign from now to 2015, he is not breaking any law. So, those who want to campaign for his re-election can do so. But what is there is that, in a democracy, the people would have to take a decision at the appropriate time. That is why democracy provides for an election.Œæ In 2015, our people will decide if the incumbent has done well or not. If he has done well, they will vote for him, if not they will vote him out. But so far, would you say the President is on track and deserves a re-election? It is not for that yet; election is not close by. When we get to the bridge, we will cross it. Certainly, I will take a decision as a Nigerian citizen on who to support at the appropriate time. I'm not going to be shy about that. You have been moving round, campaigning that the South East should produce the next president. Is that not an indirect statement that the president has no chance the next time? No, you are wrong there. Advocating a South Eastern presidency does not equate to a vote of no confidence in anybody. We are talking about equity. In a democracy like that of Nigeria, you have to have justice and equity in order to stabilize the system. That is the position of South East Forum, which I am the chairman of. We are saying that, of all the six geo-political zones, it is only the South East that has not produced the President. We are saying that the South East deserves to have a short at the presidency. However, nothing stops Jonathan from running, under a democracy. But even if he is running, that is not enough to stop somebody from South East from running for the office; it will not stop a northerner from running. The annoying thing is that some of our brothers are saying that no one from the South East should even think about it, until Jonathan finishes, whenever he finishes. I do not share that view. I share the view that, yes, an incumbent has a right to aspire for a second term and it is left to the people to judge whether he deserves a second term or not. That does not stop anybody from running. You cannot make a law that nobody should run until A or B has finished. Obama was adjudged doing well in his first term but he had challengers. The Republican Party produced Mitt Rommney and he ran a very good race that he nearly won the election. There is no monopoly in election. You supported Jonathan 100 per cent in 2011. I supported Jonathan and went round with his campaign train. Initially, I looked at the zoning system of the PDP and I said, if we were to go by the zoning agreement, it favoured the North. But Jonathan, through circumstantial providence, became acting President. When President Yar'Adua died, he became President. So, he was an incumbent and he had only done one year before the 2011 election. The South South had not produced a President before then, he was the first South Southern person to be president and that was why my sentiment went for him. My position was that, since he was there for only a year, he needed to be given a chance to do another four years. That has happened. So, the situation in 2011 will not the same in 2015. I am a man of equity and justice. I supported MKO Abiola because I believed then that power should shift from the North to South. I went round the country with Abiola. Even when some Igbo were opposing him, I was mobilizing support for him; I got Igbo leaders to support him. I was doing that because I believe in equity. If the South South had not produced a president, I would throw my weight behind the zone to produce the next president. I cannot be against my people, if I advocate justice for other people, would I not also do same for my own people? Dokubo recently claimed that the President has disappointed the South South and South East that were his stronghold in 2011. Do you share his sentiment? No. I am a fair-minded person, I won't dismiss Jonathan just yet; he still has two and a half years to go. Even if he is not doing extremely well now, he has a chance of improving on his performance. If you ask me this question in 2014, I will give you a better answer. I am a scientist, I look at empirical evidence; I look at things before I pass a judgment. I won't judge Jonathan just yet. I think it is too early to do so. There are insinuations that you are at war with some Igbo leaders over your campaign for South East to field presidential candidate in 2015, how true is that? It is true, but the development is not discouraging to me. It is not because we are in a democracy, everybody is not bound to share my views, people are entitled to their different opinions. There are some people who are saying look, nobody should talk about presidency from the South East until Jonathan finishes. They are saying that to make Jonathan happy and get closer to him. I don't have any problem with that; they are free to do that. The President knows me very well; he knows that I am a frank person. My position is that, yes, if he performs well, he can contest. Even if he doesn't do well, he can still contest and the people would be left to judge. But that does not stop a South Easterner from contesting, that does not stop a northerner from contesting, we are in a democracy and everybody is free to aspire to any office. Our democracy is not supposed to be less democratic than that of America; it is not supposed to be guided. No matter how good an incumbent may be, there are still challengers. The incumbent may win with a landslide, which is to say that voters are happy with him or her. But because it is a democracy, there would be challengers. If there are no challengers, then it is a dictatorship. Have you lost some politician friends from the South East because of your position that someone from the zone should challenge Jonathan in 2015? Our democracy is a bit on the primitive side; it is like only sycophants are recoganised. Even when you give a constructive advice or criticism, they tag you as opposition. Nobody listens to constructive criticisms. This has made intelligent people to keep quiet because they do not want to be classified as enemies. Look at the case of US, during the election, Obama was openly attacking his opponent, calling him by name and Rommney openly attacked Obama, calling him by name. But the two focused on issues, their campaigns were issues-oriented. In Nigeria, when you try to correct somebody who is power, they will brand you an enemy. At my age, I don't think that should bother me. I believe that somebody must say the truth at some point. If we don't say the truth now, are we going to say it in our grave? I will not be against somebody dogmatically, but I will creativelyŒæ assess issues. When Abiola came, some people in Igboland said no, no they will not support a Yoruba man, I asked them why. Even if you had some quarrel with some Yoruba people in the past, it is wrong for you to generalize that all Yoruba are bad. I maintained the same posture in our meetings with them. I will not support every Igbo to be President, there are some I will never support because they will go there and mess everybody up. I won't support those who are very corrupt and incompetent. Igbo would be worse off if you put a corrupt Igbo there. He will embarrass everybody with his thievery and that will give bad name to Ndigbo. When we talk about equity and justice in the sharing of power, we are not sacrificing competence, only the competent can lead this country. You have been involved in media war with some prominent South East politicians over the handling of monies realised for the Dr Alex Ekwueme birthday celebrations recently, what really happened? My dear brother, that thing is very, very embarrassing, I feel ashamed talking about it because these were people I trusted and held in high esteem. I have not recovered from the shock of what happened. About three years ago the South East Forum (SEF) leaders decided to celebrate Ekwueme, their leader. This was more or less to show him appreciation for what he had done for the forum over the years. So, we said, ok, in three years the man would turn 80, it is a milestone, we have to celebrate him. I approached Ekwueme and told him, please we want to celebrate your birthday. I told him that SEF will organise a dinner for him at Transcorp Hilton, Abuja. He gave approval to that and we agreed that the highpoint of the celebrations would be bringing together all his friends to Transcorp to say good things about him. We knew that there would be other celebrations across the country for him. Federal Polytechnic, Oko, for instance, always does such for him. We focused on the dinner for political leaders. Three months to the time, we approached him again and he still gave his approval. Then we constituted the planning committee; we selected Senator Nnamani as Chairman, Okwesilieze Nwodo was like the alternate chairman... Is Nnamani a member of the forum? Yes. We gave terms of reference at the inauguration, which took place at Chelsea Hotel. We agreed the highpoint of the celebration would be dinner at Transcorp Hotel and a novelty football match. Nnamani accepted to work along those lines. Thereafter, they decided to see the governor of Anambra State, Mr. Peter Obi, who doubles as the Chairman of South East Governors' Forum. There was nothing wrong with that. They briefed Obi and he was very happy and promised that they were going to throw their weight behind the arrangement. He asked that some of the celebrations be brought to Enugu. He asked them to come up with a budget. The committee went and raised a budget of N82 million, they sent a copy to me. I said ok, if the governor is going to bring such money, then we have to open an account for it. The account was eventually opened in Damond Bank. The signatories to the account were the chairman of the forum, chairman of the planning committee, which was Nnamani and Nwodo, the secretary. The governor was duly informed. The opening of the account was where the problem started. Some members of the committee felt that this money going into an account where Izuogu is a signatory will not be too good for them. They felt that they would not have free hand, that Izuogu talks about accountability all the time and he will make things difficult for everybody. An attempt was made to remove me so that I will not be a signatory to the account but the move failed. They now changed strategy and wanted the money given to them directly without passing through the account. They succeeded in getting the money directly. But to my greatest surprise, they refused to release N5 million that was charged by Transcorp Hotel for the dinner. Three days to the dinner, I called former President Shagari and requested him to chair the dinner, he accepted even without getting a letter from me. Shagari was already on his way coming from Sokoto but the Nnamani committee refused to release the money for the dinner. What was the reason they gave for not releasing the money? No reason was given to me. The dinner nearly failed, I had to look for money and paid - that was two days to the event. That was how the dinner held. Now, the only activity that the committee did was the one-day cultural display in Enugu. I was reliably informed that not more than N8m was used for that. But N28m was released to them for that. We said if N28m was released, part of that should fund the dinner, which is only N5m. It was generally reported that the money was shared among themselves. I am not believing rumours and that is why I said that the committee has to give an account. Have you reached Nnamani since then? Oh yes, several efforts. In fact, SEF wrote him a letter because all the committees that worked for the birthday, as far as SEF is concerned, rendered account. Two days after the dinner, we rendered an account of the dinner - how it was organised, how the money was raised and how much was spent. We sent the account to all the leaders of SEF, including Nnamani. It is a normal thing that after an activity, there is an account of how much money was raised and how the money was spent. We are not accusing anybody, everybody in the committee is my personal friend - my brothers - but we are saying that leaders must show example. I believe that leaders in this country must be accountable. They accuse you of deliberately trying to smear their reputation, how do you defend that? That is why I am giving this clarification. Why should I smear anybody's name; what will I gain from that? Look at my background in Imo State; all my political opponents know that I don't smear anybody's name. There are enough issues to hold in your campaign, I don't descend to the level of wanting to smear anybody's name. I don't stand to gain anything by doing that. If somebody says you should give him an account of an activity of N28m of public fund, is that smear? The simple thing is to render the account to show that you are clean. I am the Chairman of SEF, the buck stops on my table, so I have every reason to demand the rendering of the account. Every member of the forum is crying foul, you need to listen to what they are saying about the whole thing. They are giving impression that because it involved big men, that is why they cannot be called to render account. They are saying, because this has to do with former Senate President, former governor and National Chairman of PDP they can do anything and get away with it. Our constitution prescribes suspension of anybody that does anything that contravenes the rules of the association. Have they been suspended? No, we are still waiting for the accounts. Is the celebrant aware of all these allegations and counter allegations? Yes, he is aware. We never wanted to bother him with any of these things but he got to know later. When you are celebrating somebody's birthday, you want to keep him out of the arrangements; you want it to be a surprise package for him. So, as much as possible, we tried to keep these things away from Ekwueme. If these people had rendered an account, nobody would have heard about it. But a situation where a committee you set up would collect the money that was given on the platform of the forum and then refused to fund a legitimate item of the birthday is unacceptable. The dinner was approved by the national planning committee of Ekwueme birthday headed by Bamanga Tukur. I have the programme and it had Ekwueme's approval. The dinner was not for Ezekiel Izuogu; it was for the celebrant. If that is the case, why would they hold N28 million and refuse to bring out less than N5m to fund the dinner? Do you align with those who accuse President Jonathan of having not shown enough courage to fight corruption? I share that view, I believe that the government can do more to control corruption. I sincerely believe that the government of Nigeria, not just Jonathan's government, those that preceded Jonathan's own paid lip-service to anti-corruption crusade. Corruption is romanced in this country. Government may condemn it publicly, but down the line, you see corruption in almost everything we do. The culture of impunity appears to have eaten into our system and that is why people can go and handle big sums of money and they would feel that they are not accountable to anybody. It is a culture that is developing and it is very, very unfortunate. The young people are looking at the leaders. They are now copying the so-called leaders and are now going into kidnapping, armed robbery, etc. I am not condoning any of those vices because there is no justifiable reason for going into kidnapping or armed robbery but the truth is that the young people are looking at we elders. If they cannot find good behaviours from us, they take to anything. We have a situation today, where anybody who grabs money is celebrated; he is given a national award, he becomes an important person. Nobody cares to know how he made his money. That is the greatest problem we have in this country. You are now using bad examples as more or less what people should emulate. Every young person now wants to be a multi-millionaire. He knows that there are some multi-billionaires who never worked, who only engaged in one or two frauds before hitting it. In Imo State where you hail from, kidnapping is clearly an issue. Would you attribute the crime to a failure of governance in the state? It is not just in the state but generally there is failure of governance. The leaders have been showing bad examples. It is a cumulative effect of rigging elections, where young people are watching somebody who did not win but because he did some manipulations, is announced as winner and everybody is falling on the ground shouting "Your Excellency, Your Excellency." It is a bad example that people are borrowing. You find people who clearly had no means of livelihood but have wangled their way to wealth, they become exceedingly rich. The young people are looking at these things and at some point, they reach a conclusion that, look, the rules don't really matter. If you obey the rules you lose out, you become a mugu. Those who are keeping to the rules become mugus; those who are wangling their way become the guys. What is happening is a cumulative effect of evils. The evils are leading to more evils. I warned our people in Imo State ten years ago about what is happening now.

TITLE: Nigeria needs a radical leader to fight corruption -Abonta, Rep.
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); LEGISLATION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); REAL PROPERTY LAW (77%); CORRUPTION (76%); HISTORY (69%)
TEXT: By Iheanacho Nwosu Uzoma Abonta , a former don, is a member of the House of Representatives from Abia State. He is the Deputy Chairman , House Committee on Privatisation and Commercialisation . The lawmaker stands out as the sponsor of the highest bills on the floor of the House. In this interview he shared his thoughts on a number of issues including governance , corruption and his mission in the House. On his Bills: Most of my bills have been passed by the House and sent to the Senate for concurrence. You know how slow lawmaking is - first, second reading, committee stage and then to the whole house before passage. It takes an average of two years to have a bill turned into an Act but we will not relent in our efforts to make laws forŒæ good governance of the country. My interest has been on alternative source of revenue outside oil. So my bills revolve around agriculture and theŒæ capital market. Quite a number of my bills have been concluded in the House and sent to the Senate for concurrence butŒæ I am aware that none has been sent to the President for assent. Constitution Review: The problems confronting the constitution review is the usual legislative problems. The constitution is made in such a way that it is very rigid and difficult to amend. With the way we are going, I will give the National Assembly credit for what has been done so far. But I also have my fears being a Nigerian, Œæ a constitutional lawyer, being a student of political history and given the way Nigeria is structured. If you follow the history of Nigeria and all our efforts at constitution making,you will see that it is going to be a herculian task. We have 36 states and we have diverse interests. You know the composition of the National Assembly as well as I do and how someŒæ people view issues from sectional perspectives rather than nationalŒæ interests. Therefore do not expect that the ongoing amendment will be easy. In the last dispensation, National Assembly in its wisdom, granted financial autonomy to the State Houses of Assembly but the same legislators in the states voted against it. Now we are talking about granting a similar autonomy to the local government councils. In the course of the public sessions, most of the local governments voted for this autonomy but today the argument seems not to be in favour of that decision. The issue is that the powers that be seem to be working against that proposal.The postponement of the public presentation of the report of our nationwideŒæ public sessions is not aŒæ problem because the position of the 360 constituencies were taken publicly and therefore already public documents. The major challenge will come when anŒæ issue such as the Land Use Act will come up. You know some people might not want it removed from the constitution. If it comes to a matter of voting, you know the composition of the House. Numerically, Œæ Kano, Kebbi and Jigawa are bigger than the five states of the South East geopolitical zone. So if some people do not want certain amendments and it is one man one vote, there is no way it can go. However, I do not want to be a prophet of doom. I have hope that we will get there. If we do not succeed in amending all the sections we want to now, there will at least be substantial amendment. We should not lose hope.In amending the constitution, we must create awareness about the issues at stake. ŒæWe must also have the political will to go all out because it is going to hurt the powers that be in the system. It is not easy to retrieve from the mighty. It must be something that must be contested vehemently.The task of constitutional amendment is not just for the legislators; the media and the civil society groups must play their own roles of sensitising and mobilising the people. Local Government Autonomy I will give you the answer from two perspectives - as a Nigerian and a oneŒæ who has been a councillor. In 1991, I was a councillor and leader of the Legislative Council in Ukwa-East Local Government Area of Abia State.If you don't grant autonomy to local government councils, they will still remain an appendage of the state governors. Today, a local government chairman does not have a say in what goes on at the council. Although he is the head of the third tier of government he cannot say no to the governor of the state. In 1991-1993 when we were there, the situation was better than it is today. I cannot hold the chairman of my local government accountable now because he is only there at the mercy of the state governor.Until the two tiers are separated and each is given specific roles the problem will remain. Most importantly, there should be financial autonomy for the local government councils and that means the State/Local Government Joint Account should be abolished. Let this account be separated so that councils can get their funds directly andŒæ be free to pursue development according to the needs of their people and no according to the dictates of the state governors. The councillors should be able to vet the budget of the councils just like the National Assembly does to the federal budget. Today, a lot of things happening at the local government level come from the Commissioner for Local Government and Chieftaincy Affairs, an appointee of the state governor.This is why the governors wouldn't want to let go until Nigerians put up aŒæ fight. As a lawyer, I also know that if you give the councils fullŒæ autonomy without checks, we will also whittle down the essence of federalism. True federalism recognises two components - the centre and the component states. It does not recognise the local government as a tier. Therefore in giving autonomy to the local government, we must be very careful and define the extent of the autonomy. It is desirable and proper to grant them autonomy because it will foster development and stabilise our democracy. Capital Market The issue of the capital market has remained very topical. During the controversy, the leadership of theŒæ House in their wisdom asked the Capital Market Committee to step aside for an interim committee to investigate the collapse of the capital market. This wasŒæ to allow fair hearing on the issues. The Adhoc Committee concluded the investigation and also laid the report before the House.The capital market and its institutions areŒæ still functioning, but because of the prolonged problem between the House, Arunma Oteh and the Presidency, we declared the DG persona non grata.We still do our oversight over the capital market institutions but the House said we will have nothing to do with SEC as long as Oteh remains there. The House has forwarded its resolution to President for implementation. Though he is yet to take action, I assure you that the House will not toy with the capital market because it is also one of the indices to monitorŒæ our economy. It is one way to attract investors and grow our economy.It is not in our interest as a country to allow the capital market crash. Right now we are talking with the Abuja Commodity ExchangeŒæ Market which is one of the institutions in the sector. They have some challenges and we are trying to see how we can fix the problems. Corruption I make bold to say that corruption is the problem of Nigeria. Peter Tosh once said that everybody is talking about the criminal; who then is the criminal? Nigeria is a very corrupt society and we are not fighting corruption. We are romancing with corruption; we are sleeping with corruption; we are doing our valentine with corruption and do everything with corruption. Corruption is fastŒæ becomingŒæ a norm in Nigeria.President Goodluck Jonathan must sit up and fight corruption; the war must start from the Villa. We need a very radical leader who will fight corruption.The AsianŒæ countries of China, Singapore, Malaysia and indonesia were more corrupt than Nigeria until one day whenŒæ their leaders rose to the challenge and introduced capital punishment as penalty for corruption. As soon as the law came into force anyone caught stealing public funds or engaging in any form of corruption was either hanged of shot dead. Today we talk about the Asian Tigers because their leaders decided to have zero tolerance for corruption. But here,Œæ our laws are loose and some of us would not mind going to jail and come back to inherit N10billion. We know that you can even steal billions and just pay a paltry fine and go home to enjoy your loot.I make bold to say that civil servants are the worst problemŒæ of Nigeria. I call them "evil servants" because they are not civil in any way. Once you are appointed a minister, they send you one big memo; they tell you how you can buy a house where you will live. Once you sign that memo you are finished.Look at our annual budgets; the amount of money spent in the month of December is greater that allŒæ the money spent in the remaining part of the year. Why is it that under personal and overhead costs all the funds must be finished at the end of the year? They told us they discovered 45,000 ghost workersŒæ in the civil service. How many are the civil servants if 45,000 are ghosts? In all these, no one has been punished and we have directors and permanent secretaries in those ministries.I think that something drastic has to be done. Corruption has become endemic here and itŒæ is not found only among civil servants. Even other members of the society like market womenŒæ are involved. Go to the market toŒæ buy garri and they will sell to you with falsified measurements. It is corruption at that level. It is not only among people in government that you find corruption. We have had several investigations but nobody has been jailed. It is so bad that people now think that the best way to be rich and popular is to engage in corruption. When you are arrested and taken to court, you enjoy free publicity and after that nothing happens and you go home and enjoy your loot. The few thatŒæ even even went to jail came back and are now eminent persons deciding the fate of Nigerians instead of burying their heads in shame.In other countries they would have been hang for their crimes. I am not saying that we must apply capital punishment but we must try to do something that will show that we have zero tolerance to corruption. We need ethical revolution. Starting from the market women, school children, civil servants and even to the politicians.The greatest number of empty house in Abuja is in Asokoro and Maitama districts. Nobody is occupying them because they are not affordableŒæ and their owners are not bothered about it. Who owns them? Civil servants. If they pay you your salary twenty years up front you cannot afford those houses. So how were these civil servants able to acquire them?ŒæThis is why mass housing or low cost housing schemes have not worked. When government designs low cost housing projects, the high cost people will acquire them all and then rent them to the low cost people.

TITLE: Nigeria must fight corruption to avoid Arab spring -Jerry Rawlings
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (85%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); RULE OF LAW (77%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (76%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (71%); ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION (61%); CONTRACT AWARDS (60%); CONSTRUCTION (50%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (50%)
TEXT: From Geoffrey Anyanwu, Awka Former President of Ghana, Jerry Rawlings yesterday in Awka called on African countries especially Nigeria to face headon now the fight against corruption in government or risk a sudden eruption as occurred in Egypt and Tunisia. Rawlings, who gave a keynote address at the 2nd Zik Lecture Series of the Faculty of Social Sciences, Nnamdi Azikiwe University, Awka on the theme; "Eradicating Corruption in Africa", stated that though it would be a big battle, it was not one that could not be fought, warning that its postponement would spell doom for the country and the continent. According to him, "corruption arises from a state of deviation from the moral or spiritual norm; it is a deliberate refusal to operate based on set rules, regulations and laws and with a wicked, if not evil desires to circumvent the punitive actions that come with such deliberate action. Corruption manifests itself in many ways." At the lecture, which was attended by prominent personalities, including the Special Adviser to the President on Inter Party Affairs, Senator Ben Obi, who was the chairman of the occasion, Senator. Chris Ngige, Gov. Peter Obi, Senior Special Assistant to the President, Chief Akachukwu Nwakpu, former ASUU President, Prof. Asisi Asobie, who was the guest lecturer and traditional rulers, Rawlings said he sees corruption more in terms of moral degradation and a greedy quest to outdo each other in terms of class, distinction and perceived respect in society. He further said: "It is the willingness to tolerate the intolerable that gives the motivation or momentum for persons or institutions with influence to perpetrate acts of corruption within our society. Corruption at the level of government directly affects the rule of law and debases the moral right of political leadership to serve as a respected regulator of the affairs of the state. "Corruption in our society is most prevalent whenever the private sector meets government over transactions of state - construction of roads, procurement of goods, equipment and services and provision of various forms of services for the state. As desirable as they may be, development projects and especially the huge modernisation projects, lend themselves to this form of corruption. "It is not uncommon for state institutions and personalities such as ministers and various departments to award contracts not to the lowest bidder or the best-value-for-money bidder but to the one who effectively offers the highest bribe." ŒæThe former Ghanaian leader, therefore, said that leadership by example meant that a leader whether at national or local level, must not merely talk about truth, integrity and accountability but must demonstrate those qualities in their daily lives. Further advising the leaders he said: "Leaders must understand that when you take away the power of the people to express moral outrage, you have effectively disempowered your capacity to fight corruption through the people. Let us have faith in our people and respect them. We have statesmen and women of integrity on our continent."

TITLE: Check corruption, focus on reforms
SUBJECT: EXECUTIVE MOVES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%)
TEXT: ...My immediate priority, by Goni From JULIANA TAIWO-OBALONYE, Abuja From the President yesterday came a directive to the new Head of Civil Service of the Federation (HOSF), Bukar Goni Aji: continue with reforms embarked by your predecessors, check corruption and revamp the Federal Civil Service, ensuring it is returned to its glorious days. President Goodluck Jonathan gave the charge at the swearing-in of Goni, witnessed by Vice President Namadi Sambo, Governor of Yobe State Ibrahim Gaidam, Secretary to the Government of the Federation (SGF), Sen. Anyim Pius Anyim, ministers, presidential aides, Goni's predecessors, Alhaji Isa Bello Sali, former Head of Service, Amb. Abu Obe, Ebele Okeke (first female Head of Service), Steve Oronsaye and Prof. Oladapo Afolabi. While commending Goni for coming well-prepared both academically and professional experience, the President said the change of leadership of the service came when his administration was not just taking stock of what have been accomplished so far in meeting the desires and aspirations of the people, but also accelerating action and increasing articulation of those things still outstanding in national development. Jonathan, who commended Sali, who he said served the nation well and retired meritoriously, charged the new HOSF to build on what his predecessors have done and focus on areas that would bring accelerated impact on the lives of Nigerians. "The civil service which you now head is very central to the realization of our Transformation Agenda as a people and the associated hopes and aspirations of our citizens. "I will want to especially draw your attention to the ongoing reforms aimed at our nation's rapid economic development. "As you set about your duties, the expectation of the government and our people is that you will now build on the achievements of your predecessors so as to complete on-going reforms. In particular, you must focus on those sectors that will help the administration to deliver with urgency, beliefs and benefits which are the core of our survival as a people. Such as agriculture, infrastructure, education, health, among others. "You must also pursue with vigour the true implementation of the performance management system in the civil service, I believe its full implementation will positively improve the ability of civil servants to discharge their responsibilities. I also expect that you will intensify your efforts to enhance discipline and curtail corruption in the service. "The civil service was historically acknowledged as the citadel of excellence where the best brains, equipment and strategies are engaged, under your leadership, you must all work hard to bring back that type of civil service in the interest of our nation. It is in this regard I want to call on all civil servants to lend you their unalloyed support especially the permanent secretaries that will work with you and cooperate in the movement of greater efficiency, dedication and patriotism in service. "I commend you for your devotion to the course of the Nigerian public service, you have come prepared not just academically but also by your wealth of experience, leadership capacity and administrative skills. My prayer is that let the end of your tenure be heralded as era of remarkable improvement in the quality of service in our country," he said. Goni told State House correspondents later that he will focus on the President's directives to re-position the civil service. "Our immediate priority as directed by President is to re-position the civil service for the attainment of the objectives under the Transformation Agenda of government and how we intend to do this is that we will slightly depart from the way we do things in the past. "We will emphasise on fast-tracking the processes so that we will ensure there are concrete outcomes for our people to see and that is the immediate priority that I will put my attention to." He said: "On the issue of job racketeering, as usual just like any other sector of our national life, you must know there are syndicates, there are crooks who tap into the websites of agencies that are not even known to those agencies and before you know it, unsuspecting Nigerians are found in the hands of those dubious characters."

TITLE: Taming the monster called corruption
SUBJECT: RELIGION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ENDOWMENTS (89%); NATURAL RESOURCES (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (76%); PARENT COMPANIES (76%); OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (76%); BUSINESS EDUCATION (75%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (71%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (69%)
TEXT: By OBIAGELI UKEOMA It is in Proverbs 10: 22 that the Bible declared: "The blessing of the Lord, it maketh rich, and He addeth no sorrow with it." This injunction is a promise of God to mankind. However, in Nigeria and of course, Africa generally, the reverse seems to be the case because there are too many greedy people in government Corruption, the manifestation of greed, is endemic in the extractive industry. However, in a bid to enthrone transparency in this critical sector, and following the gradual return of stakeholders' confidence, PWYP Norway and Norwegian School of Economics (NHH), with support from Norad and Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, organised a conference on Financial Secrecy, Society and Vested Interest in Bergen, last year. The choice of the conference title was informed by the fact that secrecy in the extractive industries has really impoverished the citizens of resource rich countries, which paradoxically is the "resource curse." Nigeria, which is endowed with natural resources, ranging from coal, diamond, gold, limestone, iron ore etc, is a typical victim of the curse. The high level of corruption and theft due to lack of transparency, particularly the oil and gas industry, is quite alarming. The oil sector in the world has, over the years, gained notoriety as a place where corruption thrives and a few individuals drain the country of its resources, which could, otherwise, have been used for the development of the nation. The oil resources led to massive corruption and civil strife, instead of being a blessing. It is farcical that African countries which are endowed with natural resources are poor due to lack of transparency and accountability by both the government and the companies licensed to operate in these countries. I feel duty bound, as a participant in the said conference, to share some of the views on the need for transparency, if Nigeria and Africa as a whole is to benefit from its natural resources. Some issues in the financial secrecy include but not limited to the lawyer's confidentiality and tax havens. The name secrecy jurisdiction is preferred to tax haven because these jurisdictions sell services to foreigners. The huge financial income made is being transferred to the parent companies' country, thereby impoverishing the African nations and impacting them negatively. Considering the spate of corrupt practices by the government, as a result of the fact that the Nigerian economy is substantially public sector driven, mainly funded from the oil revenue, which, ultimately, remains a monopoly of government, the country loses a lot of money as a result of financial secrecy. The resources lost, if quantified, can provide good roads, good hospitals, good schools, all social amenities in all the local governments, thereby reducing the mortality rate in the nations. Transparency, which is the watchword in the management of natural resources in Nigeria, should be imbibed by all stakeholders in the sector. As a matter of fact, it should be one of the values associated with the companies involved in the exploitation of natural resources. For corruption to be curbed, every public expenditure and income should be put in a public domain for easy access to financial users. All other transparency initiatives focus on disclosing tax payments. The extended country-by-country reporting is the only reporting standard that requires companies to report their activities on country-by-country basis, in their host countries as well as their home countries. It is the only transparency reporting that is useful to all users of financial statements. The Nigerian government should, as a way of salvaging the country and promoting transparency in EI sector, consider the following: Avoid negotiations with companies; there should be fiscal terms in law instead of in contract; complete tax system and equal terms for all companies. If indeed we are serious about turning Nigeria around to a productive, progressive, corruption free country where men and women, rich and poor, indigene or non-indigene, royalty or commoner, able bodied or living with disability can realise their aspirations, utilise their potentials and function maximally, we must be ready for radical changes in our ways of thinking and doing things. Œ‡ Ukeoma wrote in from Lagos.

TITLE: Corruption, Nigeria's visa to failed statehood -Akanbi
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); FAILED & FRAGILE STATES (90%); ETHICS (89%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (89%); CURRICULA (89%); MURDER (78%); INDICTMENTS (78%); RULE OF LAW (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (76%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (76%); UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION (75%); TRENDS (75%); LAWYERS (74%); KIDNAPPING & ABDUCTION (73%); INFLATION (73%); ECONOMIC NEWS (73%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (68%)
TEXT: From LAYI OLANREWAJU, Ilorin Former chairman of the Independent Corrupt Practices and other related offences Commission (ICPC), Justice Mustapha Akanbi (retd), has warned that Nigeria is on the brink of becoming a failed state if the problem of corruption is not addressed with the seriousness it deserves. Justice Akanbi gave the warning while delivering a keynote address at the 46th annual conference of the Nigerian Association of Law Teachers (NALT) held at the University of Ilorin (UNILORIN) with the theme: Corruption and National Development. The eminent jurist lamented the increasing wave of unbridled corruption and criminality in the country, which, he said, could only be curbed if those in power had the political will to do so. In his lecture, Justice Akanbi said: "Bare-faced looting of public treasury, fuel subsidy scam, pension scam, money laundering, economic crimes of all sorts, oil bunkering, kidnapping, cold blooded murder, massacre, grand and petty corruption are now common day occurrences and they are all committed with reckless abandonment and impunity." He submitted that given the frenzied and fluid state of affairs in the country, the nation is on the path to the predicted failed state because "corruption breeds inefficient economic outcome, impedes long term foreign and domestic investment, reduces ability of the state to revise revenue, impedes the state's ability to provide essential public goods and services, promotes inflationary trends, undermines and reduces efficiency of professionals, makes project planning difficult, creates social unrest and undermines the legitimacy of state." The former ICPC chairman said Nigeria's poor transparency rating was due largely to lack of political will to confront the menace of corruption frontally and head on. He observed that the gradual decline and observable weaknesses of governmental institutions over the years to face the challenges of failing economy, political institutions and system were parts of the causes of corruption in the country. Challenging the judiciary to also take its place in the fight against corruption, the elder statesman said: "The judiciary must be independent if it is to effectively play the role of an arbiter and ensure that the rule of law prevails." In his opening remarks, President of the Nigerian Bar Association (NBA), Mr. Okey Wali, called on universities in the country to review their curricula to include professional ethics.  He noted that universities in the country must introduce professional ethics in their curricula to address the problem of lawyers lacking in ethical knowledge. While describing corruption as the biggest cancer and worst problem facing the nation, Wali noted that the recent American report indicting the country on the issue of corruption only served to remind the nation of a problem that was well known. Earlier in his welcome address, Vice Chancellor of the University of Ilorin, Prof. AbdulGaniyu Ambali described the conference theme as apt and timely. The vice chancellor, who was represented on the occasion by the Deputy Vice Chancellor (RTI), Prof. Felix Oladele, also noted that corruption was not a new phenomenon but a disease that had eaten up every facet of the Nigerian society. President, Nigerian Association of Law Teachers (NALT), and acting Dean of Law, UNILORIN, Dr. Abdulqadir Ibrahim Abikan, in his remarks stated that the NALT conference had become a household event through which law teachers throughout the country gathered to ruminate on topical national issues. Abikan stated that the drive to eliminate corruption prompted the choice of the title of the conference.

TITLE: The US report on corruption in Nigeria
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS (72%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (71%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (70%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (70%)
TEXT: The recent submission by the United States Government that massive corruption pervades all levels of government in Nigeria is weighty and disturbing. Although this negative profiling of Nigeria is not entirely surprising, it is a dent on the country's image. The damming report, said to have been submitted to the United States Congress by the Secretary of State, John Kerry, is lifted from a document entitled "Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012". The document prepared by the US State Department, was sourced from information from US embassies and consulates abroad, foreign government officials, non-governmental and international organisations and published reports. Among other things, it alleges that though Nigerian laws provide criminal penalties for official corruption, government has done little or nothing to implement the laws effectively. The outcome of this failure to implement anti-corruption laws, the report further alleges, is that public officials in Nigeria frequently engaged in corrupt practices with impunity. Besides, the report took a swipe at the Nigerian judiciary, accusing our judges of taking bribes, thereby making it difficult to render impartial judgments, while litigants wait for long periods for their cases to be heard. Over all, the scathing report estimated that Nigeria lost about N1.067 trillion ($6.8 billion) to what it calls endemic corruption and entrenched inefficiency. Expectedly, the Federal Government has reacted forcefully to the US report. President Goodluck Jonathan described the report as skewed, overblown and unrealistic. He said his administration has not relented in its fight against corruption, insisting that all the relevant laws are being applied against those who have corruption cases against them, contrary to the allegation that his administration is treating corruption with kid gloves. Despite the government's defence, the unassailable fact is that corruption in Nigeria has gone a notch higher in recent years. This is not only among politicians occupying high public offices, it has permeated Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) of government, as a recent anti-graft watchdog report revealed. This is a serious cause for worry. To continue to play the ostrich on the problem of corruption as the government is currently doing is to live in denial. The US report may have seemed alarming, but it is obvious that government is losing steam in the fight against corruption. This gives critics the impression that this administration is not demonstrating enough will to tackle corruption. It is also common knowledge that there are some glaring cases in which the government has not demonstrated seriousness in its anti-corruption crusade. Nigerians and the international community have been following the cases of corruption being handled by the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) and the Independent Corrupt Practices and Other Related Offences Commission (ICPC). All eyes are on Nigeria to see the conclusion of these cases. The handling and eventual resolution of the cases will go a long way in convincing skeptics that government is, indeed, committed to tackling corruption. Therefore, if the US report is the prodding that our government needs to ginger up the anti-graft crusade, it is welcome. There is no doubt that corruption, especially in high places, has become a threat to the nation's economy and a danger to our democracy. It is high time the Goodluck Jonathan administration got more serious with the fight against corruption. At the moment, government seems too tolerant of the menace. It appears to lack the political will to confront corruption head-on. This does our national image more harm than good. Let our leaders excise the cancer of corruption from Nigeria.

TITLE: N'Assembly workers protest alleged corruption, illegal deductions
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (89%); PETITIONS (78%); APPROPRIATIONS (78%)
TEXT: From IHEANACHO NWOSU, Abuja Activities at the National Assembly were yesterday paralysed as staff protested alleged corruption and questionable deductions from their salaries by the management. The workers, under the aegis of Parliamentary Association of Nigeria (PASAN) said the management owed them N11 billion. The protesting staff, who took over the White HouseŒælobby, an entrance to the Senate and House of Representatives chambers, grounded legislative businessŒæfor about three hours. The intervention of the Senate President, David Mark and the Speaker, House of Representatives, Aminu Tambuwal, however, saved the day. The duo addressed the crowdŒæand promised to look into their allegations. Addressing his colleagues, PASAN Chairman,ŒæNational Assembly chapter, Mohammed Bawa, said the workers would continue to press that the management of National Assembly attent to their demands. He urged Mark and Tambuwal to institute a public probe into the activities of the National Assembly management with a view to making them account as it concerned staff strength and funds appropriated for staff salaries, training, welfare and other incentives. "That you direct the management to pay the approved CONLESS within 21 days beginning from yesterday. "That the management should refund N10, 000 with nine per cent interest from the date of payment," he said. Yesterday'sŒæprotest was a follow up to series of agitations including petitions to bothŒæMark and Tambuwal by the workers. Bawa vowed that the staffers would continue the protest until the authorities of the National Assembly Commission yielded to their demands. He insisted that theirŒædemands were non negotiable, urging the leadership of the two chambers to investigate the activities of National Assembly management. He expressed appreciation to both Senate president and Speaker of House of Representaives, who personally received their petition from them. Bawa, who declined to go into details of the allegation, accused the management of not paying attention to the welfare of workers, saying he would not want to pre-empt outcome of a meeting already scheduled for this week among all stakeholders. Some PASAN members, who spoke under condition of anonymity, said the bone of contention was the refusal of the management to refund N10, 000 being deducted from their salary annually.

TITLE: Ekwueme, Clark, Gbonigi, others meet on Boko Haram, corruption
SUBJECT: BOKO HARAM (92%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (91%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); HOTELS & MOTELS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); RESORTS (72%); NATURAL DISASTERS (66%); FLOODS & FLOODING (66%)
TEXT: By DURO ADESEKO Leaders of the Southern Nigerian Peoples Assembly will tomorrow begin a two-day conference on some issues affecting the country including the threats posed by Boko Haram Islamist sect and corruption, among others. It was gathered that the meeting, which holds at the Eko Hotels and Suites, Victoria Island, Lagos and ends on Monday, was called to enable the leaders to form a common front over the ongoing constitution review. A statement signed by Senator Anthony Ogungbemi Adefuye on behalf of the conveners yesterday said the conference will be presided over by the leader of Yoruba Unity Forum, Bishop Emmanuel Gbonigi while Dr. Alex Ekweme will lead the Southeast delegates and Chief Edwin Clark the Southsouth delegates. "The conference will attract seasoned administrators and astute scholars of note and they will brainstorm and agree on such an enduring constitution that will return Nigeria to her glory", it added. Discussions at the conference will focus on the constitutional review by the National Assembly, amnesty for Boko Haram sect, the national insecurity, corruption and national development. Other topics for discussion include the national centenary dialogue and renegotiation on the basis for national unity and the emergency preparation for the prompt arrest of the anticipated flood disaster in 2013 by the relevant sectors of the economy among others. The conference is the third of its series.ŒæIt debuted and was held in Ibom Hotels and Resort, Uyo, Akwa Ibom State in July 2012 under the chairmanship of Chief Edwin Cark. It was followed by another held in Enugu under the chairmanship of former Vice President, Alex Ekweme. A communiquí© is expected to be issued at the end of the conference.

TITLE: God used me to fight corruption in Nigerian football - Lulu
SUBJECT: SPORTS BUSINESS (90%); SOCCER TOURNAMENTS (90%); SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (89%); SPORTS AWARDS (89%); FIFA WORLD CUP (89%); SPORTS & RECREATION (88%); ELECTIONS (76%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (73%); TOURNAMENTS (73%); DUE PROCESS (70%); CORRUPTION (69%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (69%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (69%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (68%)
TEXT: By ROMANUS UGWU, Abuja Alhaji Sani Lulu Abdullahi will certainly occupy an enviable position when the history of Nigerian football administration is documented. He came, he saw and glamorised football administration in the country while he lasted as the 'Lord of the Glass House'. Even though not many will concur with the above assertion, the Kogi State-born Quantity Surveyor had battled relentlessly to convince Nigerians to accord him some respect for the impressive input he made in the development of football in the country. Fielding questions from the media during his recent birthday celebration at his FOSLA Academy in Abuja, Lulu spoke on a wide range of issues, especially the continued cry of financial crisis by the current board of the Nigeria Football Federation (NFF), the debate over Super Eagles players' winning match bonuses and the rumoured anointing of a candidate for the upcoming 2014 NFF presidential election. Read on! Cry of lack of funds by NFF officials I was once the president of NFF and I saw it all. That's why it's always very important that I share my little experiences, especially now that normalcy is returning to the system. I was in the football federation for about four years based on the mandate that was given to me. I started on a very pathetic note because I inherited a debt profile of over N300million. There was absolutely nothing in the coffers of the NFF when we came on board. But while I was leaving office in 2010, though through fraudulent impeachment, I left an amount totaling N2.8billion in various accounts of the body despite the fact that I did not run a revenue-generating organisation. Mindful of the fact that 2010 was the peak period for Nations Cup and World Cup, N500million and N900million were respectively released for the events by the government. What I got from government as at July 2010 was less than N2billion. You can imagine that with all those hectic programmes, I prosecuted those tournaments and still left N2.8billion in the coffers of the NFF. I challenge anybody to refute my claim. Debt for the current board Incidentally, there was no statement of account when I left office. But it is on record that I lent the federation some money from my personal account. There're due processes of remitting funds and I want to believe that, as at the time we're talking about, there could be some pockets of debts here and there. But even though there was no detailed account, I doubt if the total debt was up to N100million. That was not anything close to the money I left behind. For clarity sake, the amount I left behind was part of the $8million proceed from the 2010 World Cup, the $5.5million payment from Nigeria 2009 FIFA Under-17 World Cup and a leftover of about N400million from the federal government grant for the World Cup. We had up to that amount because we crashed out of the World Cup early. Unfortunately, the claim that my administration left some debts behind had continued to reverberate. When I took the mantle of leadership from Alhaji Ibrahim Galadima, the news was that his administration left some money in the coffers of the Nigeria Football Association (NFA), but I felt indicted because I met over N300million debts on ground. I refuted that claim with facts and bank statements. It was different from my claim. I made a statement of fact that I left N2.8billion in the coffers of the federation and till today, nobody has disputed my claim. This has no relationship with the court contempt case we are currently facing. For me, I know that I left a healthy system. Conception of Nigerians Some people used the power they have in government to give a very wrong impression about my administration, painting us as corrupt individuals, but I sincerely believe that at the appropriate time, we will expose those people. I spoke to the media recently, where I challenged Nigerians that anybody with any evidence against me should come and confront me with facts. For the records, no corrupt person would be given less than N2billion to run his administration within a year and the person will leave behind more than N2.8billion while being illegally impeached from office. It is on record that a non-fund generating organisation was able to leave such an amount in its coffers. Can I be corrupt with all these evidences on ground? Alleged corrupt practices For the fact that I was part of the system, I cannot exonerate myself from corruption in the Glass House during my regime. But I must confess that I fought corruption headlong for the four years I ran Nigerian football. The facts are there to substantiate my claims. I suspended the issuance of ITC (International Transfer Certificate) and FIFA Players Agent certification for one year because I was not too sure about the transparency in handling those issues. I insisted on knowing the standard and the nitty-gritty in those transactions. I fine-tuned the issuance of ITC to conform to the international standard. Then, I was ready to indict, discipline or even terminate the appointment of anybody that was found wanting in the deal. I hate illegality and nobody can accuse me of getting involved in such. However, I cannot beat my chest and claim that we wiped out corruption in the Glass House completely because I couldn't have been everywhere at the same time. But the good thing is that we put down the structures with which to fully eradicate corruption from the system and God used me to fight corruption in the system headlong. Regrets? I sincerely believe that God used Nigerians to put me in the Glass House and He had His reasons for making it possible. I'm not aggrieved at all, but I must confess that some people actually offended me and by offending me, they offended God. Those people only deprived Nigerians of enjoying the smooth continuity of what we had in stock for the nation. We came to redirect and re-engineer Nigerian football with the vision of using the power of the game to develop the future of the Nigerian youth. We were carefully pursuing the programme before it was truncated along the line. It's only Nigerians that can assess us with what we did, what our predecessors did and what our successors are currently doing now. Return to the Glass House I'm not in the mood to campaign for any position and I had repeatedly said it that I did not leave anything at the Glass House that I would want to go back to collect. I spent my personal money to develop Nigerian football. So, I'm leaving everything to Nigerians to judge. But the ultimate person that determines the destiny of any man is God and He does it at His own time.

TITLE: Why corruption cases fail in court - Agbakoba
SUBJECT: MIRANDA RULE (93%); CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (89%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (88%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); LITIGATION (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (77%); SUPREME COURTS (76%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (75%); ARRESTS (73%); POLICE FORCES (72%); HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATIONS (71%)
TEXT: Former president of the Nigeria Bar Association, Olisa Agbakoba (SAN), in this interview with journalists, said the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) and the police have not done well in the prosecution of suspects. RAZAQ BAMIDELE brings the excerpts: You joined the defence team of your client, Mr. Seun Ogunbambo, who is standing trial for alleged subsidy fraud. Don't you think the grounds of your application to quash the case, which you referred to as "Miranda Rights" is alien to our legal system? What is Miranda Right and how does it apply in this case? Miranda rights are very applicable to Nigerians. It's a name that derives from the American decision when Miranda, a black person, was beaten to death by the police and Miranda's family brought an action against the state of Arizona and the Supreme Court decided that the Miranda right was entrenched in the fifth amendment of the American constitution. Now, in Nigeria, the origin of Miranda rights is quite old. It is traceable to the very widely known practice of the police; to beat people and extract information, which they call confessionals. When you read the report when I was the president of the Nigerian Civil Liberty Organisation (CLO), we found out that as high as 80 per cent of the people in police custody were forced to make confessions and a very sensible rule was put in place, which was called the 'judge's rule', which required the judge to ensure that a statement of an accused person has been responsibly taken at the police station and signed by a senior police officer. Now, that judge's rule is enshrined in section 35 of the constitution akin to Miranda right. All it says is that a person who is going to make a statement must receive legal advice immediately upon his arrest because it is that legal advice he receives that proves to the court that his rights have not been violated and in particular, his statement has been voluntarily made. I have studied a number of cases and in particular the one I am doing, and when I did not see the application of the Miranda rights, I said no, that is serious. It is a very serious issue and I felt it is important that the right be contested in court. No, it is not alien to Nigeria. And how can it cause more trouble for my client? No!Œæ Rather it will establish whether his statement was made voluntarily because the caution required in the statement was not contained. But has the Miranda law been argued in any Nigerian court before now? This is the first time and somebody must start something. The constitution is in the interest of Nigeria. So, I am not talking (just) to raise my voice. What is your take on the operational mode of the EFCC in handling the subsidy probe? Not just the subsidy probe; everything. I don't rate the EFCC highly in their prosecutorial methods. I know of some of my very good colleagues in the EFCC who have performed very well, and I can mention Rotimi Jacobs (SAN). But I speak generally - we are talking on whether the EFCC should be restructured. Not just the EFCC, what of the police? The police force is a disgrace. Because at least, EFCC (personnel) are lawyers, but the police are not lawyers, so the police can prosecute, and prosecuting a crime is not an easy thing because you have to understand what you are doing and you have to be trained. So, a lot goes on at the levels of law, whether EFCC or the police because they are not trained. If as a persecutor, I am reading the file brought by Mr. X and an EFCC investigating officer says this is a file I have investigated and I feel that you, the legal officer will make a charge. That is how it starts. It is the EFCC investigative side that first takes off the case; gathers all the pieces evidence and then says we think something should be done here. Do they do it? I challenge the EFCC to confirm or deny that they have a meeting where they say how many files do we have? Who is the investigating officer? You, did you check to see that all the elements that constitute murder are present? They don't do that! They just say we don't like you, put him in jail. Go and get witness from everybody. When you get it, collect and put it in proof and when you put it in the proof, take him to court. In one case in Abuja, I told the judge that my Lord, I can't read this thing. I'm entitled by Section 35 (2), to provide legal representation for my client, but if I cannot read the document, how can I do so? And I'm bringing that in this case too because they have charged the man with offences giving a bundle but when I read the bundle, they are all jumbled- disjointed- not even paginated. So, if you say the man forged something, I cannot tell where I can find it. Because in the olden days, a statement with which a man is to be charged with an offence is a sacred document. The judge reads it thoroughly. Here, how many judges read the proofs before they give consent? They just pile the files in the judge's chamber and they say what do you want? Consent? That was why Gani (Fawehinmi, SAN) challenged the principle of consent many years ago. Consent to prosecute is a serious thing. My point is that the entire chain of prosecution that begins from investigation, to prosecution, to the judge's consent is all messed up. So by the time you are in the hands of an experienced constitutional-criminal lawyer like me, they can tear it apart. So, the entire fuel subsidy crisis has not been handled well because Nigerians were very disappointed. In fact, not disappointed Nigerians were shocked to their bone marrow that this type of thing is happening. And for me, in the maritime industry, I was absolutely stunned because I never knew that this type of thing was happening. So what Nigerians seek to see is a vigorous campaign to recover the money. But I don't even know how much was stolen. I have forgotten because today they say it is this, tomorrow they say it is that. But whatever, what the EFCC should tell us now is "so much has been recovered." Don't blame defence lawyers who take advantage of EFCC's weakness. Like Seun, because Seun is entitled to the presumption of innocence, so it is you who says he has done something that should make sure that the case is respected because the matter is all being bungled, nobody has any clue about what has gone on. If I were the EFCC Chairperson, here is what I would have done; I would have written a memo to Mr. President, I would tell him, Mr. President, this is a highly specialised matter and I don't have the skills to handle it. We need to retain competent private prosecutors. Agree with their terms of engagement and go to court. That is what happens in England. In England, you have what is called the Crown Persecution Service; it is headed by the Attorney-General. It is a highly organised and proficient prosecution service.
