TITLE: Kirinyaga Governor to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); GOVERNORS (90%); WITNESSES (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (68%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Kirinyaga county governor Joseph Ndathi has said his government will take action against individuals who engage in corruption. Speaking after taking oath of office at Kutus Primary School, Ndathi said: "I do not care whether you campaigned for me or not. As a former administrator I am not going to tolerate corruption." He said he will work with everyone and told residents that the campaign period is over. Ndathi said no government employee will be intimidated in the course of discharging duty, saying politics will not be entertained in government offices. "Civil servants will not interfere with your work, so do your part as I do mine," said Ndathi. He said he will cooperate with all leaders and will soon develop a five- years strategic plan that will help the county realise its potential. Thousand of residents flocked the school compound as early as 7 am to witness the event. Kerugoya High Court judge Lady Justice Cecilia Githua administered the oath to Ndathi and his deputy Julius Njiri. Njiri thanked Kirinyaga residents for voting them in office and promised that they will not let the voters down. He said he will assist the governor in ensuring that all promises made during the campaigns are fulfilled. He said his office will address the many challenges facing the region and called for support from relevant stakeholders. Those who attended the event included former Chief Justice Evan Gicheru, Transport PSs Kibicho Karanja and Richard Ndubai PS, among other senior government officials.

TITLE: Council Loses 20 Million to Corruption Daily
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Over 20 million shillings is lost to corruption daily at the Nairobi city county. Officer in charge of integrity Daniel Masetu says most of the graft cases occur in the licensing, parking and food and hygiene departments.

TITLE: Mwea Farmer Accuses Mill of Corruption
SUBJECT: FARMERS & RANCHERS (90%); AGRICULTURE (90%); RICE FARMING (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); RICE MILLING (88%); PUBLIC FINANCE (86%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (70%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (70%) Kenya; Corruption; Agribusiness
TEXT: A rice farmer in Mwea suspects that their society officials are mismanaging money set aside by the government to offset their debt.The farmer who did not want to be named said Mwea Rice Mill Growers society has been harvesting their rice to recover their debt. However, last year Finance minister Njeru Githae gave the society money to offset the debt."Now that the debt has been paid off, the officials are trying to swindle part of the money to get back to our fields," said the farmer. He said they are unable to get bank statements from the society.Efforts to get a comment from the societies general manager were futile as he was in closed door meetings for two days. The farmer said MRGM should pay them for the extra rice they harvested as its value surpassed that of their debt.

TITLE: Cabinet List Sent to NIS, Anti-Corruption for Clearance [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (89%); BACKGROUND CHECKS (89%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); SCANDALS (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); ETHICS (72%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: PRESIDENT Uhuru Kenyatta has sent the names of his likely nominees for Cabinet to the National Intelligence Service for background checks. NIS will check with the Kenya Revenue Authority to ensure that the proposed nominees are tax compliant as well as the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission to ensure that they are not corrupt. Uhuru and Deputy President William Ruto want to prepare a list that will not have problems in Parliament when they present it for vetting. They do not want nominees to have ongoing cases or investigations related to corruption or abuse of office. Some past ministers and politicians have already been disqualified for involvement in scandals including the running of the Constituency Development Funds. "There are at least four senior politicians who were ministers in the grand coalition government that the president and the deputy president have already struck out of their initial list out of their questionable past in running of public affairs. A number of Permanent Secretaries who were to be promoted will also be shocked," a senior government official said. Speaker Justin Muturi and MPs have already warned that the National Assembly will not rubber-stamp the nominees and those on the list should be prepared for thorough vetting. Uhuru and Ruto have already prepared a list of 19 Cabinet Secretaries including six women but have eight names spare in case some of their nominees are rejected. The Constitution requires them to select a minimum of 14 Cabinet Secretaries and a maximum of 22. They are likely to announce the Cabinet nominees with some youthful and new faces on Monday, the day before Parliament reconvenes on Tuesday. "There are some names that keep on being mentioned in the media. Very many of them especially current ministers will be surprised when the list is out. They (Uhuru and Ruto) have concentrated on experience and knowledge instead of political patronage. It is a delicate balancing act," said a senior Jubilee member. Parliament will start sitting on April 16 and one of its first duties will be to set up various House committees. The Committee on Appointments will vet the nominees before presenting them for approval to the National Assembly. The Committee will also invite the public to make submissions on the nominees who will be grilled publicly on their qualifications, experience and integrity. Uhuru, 51, and Ruto, 46, have concentrated on identifying young professionals of around the same age to take up the cabinet roles as well as other positions in their offices and State House. However some of the most critical dockets such as Security and Finance will be taken up by more senior individuals with experience.

TITLE: EACC Cautions County Officials Over Corruption
SUBJECT: COUNTY GOVERNMENT (92%); CORRUPTION (92%); COUNTIES (91%); ETHICS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); MISCONDUCT (88%); RULE OF LAW (78%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: County governments have been asked to set up systems that will enhance accountability and transparency. They are to fully comply with all laws in the devolved system and seal and eliminate loopholes that may be used for corruption. Irene Keino, the vice chair of the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission said in a statement yesterday the system of devolved government is new and largely not clearly understood. "Corruption thrives where there are no systems or the systems are weak," she said. Keino warned that the commission will zealously discharge its mandate with regard to combating and preventing corruption in the public service. "No public officer, wherever serving and in whichever capacity, should regard him or herself as outside the scrutiny and grasp of the law," she said. Keino added that the commission will "swiftly and decisively" deal with any official who plunders public resources or engages in unethical conduct. "They should uphold the rule of law and constitutional requirements by paying special attention to the procurement laws and observe the same strictly in all procurements," she said. The county governments have also been urged to formulate and implement a framework for civic education and empowerment to enhance citizen participation in governance.

TITLE: Truckers Protest Mariakani 'Corruption'
SUBJECT: TRUCK DRIVERS (92%); TRUCKING WEIGH STATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); VEHICLE TRAFFIC (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (76%); LABOR UNIONS (56%) Kenya; Corruption; Transport and Shipping
TEXT: Truck drivers yesterday blocked the Mombasa-Nairobi highway at Mariakani for more than six hours. They were protesting alleged corruption at the Mariakani weighbridge. The drivers said weighbridge officials are selective in their weighing of loads. Some of the drivers blamed brokers at the weighbridge for perennial snarl-ups. The protest, which started at around 10am yesterday, caused a major traffic jam that stretched for 20km in both directions Kenya Long Distance Truck Drivers and Allied Workers Union Mombasa branch secretary Roma Waema, who rushed to the scene, said some trucks are usually deliberately delayed at the weighbridge. "If you don't 'speak their language' they will make you wait for hours or even days before they weigh your vehicle," said Waema. Muslim for Human Rights rapid response officer Francis Auma who was caught in the jam as he travelled from Nairobi was allegedly slapped by a senior officer at the weighbridge as he tried to inquire what was going on. "This is something that has been going on for quite a while but there is still no permanent solution," said Auma. Frederick Mutisya, a driver with Pema Digital Services, said overloaded trucks are usually made to wait along the highway for an opportune time to be sneaked in and out of the weighbridge unpunished. "The brokers are the people who run things at the weighbridge. They tell trucks when to pass and when not to pass. They usually wait for the big bosses to move out before they deal with the smaller officers," said Mutisya. Mombasa senator Hassan Omar said the matter was listed for discussion in the senate yesterday at 6pm. He said the traffic jams hinder businesses and may lead to major loss of business for counties using the highway especially at the Coast. Kenya National Highways Authority corporate affairs manager Charles Njogu said he was not in a position to comment on the issue when the Star contacted him yesterday. "I am not in a position to talk right now. Please allow me time to find out what is happening," he said. By the time of going to press, he was yet to get back to the Star.

TITLE: Former VP Kalonzo Warns Against 'Devolving' Corruption to Counties
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%) Kenya; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: Former Vice President Kalonzo Musyoka has warned the government against diluting the gains made by devolution. Kalonzo urged the Jubilee government to muster the political will to ensure that power and resources are devolved to the 47 counties as provided for by the constitution. He told governors to ensure that resources at their disposal are not looted through corruption. Kalonzo cited City Hall which he said is synonymous with corruption. "We are keen on devolution but we are certainly not going to condone the devolution of corruption," he said when he paid a courtesy call on Nairobi Governor Evans Kidero. The former VP urged Kidero to ensure that Nairobi City turns into a 24-hour economy. "I wish for the day that I can come to have coffee on Mama Ngina Street at midnight safely without any hitch," Klonzo said. He urged Kidero to look for money from investors to clean up Nairobi River and Athi River so people can drink and swim in them. "The stench from Nairobi Dam is unbearable while driving on Mbagathi Way, so we should see to it that it is cleaned up. I will be liaising with Governor Kidero, (Governor Alfred) Mutua of Machakos and (Kivutha) Kibwana of Makueni to thoroughly clean Athi River," Kalonzo said. Kidero said he will see to it that the devolution dream anchored in the Cord manifesto is realised.

TITLE: Corruption Always Comes With Power [opinion]
SUBJECT: APPOINTMENTS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (89%); COUNTIES (89%); CORRUPTION (83%); AGREEMENTS (74%); AUTOMOTIVE RECALLS (73%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (71%); PUBLIC FINANCE (70%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (68%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (68%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (68%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: There are many ways to judge the well-coordinated and implacable effort by our MPs to get their salaries raised back to the princely sums they were receiving before the last election. From a moral point of view, it is indefensible, that the MPs who are very well aware of the kind of poverty in which most Kenyans live, should demand salaries more befitting legislators of an advanced industrial nation. From a macroeconomic point of view, it is a storm in a teacup. Kenya may be a poor country, but a few hundred Mercedes Benzes and a few hundred MPs drawing a million shillings a month each, is not going to destroy the economy. Indeed the proposed pay cut for MPs, is very much like the initiative by President Uhuru Kenyatta when he was Finance minister, in which he had ministerial Mercedes Benzes recalled, and VW Passats offered to ministers instead. Replacing the cream of German engineering with another top-level German car was really more a token gesture than a serious policy change. So too with the reduced salaries for MPs. If there was any serious intent in reducing government expenditure, it would have to begin with the massive--and completely opaque-- expenditures of the Ministry of Defense and the Office of the President. But there is one more significant perspective in all this: the purely political perspective. And from this point of view we would ask this question: What else did you expect? For many years, Kenyans from all walks of life have been in agreement that our Presidents have far too much power. And also that this power was routinely abused. As recently as two or three years ago, and under the new constitution, we had former President Kibaki appointing "county commissioners" while knowing full well that there was no provision for any such appointments under the new constitution. And yet not only did Kibaki appoint them, but he refused to have them recalled to other duties when objections were raised. The new constitution was supposed to cure us from these excesses of presidential power, in which the imperious decrees of one man had the force of law, even when such decrees were actually in direct violation of what we knew to be in our statute books. Further, the power taken away from the presidency was supposed to be vested in various other institutions--the Judiciary, Parliament and the new county governments, in particular. But power is power, no matter who exercises it. And if power had proved to be corrosive and corrupting to the presidency, why would we imagine that it would be any less corrosive or corrupting when it was exercised by the Judiciary, Parliament or by county governors? To my mind, nothing is more natural than that the MPs, finding themselves as part of an independent institution vested with legislative powers, would seek to use their authority to increase their salaries. And that in doing so, they would have as little regard for constitutionalism as Kibaki had when he appointed all those county commissioners. We have seen successive Presidents succumb to the temptations of power and the lures of arbitrary rule. So why should we be surprised if the Judiciary or Parliament goes down the same path? Of course there are barriers in the way of these MPs: for one, the Salaries and Remuneration Commission exists precisely to thwart such moves as those recently undertaken by Parliament. And as a last resort, the SRC can take up the matter in court, and seek judicial interpretation of its powers to establish salary levels for the MPs. This clash of constitutional organs of state, contrary to popular opinion, is not a sign of national collapse. It is actually proof that the constitution is working as it is supposed to. Democracy presupposes the existence of antagonistic forces which will pull in different ways and seek opposing ends. There was never going to be peace and tranquility between the SRC and Parliament. The two organs of state were bound to clash sooner or later. And it is only appropriate that they should. When we sought to limit presidential power which was so conspicuously abused under the old constitution, we should have known that the abuse of power would not vanish, but only be assumed by other organs of state. There is a simple way of expressing this in layman's terms: Nothing in life is free. And something as important as the diminishing of presidential power, must come at a steep cost.

TITLE: Corruption Index Not Major Investor Concern - Keninvest
COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); KOREA, REPUBLIC OF (94%); LIBERIA (92%); GERMANY (90%); SUDAN (79%); ETHIOPIA (79%); NORTHERN ASIA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); TRADE DEVELOPMENT (78%); COMPUTING & IT SECTOR PERFORMANCE (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (73%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (70%); COUNTIES (66%); CONSTRUCTION (64%); TEXTILE MFG (50%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: KENYA Investment Authority has downplayed the impact the recent corruption index could have on the investors appetite but admits more needs to be done to curb the vice. A Transparency International report released on Tuesday in Berlin ranked Kenya as the fourth most corrupt country in the world after Sierra Leonne, Liberia and Yemen. Corruption is one of the key factors the World Bank considers when researching on ease of doing business in various countries. "At the moment there is so much focus on Africa and Kenya might dampen the impact of the corruption perception," said KenInvest managing director Moses Ikiara. "We need to do much more to ensure it does not persist for long to a point it begins to affect investments." Ikiara was speaking yesterday at his office after meeting a South Korean business delegation. During the meeting, the delegation which was led by South Korea ambassador to Kenya Park Sang-Hee and Member of National Assembly of the Republic of Korea Choung Byoung Gug were briefed on various ongoing project like Konza and the Lamu port and Southern Sudan-Ethiopia transport corridor (Lapsset) which they were urged to take part in. Also present were county governments of Machakos, Kisumu and Nairobi which are looking to explore the increased investment interest by South Korea in Kenya to develop their regions. Other than partnering with Kenya to fund various government projects, the South Korean delegation comprises of 16 companies looking to operate or expand their businesses drawn from agribusiness, construction, finance, textile, manufacturing and ICT sectors.

TITLE: Nyamweya Denies FKF Corruption Accusation
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); SPORTS GOVERNING BODIES (90%); SOCCER (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); COUNTERFEITING (77%); SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (73%); SPORTS SPONSORSHIP (73%); SPORTS & RECREATION (73%); SOCCER TOURNAMENTS (73%); ELECTRONIC MAIL (53%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A group of suspended Football Kenya Federation officials yesterday presented to the anti-corruption commission what they said is evidence of corruption and mismanagement in the organisation. Secretary general Sam Nyamweya in a swift rejoinder dismissed the documents as fake and denied any wrongdoing. "Football Kenya Federation wishes to inform all our football stakeholders that it has come to our attention that some suspended football officials have been hopping from office to office armed with fake documents," Nyamweya said in a statement. "These documents include bank statements purported to have been issued by our bankers. We wish to inform you all that the federation, after perusing the documents established that they are not authentic and has therefore referred the matter to the anti-fraud unit" FKF national committee member Hussein Swaleh Hussein handed over the documents that include the federation's bank statements, letters written to world soccer governing body Fifa, email communications, minutes of meetings and the organisation's annual report. EACC confirmed it has received the documents and has launched investigations. Unconfirmed reports however said sponsors of various soccer tournaments including Coca Cola and Tusker have asked for an audit of their money. Nyamweya said officials suspended for gross violation of rules governing football have ganged up against him and other officials with the aim of discrediting the gains made by FKF. Hussein said since 2011, there has been non disclosure of "colossal amounts of money" sent to FKF from Fifa, the Confederation of African Football and other sources.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Officer Arrested
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ARRESTS (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); ASSAULT & BATTERY (86%); SEXUAL ASSAULT (86%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Conflict, Peace and Security
TEXT: RUIRU: Police officers on Sunday arrested an anti-corruption officer for creating disturbance at Ruiru Police Station . Charles Sirengo Samiji allegedly insulted the officers. Ruiru police boss Isaac Thuranira said Samiji went to the station at 10.30 am and told the officers that they are corrupt, illiterate and unfit for promotion. Thuranira said the Samiji harassed and indecently assaulted a female officer by touching. The police boss said the anti-corruption officer who was drank grabbed the occurrence book and destroyed it. He was arrested for undermining the authority of a public officer and creating disturbance in a manner likely to cause bleach of peace. Thuranira said the suspect will be charged in court later.

TITLE: AGOA Seeks Long-Term Extension - Watching Corruption
SUBJECT: EXPORT TRADE (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (89%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (89%); EMERGING MARKETS (79%); INDUSTRY SECTOR PERFORMANCE (78%); AGREEMENTS (78%); JOB CREATION (77%); COMMERCE DEPARTMENTS (77%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (76%); SPECIAL ECONOMIC ZONES (76%); TRADE DEVELOPMENT (76%); EXPORT PROMOTION (75%); EMPLOYMENT GROWTH (73%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (72%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (71%); TAXES & TAXATION (71%); HUMAN RIGHTS (61%) Kenya; Corruption; AGOA
TEXT: Kenya continues to benefit from the African Growth and Opportunity Act, but as the bill seeks long-term extensions widespread corruption will be scrutinized. "Part of our ongoing conversation with Kenya is addressing a host of issues in the business environment," says David Renz, a counselor for Economic Affairs at the US Embassy Nairobi. "We are closely watching the commitments of the Kenyatta administration for addressing corruption." AGOA, a US bill lowering tariffs for African exports, began in 2000 with a proposed lifespan of fifteen years. Since its inception, trade has increased from $2.6 billion to $22.6 billion in 2012. In 2012, Kenya exported $380 million worth of goods under AGOA. In the Export Processing Zones, where 25,000 people are employed, exports contributed $262 million. An AGOA forum will be held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia between August 12 and 13. The US will aim to extend the agreement for 15 to 20 years. There are two main reasons an extension is being sought. First, many African products cannot compete in American markets. This remains a reality in Kenya. "AGOA has provided incentives for economic growth in the formal sector, where Kenya is trying to create jobs," says Renz, "But, we still have to have a product that meets market needs in the US and is manufactured at a competitive price." Several roadblocks for Kenyan production costs include transportation issues and the price of electricity. The second reason concerns Africa's fast growing economies and Obama's focus on the region. "It's no secret that the president views Africa as a key place," said John Anderson, an assistant secretary in the US department of commerce. "We want to take advantage of the opportunities during the promising future the continent is poised to have." AGOA is currently eligible to 39 African countries, under strict compliance rules. Each year, countries are assessed on their governance and human rights records. Numerous African countries, as a result, have been barred from trading. This year, Kenya's widely reported corruption will be under the microscope. "If there is corruption that is rampant, we will go in and talk to them about it," says Florizelle Liser, the assistant US Trade Representative for Africa. The bill's extension is being debated in congress this week. Many are confident it will pass. "We are very, very focused on what we have to do with congress and AGOA stakeholders," says Liser.

TITLE: Can Rule of Reason Save Kenya From the Arms of Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL SCIENCE (90%); PHILOSOPHY (90%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (90%); POLITICS (87%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (85%); CLASSICS (77%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (74%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (67%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: To have the rule of reason however, we must have leaders who are not afraid or too lazy to think, reason, read in search of knowledge and solve problems. Without eyes of knowledge, a leader and his people will be blind. I have been re-reading my Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Mahatma Gandhi, Niccolo Machiavelli, Sigmund Freud, Karl Marx and any other philosopher I think can help me answer questions on why Kenya is rotting so fast and what we must do to save ourselves. In the journey of my mind, I have stumbled upon another question: If rule of reason has saved others elsewhere, can it save Kenya. To transform ancient Athens, which mistakenly called itself a democracy, the great philosopher Plato said, Athens the city of corruption needed the rule of reason for her salvation. Like Plato, I believe Kenya whose corporate corruption has been rated number one in the world and mistakenly also calls itself a democracy, also needs the rule of reason to liberate herself from the iron arms of the octopus of corruption, poverty, negative ethnicity, unemployment, fear and desperation, depressions and suicide, insanity, recklessness, beastliness and death wish. Plato called for the rule of reason because he believed, though Hindu philosophers accused politics of corruption, as long as people were neither gods nor beasts, they would remain political animals and through political philosophers armed with power of knowledge of science of politics, power could be exercised wisely and incorruptly for the good of society. How could men then construct rule of reason that did not corrupt them? Plato thought human nature was such that men had three faculties - replicable in a civil state - of reason by philosopher rulers, courage of soldiers, appetite or greed of farmers and men of commerce. Here in Kenya, the Kikuyu thought like the Greeks. The country belonged to the man of wisdom - muthamaki, the man of courage - njamba and the man of wealth - gitonga. The masses lived in the country they did not own. In this pre-colonial society, power was not given to the warrior or rich man but to the man of reason. Unfortunately today, power is not entrusted to the ruler of reason. It is sold by voters and bought by the rich man and later bequeathed to his children. After buying leadership, the rich man uses resources of the state for self enrichment and protection by the man of courage. Kenya is not led by reason of the philosopher president or by the soldier. It is led by the appetite and greed of the rich man - the capitalist. Under the rule of appetite and greed, problems of society grow worse by the day. As in ancient Athens, corruption is king. We no longer suffer shame for corruption. Graft has eaten into democracy and left a mere shell of it. As ideology of hate pitted Athens against Spartan, negative ethnicity also pits community against community. As corruption engenders the wealth of the rich, equally, it engenders mental and material poverty of the poor. As we watch, insanity grips society while gun and greed reduce society to a jungle of carnivores and herbivores. We are self-destructing and rule of reason must save us with the science of politics as well as engineering, medicine, mathematics, chemistry and physics. To have the rule of reason however, we must have leaders who are not afraid or too lazy to think, reason, read in search of knowledge and solve problems. Without eyes of knowledge, a leader and his people will be blind. Rule of reason is impossible without a renaissance and an age of reason. Already we have lost an entire jubilee of missed opportunity to think out our development. And we shall lose another jubilee of reason if we don't end leadership of wealth instead of ideas, knowledge and wisdom. If we shall self-liberate, we must read and seek knowledge like mad. Rule of reason is impossible where leadership is sold by voters and bought by men and women of appetite and greed or taken with guns by soldiers. Finally, rule of reason cannot germinate in the soil of hunger or intellectual poverty because starvation kills thought and reason. To foster reason, we must read but our reading culture is dead with mobile phones taking the place of books. If 29 per cent of Kenyans live by superstition, more than 11 million hardly reason or think and will not welcome the rule of reason. In 'The Brothers Karamazov', novel by Fydol Dostoevsky of Russia, the Grand Inquisitor argues that Christianity captures its unthinking flock with miracles, mystic and authority, instruments of perfect unreason against freedom. As deadly brew kills minds of the youth, more deadly opium of negative ethnicity keeps Kenyan communities at each other's throat. Unfortunately, it is easier not to think and steal, than think and work. And as reasoning and thinking were subversive to elders of Athens who condemned Socrates to die by drinking hemlock, many in Kenyan government would today also condemn a true thinker and pursuer of truth to death and use every trick to draw people from thinking. Not to kill another Socrates or Jesus, we must have rule of reason. Sadly, Kenyans are driven by appetite and greed, not by pursuit of truth, excellence, goodness, justice and morality. This is why our society is rotting, retrogressing, dying collectively and our problems getting worse.

TITLE: Shollei Says Corruption Allegations Untrue
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (89%); APPELLATE DECISIONS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); SUBCONTRACTING (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); RELOCATIONS (72%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (72%); RECRUITMENT & HIRING (68%); APPEALS COURTS (64%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Chief Deputy Registrar of the Judiciary Gladys Shollei has appeared before the legal and Justice Affairs Committee today to discuss issues surrounding her 15 day suspension from office by the Judicial Service Commission. The JSC suspended Shollei on Monday to pave way for investigations into corruption allegations made against the her. While fielding questions on members of the JSC who she may have issues with, Shollei confirmed that she has had issues with commissioner's Ahmednassir, Ominde and Warsame whom she accused of frustrating her work. She said Commissioner Ominde has "fought her from the very beginning". She said she has had to write several letters to Chief Justice Willy Mutunga asking the CJ to explain her role in relation to Ominde's. She stated that she answers to the full JSC and not individual commissioners. She further stated that Commissioner Warsame had "taunted me about hiring people" claiming that on several occasion Warsame remarked that her predecessor hired "upto 30 people for him." Shollei further said she is yet to receive any information about the charges against her or the reasons that members of the JSC decided to send her on compulsory leave following a vote of 5-4 in favour of the proposal. Adding that she is yet to see the minutes of the meeting held over the weekend Shollei also sought to clarify issues touching on the purchase of buildings and other materials acquired by the Judiciary. She told the committee that contrary to allegations the judiciary has not purchased any building in Mombasa as reported. She said lawyers had complained over the Court of Appeal being located in Malindi, but she explained that the building was purchased before her tenure. She said she has been working on implementing the Judiciary's policy to relocate the court to Mombasa. She said the Judiciary is still scouting for a suitable building to house the court stating that she has received an offer from the Postal cooperation and has written a letter to the organization to ascertain whether there building is suitable and whether the corporation is a government body adding that she is yet to receive a response from the cooperation. On the issue of constructions at the Milimani Commercial Courts, Shollei said that during her tenure she received complaints about the building over issues such as substandard internet and telephone connectivity as well as problems with the ceiling which was reportedly about to cave in. She said she convened a meeting of the subcontractors working on the building after which they agreed they had not completed work on the building and agreed to correct the error with no additional cost to the Judiciary. She further stated that additional work at the Courts cost Sh230 million and not Sh1 billion as alleged. The Chief Registrar of the Judiciary also confirmed that vehicles have been purchased for newly recruited Judges stating that it was the policy of the Judiciary to purchase Mercedes Benz for judges. On the leasing of office premises, Shollei said the Judiciary is renting new premises as the Supreme Court cannot house the 30 judges currently operating in the court. She said the Judiciary is following a six year plan in which they will rent premises for the first year but by the six year would have purchased a new building. She added that the Supreme Court is also currently undergoing renovations which greatly required as it was first built in 1930. She said the JSC has been furnished with all the information on the projects. Shollei said she has refused to say anything in camera saying that she has nothing to hide. Shollei further said the accusations about her being militant are true stating that "Yes I do not apologize about it." She said her style of management is only not acceptable when its a woman.

TITLE: Corruption Seen As Biggest Threat to Devolution - Report
SUBJECT: COUNTIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (89%); POLLS & SURVEYS (77%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Transparency International TI Executive Director Samuel Mbithi address the media during the launch if the health integrity study at Nairobi Safari club. Kenyans are split on whether the government is committed to devolution, a report by Transparency International suggests. Of the 1,766 surveyed in the report 51.8 per cent felt that the government is committed to devolution with 72.7 per cent saying the disbursement of funds to counties is a show of the this commitment. This reason was also rated most highly by the 48.2 per cent who felt that the national government is not committed to the process by 42.7 per cent. A further 42.2 per cent said that the central government is still interfering with county affairs. Corruption was rated as the largest threats to devolution by responded with 35. 9 per cent saying this is the biggest threat. Lack of adequate funds was also rated as a possible threat with 21.5 per cent , followed by political interferences at 20.5 per cent and supremacy wrangles within the county and central government by 18.3 per cent Majority of the respondents, 43.7 per cent are also satisfied with the performance of county governments. However a larger majority of 83 per cent said they had no knowledge of how funds have been allocated to their respective counties. Majority, 56 per cent also did not know where to get information on funds allocation. The report also reveals that even though majority believed priorities of the national government were good, 37.1 per cent of them viewed them as unrealistic as compared to only 30.5 per cent respondents who thought county governments' priorities were unrealistic. Further, about a sixth of the respondents view the development priorities to be out of touch with the needs of citizens at both county and national level. Launching the report, Transparency International Kenya (TI-Kenya's) Executive Director Mr. Samuel Kimeu noted that citizens' views on the national and county governments' priorities could be a pointer to the governments to revisit campaign priorities and to align them with what the people identify as real and urgent needs through paying fidelity to the participatory planning process enshrined in law. "The public response to our poll is indicative of the lack of peoples' voice in the setting of development priorities." Said Mr Kimeu Kimeu cautioned that if corruption goes unchecked, it will undermine the developmental aspirations of Kenyans at both levels of government. "Merely lamenting about widespread corruption will never address the scourge. Being responsible and well informed citizens, it is our duty to our nation and future generations to take individual and collective steps to stop corruption in our society. " The judiciary was seen as the most trusted institution in driving the anti-corruption agenda with close to 30 per cent respondents supporting this assertion. The confidence in the civil society and EACC stood at 20 per cent and 17 per cent respectively The survey was conducted across 31 counties and eight regions. Across the regions, Rift Valley accounted for the largest number of respondents with about 28 per cent of the total while North Eastern accounted for the lowest number at 4.1 per cent respondents. The survey respondents were mainly between 18-49 year olds with an almost equal split between 18-29 and 30-49 years age brackets. Only 10 per cent of the sample was picked from Kenyans above 50 years. According to Transparency International the two demographic groups were purposely sampled as a reflection of the national population. The organization said that this group is also likely to be more impacted by success or otherwise of such critical issues like improved governance into the future.

TITLE: Transparency International Launches Report On Corruption in Education.
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); EDUCATION FUNDING (73%) Kenya; Corruption; Education
TEXT: Transparency International in a new report shows says stepping up the fight against corruption in education is necessary not only to keep children in school and meet literacy and development goals, but also to ensure that the next generation is prepared to say no to corruption. According to the organization's Global Corruption Report,in order to prevent corruption from becoming commonplace, promoting integrity among young people is critical to building a better future. This report seeks to shed light on the many shapes and forms of corrupt practices in education, be they the embezzlement of national education funds, hidden school costs or the buying and selling of fake degrees. Huguette Labelle, Chair of Transparency International emphasizes on the need to sensitize and create awareness for the young people on corruption: "For schools to educate the corruption fighters of tomorrow they need to be free from corruption themselves. Without a strong dose of integrity, our schools and universities will fail to provide future leaders with the basic tools needed to succeed, and more importantly, to combat graft. With nearly a fifth of the world's population between 15 and 24 years old, young people have the potential to stop corruption both as the citizens of today and as the leaders of tomorrow." Labelle said

TITLE: Mining Audit Shows Massive Corruption
SUBJECT: MINERAL LEASES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LICENSES & PERMITS (90%); MINING REGULATION & POLICY (90%); MINING & EXTRACTION RIGHTS & ROYALTIES (90%); PROSPECTING & EXPLORATION (89%); MINES & MINING (78%); AUDITS (78%); LAWYERS (70%); CORRUPTION (70%) Kenya; Mining; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: SOME of the companies issued with mining licenses earlier this year had not even been registered and had no business name, an investigative report has disclosed. The interim report by the task force set up in August by Mining Cabinet Secretary Najib Balala to look into issuance of licenses issued this year revealed massive irregularities. "In some instances, licences were issued to entities that at the time of application for the said licences were not incorporated and neither possessed a certificate of incorporation nor a business name registration," stated the report. "Some licences were issued even though financial capability was not demonstrated by the applicant and in some instances no financial documents are supporting the documents as required by law." In August, Balala ordered for a review of all the licenses issued from January and cancelled 43 licenses that were issued from March noting that the rush to issue licenses during the transition period when a new government was taking over was very suspicious. He said it was questionable the way some individuals had been issued with mining licenses yet their exploration and financial capability was not clear. Out of the 43 companies whose licenses were revoked by Balala, the report said only 28 out of these had fully received their licenses with the rest being at various stages of consideration for different types of licenses, the report said. The task force investigating the matter found that in some cases, the law was blatantly flouted. "Whereas possession of a valid prospecting right is a requirement for the issuance of exclusive prospecting licences (EPLs) and special licences, some licences were issued where the applicants did not have valid PRs," said the report. The task force which is chaired by lawyer Mohamed Nyaoga is supposed to issue a complete report within 60 days after its setup and will also be required to recommend measures for developing processes and institutions to effectively comply with the licensing procedures. After reviewing licenses for this year, Balala, who eyes overhaul of the entire mining sector, said he will ask the task force to start investigations into the other licenses issued between 2003 to end 2012.

TITLE: Corruption Has Finally Arrived At the Mara [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPING (89%); TRAVEL  HOSPITALITY & TOURISM (74%); MOVIE FILMING (70%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Corruption is indeed contagious. When it happens in one sector, it soon spreads and infects even those who seem immune to it. Yours truly has pointed out from time to time, the rot in some parks, and especially the Maasai Mara reserve. In most cases, it has been a question of bad roads, bribes to the authorities to overlook a driver coming home late from game drive, or bribing to be allowed to off-road, especially those who deal with commercial documentary filming. One would see some foreign registered vehicles with a sign at the back reading "do not follow off-road" and posing as filming crew but turns out to be a normal tourist on a self-drive safari but who happened to know how Kenyan operates. So to say, corruption in the bush had been, for a long time, something we can bear. Not anymore. Having been quiet for a long time, the security guys posted to man different areas in Mara, are literally running after the disappearing dollars. They do not even hide their act. They do it in full daylight and with little regard that a client may be be able to recognise them in case there is a call for identification parade. They know they are 'covered'. I was in Mara last week. I chose to be on the Mara conservancy side since I have always felt that this part of Mara has more sanity in its operations. I had begun my game drive as early as 6am. The purpose of the early bird wake up time, was to have time to see the sunrise and still be able to cross the mara bridge in time to chance a crossing from the conservancy side. At the Mara bridge, the process of verification of the tickets went on smoothly, as I had anticipated. They are still on the modified digitalised payment method while the Narok side of the divide has moved back to the hand written ticketing despite having moved with time and introduced the card system. It cannot be said that the card system was wrong. Just the spoon getting smaller. Into the game drive, the time for a short stop by the river to have coffee, was calling. As has been my preference for all times, I chose a well-established campsite to offload the clients and chose a spot to lay the table. Just as I was removing my camping chairs, I heard a movement in the thickets that surround the campsite. A Land Rover was approaching. When it finally arrived, a lone tourist came out, followed by a uniformed guard, who was carrying a gun. Without even introducing himself, he proceeded to where I was setting out the table and asked me why I was endangering my clients by having them come out of the van at such a hidden spot. He was speaking in English, to make sure that my clients understood what he was saying and maybe side with him. What he did not know was that my clients were here for an umpteenth time, and had used the same spot for breakfast on countless occasions over the years. He also did not know that, that was an old school trick to scare the clients in order to minimize bargaining when he mentions his real intention of the abrupt interruption of our tea break. The rules were all written on his face and his tone said it all. No bargain. Drive to the bridge and pay the fine of Sh10000, or share "chai" and save the valuable time for game drive. Just then, we heard the noises of water splashing violently close to where we were. Wildebeests were crossing. A quick calculation went through my head. Since there was no bargain, I could also benefit a little from his presence. I gave him my clients, to escort them to where the crossing was happening, on foot. It was going to be a new experience for them, and my money was not going to be in vain. One thing was clear though. The rot had finally caught up with Mr Brian of the Mara conservancy. I know he has nothing to do with the process of posting the GSU at the Mara bridge, but let him be informed that the disease is now at his backyard.

TITLE: Kiambu Coffee Society Closed Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); AGRICULTURE (90%); COFFEE (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); CLOSINGS (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); AGRICULTURAL CHEMICALS (74%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (74%); CORN FARMING (73%); APPOINTMENTS (72%); FERTILIZERS (69%) Kenya; Corruption; Agribusiness; Company News
TEXT: THE Komothai Coffee Cooperative Society has been closed. The co-op was closed indefinitely during a special general meeting at its office in Komothai Ward, Githunguri on Saturday. Members blamed the closure on poor management, corruption and the government's laxity in prosecuting incriminated officials for the past 10 years. They accused county cooperative commissioner Ephraim Mathenge of colluding with officials to steal from the society. The members said they have lost Sh25 million and the society owes the Cooperative Bank Sh52 million. "The society's workers have not been paid for the past four months. That is why we are giving the government three months to investigate where Sh10 million and another Sh15 million it gave to the society for fertiliser was taken," said Rebecca Wairimu Njihia. "Years back our families benefited greatly from coffee. Now it would be better to close this society, uproot the crop and start farming maize instead. We don't want to be told of borrowing power which has seen us have a debt of Sh52 million." The members said the society's marketer has been depriving the farmers of coffee. "He should be appointed in consultation with farmers not by the board which works in cahoots with them to steal from us," said John Mburu. "We used to give loans to the government in 1967. We used to produce 16 million tonnes of coffee. We are now producing 17, 000. The officials are corrupt and they never release accounts to us for perusal." Kiambu Deputy Governor Gerald Githinji said a fresh election should be done on Friday and police directed to seize all the book keeping records. "The farmers have said that they don't want the officials elected a few months ago," he said.

TITLE: Uhuru and Ruto Have No Political Will to Eradicate Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); DISEASES & DISORDERS (90%); LARCENY & THEFT (87%); CHILDREN (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (69%); TERRORISM (64%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Though founding fathers did not list corruption together with poverty, disease and ignorance as our leading problems, since the Kenyatta regime became notorious for grabbing public land and other properties, graft has been identified as a problem to solve to advance economically, socially and politically. In Kenya, research surveys continue to show corruption as an integral part of our daily pains, a problem over which we have no power. Though corruption eats into our soul every day, reducing our ability to reject it, we cannot surrender and must as often as possible take a position against it. At the very least, this will make us cleaner people. Even though we may disbelieve, it reassures every time President Uhuru Kenyatta announces his intention to fight corruption, important because no war against corruption can succeed unless the president leads it. However, it is my considered view that Kenyans should not place too much hope on President Uhuru ending corruption since neither him nor Ruto are ideological foes of corruption. Most of our problems stem from corruption because it distorts our economy from solving to creating problems. In short, corruption means stealing from others and gearing our thoughts and activities to actualising theft. Corruption also makes enemies of all those who will steal from one another. Other than creating poverty, anger and enemies, corruption also makes government and country private property of leaders; takes food from the mouths of babies; kills the sick in hospitals, lets in terrorists to kill; allows defective vehicles onto our roads to kill thousands; allows criminals to steal hundreds of billions from government coffers; kills youth with drugs and alcohol; sells leadership to thieves and bars persons of integrity from leadership. President Uhuru and Deputy President Ruto cannot eliminate corruption because they believe in capitalism, the mother of graft and the ideology of greed. Corruption in Kenya is everywhere, polluting the soul of every individual and every institution. It is in government, in schools, in the police, on roads, in hospitals, in media, in churches, everywhere. We wrongly believe fighting corruption only means arresting and jailing corrupt people. The harder part is teaching the entire country the ideals and taboos of fighting graft. As in fighting disease, in fighting graft, prevention is better than cure. Many doubt President Uhuru's intention to wage war against corruption because, in a country flooded by corruption, we see no casualties paraded in courts for corruption, we hear no protestations against arrest and prosecution, and there are no anticorruption campaigns in our cities, towns, villages, schools, churches, radios and televisions. Corruption cannot be fought in silence. President Uhuru has power and enjoys goodwill to fight corruption. But to fight graft he needs more than power. He needs own reasons to declare war against graft, political will to fight and total conviction that corruption is his personal enemy. Yet to regard corruption as a personal enemy, graft need to have hurt President Uhuru at a personal level. Has it? If Uhuru and Ruto have benefited more from graft than they have been hurt by it, their war against graft will be stillborn. To realise difficulties of fighting corruption we need to acknowledge its various tentacles. Most fundamental is corruption inherent in capitalism, our economic system or socialism gone mad. Where there is corruption of the system, fighting it will require revolutionary efforts. But if our leaders believe in capitalism, they cannot fight it and profit from the system. Corruption is very difficult to fight when it is founded on greed, the ideology of capitalism that we don't currently question - theft is fair, exploitation is smart and loot is legitimate. It is fair for a smart thief to keep his loot if he is uncaught. If President Uhuru and Deputy President Ruto have decided to fight graft, they will find it easier to fight petty than grand corruption. After all, petty thieves will not come from their class. President Uhuru might even believe that old graft no longer smells and may no longer need fighting like raw corruption which still smells foul. But logic will dictate equality of treatment between old and new graft. If Uhuru and Ruto benefited from old graft, fighting new graft will be impossible. Experience also teaches that fighting the corruption of other people from other places and communities is easier than fighting corruption of our family members, friends and ethnic communities. Ultimately the most difficult corruption is graft that has captured power and is in government. It will use government resources to defend itself. It is lack of ideological capacity and political will that researched and investigated corruption as reported in Controller and Auditor General, Ndung'u Report, Transparency International and TJRC has not been prosecuted by various Kenyan governments including this one of Uhuru and Ruto. Kenyan corruption has progressed in quantity and quality and no longer cares about life. Like mafia, it kills those who will expose or wish to eradicate it. The worst is our moral corruption that kills soul of the nation and individuals we read about everyday killing spouses and children in homes and often, uncaring drivers and travelers on our roads. Kenyan corruption has grown intractable because it does not fight alone. It is has allies in negative ethnicity that will protect "own" graft and political leaders who resort to corruption to win elections.

TITLE: Governor Jama Warns Garissa County Staff Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); EXECUTIVES (90%); COUNTIES (90%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); QURAN & ISLAMIC TEXTS (69%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: GARISSA Governor Nadhif Jama Adam has warned county officials against corruption. Speaking during the swearing-in ceremony of county chief officers yesterday, Jama said public officers should follow the law and provide services to residents instead of enriching themselves. "You have not been appointed to benefit as an individual but to work for the community at large," said the governor. Jama told the chief officers that they are the principle accounting officers of their respective departments responsible for all maters including finances. "It is a big responsibility on our shoulders and we will be accountable even before God," he said while quoting verses from the Quran. He told the officers to serve the public equally without fear or favour. "I will not entertain any form of mismanagement of public funds by any individual. I don't engage myself in corruption and so I expect the same from you. Those caught will face the full force of the law," Jama said. He said since his administration is complete major development projects will soon be unveiled. Jama had just arrived from a month long overseas' trip where he secured major investors, who are expected to attend a county investors' forum in January. The chief officers who were sworn-in yesterday include Jawahir Keinan who take charge of Youth, Polytechnic and Sport docket, Mohamed Daud Abdi (Lands, Housing Development and Public Works), Mohamed Hassan Mohamed (Infrastructure and Transport), Rahma Dekow Omar (Inter-Governmental and Institutional Relations), Fatuma Omar Sheikh (Environment, Tourism and Energy) and Dr Sofia Mohamed Ahmed will be responsible for the crucial Health docket.

TITLE: Governors Told to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (81%) Kenya; Corruption

TITLE: Kenya's Score Against Corruption Dissapointingly Low - TI
COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); AFRICA (92%); SUDAN (90%); SOMALIA (90%); BOTSWANA (76%); AFGHANISTAN (51%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); RANKINGS (90%); FREEDOM OF INFORMATION (73%); INVESTIGATIONS (70%) Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Kenya's score for the reduction corruption in the country remains disappointingly low. This is according to a Corruption Perception Index by Transparency International released today. Out of 177 countries and territories surveyed, Kenya was ranked at position 136, with a score of 26 on a scale of 1 to 100, where 0 is highly corrupt. "Kenya's score has remained disappointingly low and stagnant over a long period of time. Evidently whatever efforts that have been put into the fight against corruption have borne little results. A new impetus and approach to this issue is required," said Samuel Kimeu, Executive Director of TI Kenya. Botswana retained its title as the highly ranked African country at position 30 with a score of 64 and Somalia was ranked last at position 174 with a score of 8. Only 6 out of 55 African countries ranked scored above 50 indicating a corruption problem in the continent. "Africa fares badly in our view because of the opacity that afflicts public affairs. It is worth noting that few countries have effective access to information laws and free media. The solution is greater transparency and empowering of the public to ensure accountability of public officials and institutions," said Kimeu. According to Transparency International Kenya, corruption within the public sector remains a big challenge, not only in Kenya, but also globally and that public institutions need to be more open about their work and officials must be more transparent in their decision-making. Corruption remains notoriously difficult to investigate and prosecute. In the category of the least corrupt Denmark and New Zealand tie in first place with scores of 91. The two were followed by Finland (89), Sweden (89), Norway (85) and Singapore (85) complete the first five positions respectively. South Sudan (14), Sudan (11), Afghanistan (8), Korea (North) (8) and Somalia (8) are the five countries placed at the bottom of the index. "The top performers clearly reveal how transparency supports accountability and can stop corruption," said Huguette Labelle, Chair of Transparency International.

TITLE: Ex-Ps Mwangi Faces Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (90%); MAGISTRATES (90%); REAL ESTATE (87%); APPROVALS (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (71%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Governance
TEXT: FORMER Foreign Affairs PS Thuita Mwangi and two ministry officials were yesterday charged with corruption over the Tokyo embassy scandal. Mwangi, Anthony Mwaniki and Allan Mburu an employee at the embassy, denied the charges before anti-corruption magistrate Doreen Mulekyo. The three are accused of approving the purchase of a property in Tokyo for the Kenya Embassy and ambassador's residence at Sh1.07 billion when they could have got a fair market price if they adhered to proper procurement procedures. They were charged with failing to comply with the law and procedures relating to procurement of real estate property by directly purchasing the Tokyo property. They have also been accused of using their offices to improperly give Sh297 million to Nobuo Kuriyama for the the property. Allan Mburu faced another count of signing a contract for the purchase of the Tokyo property without authority. Mwangi had moved to the High Court to stop his prosecution at the magistrates court. However, Justice David Majanja ruled that Mwangi failed to prove that DPP Keriako Tobiko acted beyond his powers or departed from the rules of natural justice in ordering their prosecution.

TITLE: Uhuru Pledges to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ETHICS (78%); EMERGING MARKETS (78%); JOB CREATION (77%); HOTELS & MOTELS (77%); LABOR SECTOR PERFORMANCE (77%); ANNIVERSARIES (77%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (74%); EXECUTIVES (74%); TRADE DEVELOPMENT (74%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (73%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); EMPLOYMENT (73%); LOBBYING (72%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (67%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: PRESIDENT Uhuru Kenyatta has pledged to fight corruption in all sectors to make the country attractive to investors. Speaking during Kenya Private Sector Alliance luncheon to mark its 10th anniversary at Safari Park hotel on Saturday, Uhuru said his government is keen on ensuring good governance and integrity in the job market. "With this, we shall ensure proper work ethics, something that will no doubt attract more private investors in the market. My government will deal with corruption in all sectors as we aim to achieve this," the president said. Kepsa chief executive Carole Kariuki said that the alliance will re-engineer its efforts to also boost retention of investments and not just attracting them into the country. "We are also looking forward to support national development through economic growth and employment creation. And lastly, we aim to support our members through business growth among themselves and the government," said Kariuki. Kepsa is a lobby group made of various business associations that advocates on behalf of various sectors, conducts projects and partnerships locally and internationally to boost trade and engages the government through talks on some policy issues regarding the economy before implementation. "This marks a momentous point in the life of KEPSA. This is a time to celebrate, refresh and re-engineer for a more impactful time ahead," said Kepsa chairman Vimal Shah. Corruption has been one of the main issues raised by the World Bank in its report on ease of doing business in Kenya. Kenya dropped in ranking by eight positions in the doing business report for 2013 to stand at position 129 for failure to implement some regulation reforms. Kenya has been dropping in rank for the last four years. The private sector has been complaining that bureaucracy in government offices has bred corruption which has increased the cost of doing business in the country. "Let me once again assure you of my government's commitment to support the private sector, as promised in our meeting in May this year," Uhuru said. He added: "We will continue with the spirit initiated by the former government to ensure peace and an enabling business environment is maintained throughout the country to allowbusiness to thrive."

TITLE: EACC Investigates Laikipa County Govt Corruption Allegations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); GOVERNORS (91%); ETHICS (90%); ELECTIONS (90%); BUILDING RENOVATION (90%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (90%); COUNTIES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CONTRACT AWARDS (90%); WATER & SEWER SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CONSTRUCTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); INTERNAL AUDITS (89%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (89%); GAS STATIONS (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); AUDITS (89%); BUDGETS (85%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); AGREEMENTS (78%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (77%); ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS (76%); TECHNICIANS & TECHNOLOGICAL WORKERS (75%); CITIES (69%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The Ethics and Anti Corruption Commission has initiated investigations into the alleged fraud at the Laikipia county Governor's office. This is after after the commission received a letter from the Transition Authority following complaints. The EACC is specifically investigating the payment of Sh3,225,965 to Oritere Builders and Construction Company Limited for the Governor's office renovation and construction at Kinamba. The EACC is probing claims the company was irregularly awarded the contract shortly before the elections. It is alleged that Oritere Builders is associated with the driver of a senior employee of the Laikipia county government. EACC is investigating allegations that the Laikipia County government officials purported to have awarded a tender to renovate the Kinamba governor's office to Oritere Builders and Construction Company associated with senior county officials days before governors were elected and when such tenders had been stopped by the then Secretary to the Cabinet and Head of Civil Service Francis Kimemia. The investigators are trying to establish how Oritere Builders were awarded the tender for renovation of office, construction of public toilet, governors, toilet, installation of electricity/wiring, installation of water tank and leveling of parking two moths before the historic General Election that saw the forty seven governors elected for the first time in the country. The tender was allegedly awarded on February 5 2013 after the Transition Authority stopped any such transactions by County, Municipal and City councils. Oritere Builders and Construction company wrote their acceptance letter on February 8 2013 to the Town Council of Rumuruti. According to County Government internal audit report sent to the EACC and Transitional Authority, there was no contract documents was given for the renovation and repairs to the governor's office in Kinamaba nor were architectural designs provided. The internal audit report says that the Engineers Estimates document provided was signed, stamped and dated October 24 2012 and there was no correlation between Engineer's estimate and the BQ provided. "We have carried out an investigation on allegation of misuse of public funds at Kinamba budget petrol station renovation and repairs of governor's office at Kinamba as directed by you vide letter referenced CGL/CA/PAC/34/1 of date 28th June 2013. We have also carried an assessment on extent of achievement of value for money," the internal audit report by the county internal audit team reads in part. There were no bids provided for the tender and neither was any retention money held as provided in such contracts. EACC is also investigating allegations that the governor procured eight Ford vehicle for county executives without following the procurement procedures. In relation to Fuel Consumption by Laikipia County government vehicles at the Kinamba Budget petrol station, the internal audit reports indicates that there was no contract but instead it was a gentleman's agreement between the governor and the petrol station owner breaching the Public Procurement Oversight Authority regulations. It was also established that there were no LPO's, requisition, fuel register, or detailed orders and delivery notes to monitor the fuel consumption by the government. Efforts to get a comment from the Laikipia Governor Joshua Irungu were fruitless as he did not reply to an SMS sent to him.

TITLE: Judiciary Riddem By Corruption Transparency Survey Shows
COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); EASTERN AFRICA (94%); AFRICA (94%); RWANDA (92%); UGANDA (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%); BURUNDI (79%)
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (97%); CORRUPTION (91%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); ANNUAL REPORTS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); ETHICS (77%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (75%); POLICE FORCES (75%); HOTELS & MOTELS (55%) Kenya; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: TRANSPARENCY International has released East Africa Bribery Index survey report that they did since August 2012 to August 2013 ranking Kenya number four out of five countries worse hit by bribery and corruption. Worst East African countries involved in bribery and corruption cases are: Uganda with 26.8 per cent, Burundi 18.6 per cent, Tanzania 12.9 per cent, Kenya number 4 with 7.9 per cent and then Rwanda with 4.4 per cent bribery index. Releasing the report on Friday at Kaskazi Beach hotel in Diani-Kwale Transparency International program officer Coast region, Francis Kaeru said they managed to talk to 2245 people in about 45 counties in Kenya on the issue of bribery and corruption. The report ranked police department number one among the governments departments which asks for bribe for them to give services to Kenyans for the last six years since they started releasing the annual report on bribery and corruption in East Africa. Kaeru said that police are followed by Registry and licensing department and third department is the Judiciary. He said that out of ten governments departments Police, Judiciary and lands ministry officials are worst corrupt with 70.7 per cent, 46.7 per cent and 38.3 per cent respectively. "Land ministry is leading in taking the highest bribe of Sh8, 949, Judiciary is the second taking Sh8, 390, County and local councils take Sh5, 637 while police take Sh4, 411. That is the average size of bribe that those departments ask from wananchi if they go to get services from their offices," he said. Kaeru said that it is amazing that Judiciary which Kenyans had been trusted to reform that it takes double the bribe which police ask from locals so that they can serve them. "Most of Kenyans said that they give bribe so that they can get services quickly from government officials and to avoid trouble with authority among other reasons according to the survey. That means service delivery by government officials to wananchi is very poor because of bribery," he added. He said that the survey also indicates that the level of bribe and corruption among government officials in the country since August 2012 and August 2013 has increased. Kaeru said that out of 10 Kenyans who were interviewed only 1would report bribe and corruption cases if he or she is asked to pay bribe. "Over 90 per cent Kenyans decline reporting bribe and corruption cases to agencies tasked to deal with such cases like Ethics and Ant-corruption commission (EACC) Transparency International according to our survey while only 10 per cent reports bribery cases, "he said. The TI official said that although cases of corruption are increasing everyday no reports are made on the same by those affected. He said that if nothing is done to curb the vice then corruption in the next one year to come will be worst urging Kenyans, leaders and organizations to stand together and fight corruption. Transparency International recommendations are; improving service delivery by sacking government officials found corrupt like it is the manifesto of the Jubilee government and coming up with laws to help in dealing with corruption especially empowering ant-corruption body. County governments to have laws to govern them in using public funds and locals to be sensitized that giving bribe is illegal and government service are ones rights. The organization also recommended that Kenyans should report corrupt cases to relevant organizations for action to be taken in curbing corruption in the country.

TITLE: IFMIS Will End Corruption in the Counties [opinion]
SUBJECT: COUNTIES (92%); COUNTY GOVERNMENT (91%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); MISCONDUCT (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (76%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (74%); ECONOMIC NEWS (73%); EVIDENCE (72%); ARRESTS (71%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (67%) Kenya; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Over the last few months, there has been hue and cry over the Integrated Financial Information System (IFMIS) accounting system adopted by Treasury some years ago. Most of the blame heaped on IFMIS is neither sincere nor innocent. The "institutional resistance" to IFMIS has everything to do with the system's ability to deter financial impropriety and crime - period! Those criticizing the IFMIS system for alleged systematic inefficiency forget to say that poor exposure of the workings of the system is normal with any technology. Instead of demonizing technology, they should be familiarizing themselves with the workings of this crucial solution to public finance management. With the devolution of huge amounts of financial resources to the 47 counties, the adoption of the IFMIS is now more critical than at any other time in our history. Operations of most of the 47 county governments have been slowed or even plagued by teething challenges that can be arrested. Providing a solution to financial management at the county level will forestall corruptions at the lower tiers of government and ensure that development will finally 'trickle down' to the grassroots. Treasury has a role in ensuring that county governments adopt the IFMIS system since it has the mandate to implement systems that would lead to better management of the financial resources accruing to the county governments. And contrary to those who believe that county governments have absolute control of the financial resources handed over to them by the national government, 'our' devolution is based on a system of interdependence and cooperation between the two levels of government. Some of the objectives of devolution are to promote social and economic development as well as the provision of "proximate, easily accessible services throughout the country." To enable them function properly, the constitution has enabled the counties to access reliable sources of revenue for governance and delivery of services in an effective manner. But what have we done to ensure that the official delegation of authority and massive financial resources does not result to the devolvement of grand corruption and the likely malfeasance it can yield? Although county governments have the power to administer and spend revenue, the experience we've had since independence is that their predecessors, local authorities, lacked the capacity to do so. As a result, most had insufficient resources to run their affairs. But there is also compelling evidence that even the limited amount of resources they acquired was drained off by corrupt officials. This is definitely not what we want the new county governments to replicate and hence the need for the IFMIS system. Under the Constitution, the 47 county governments are empowered to raise and spend all their revenues, but also to share what is collected by the national government. This means that cash collected from across the country must be shared by all including in places where very little of it was collected. Therefore, it is only right that such cash is used for the purpose for which it was allocated in the first place and for the entire county to adopt absolute transparency and a watertight system of ensuring accountability. In more ways than one, IFMIS ensure this. The Cabinet Secretary in-charge of the national treasury has the powers to stop the transfer of finances including 50 per cent of the funds allocated to a county government whenever there is sufficient evidence of misuse of public finances. The adoption of IFMIS by the national government in 1998 and its extension into ministries and public institutions is properly within the law. What is now needed is for it to be extended to county governments so that wananchi can get a value for their money. Dr. Njoroge Obadiah Kimani is a public finance consultant and an advocate. info@kimaniandassociates.com
